PETITION.TITLE: Violent Television Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that:
We are concerned about the increase in violent television programmes for children and particularly those programmes promoting violent toys that are available for sale in Australia.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That you support the Broadcasting (Prohibition of Violent Programmes for Children) Act 1988 which has been presented by WA Independent Senator for Nuclear Disarmament, Jo Vallentine. This act aims to prohibit the broadcasting of children's TV programmes that are violent and that promote toys modelled on characters, weapons or other war accessories which are also available for sale in Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Alston (from 13 citizens), Patterson (from 19 citizens) and Vallentine (from 13 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: X-rated and Violent Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Parliamentary Joint Select Committee on Video Material has concluded that ``Adverse effects upon people, and especially upon children, of exposure to material containing various degrees of violence, pornography or obscenity have been demonstrated''.
The majority of the Select Committee strongly opposed the proposition for a new NVE (non-violent erotica) category, which would have entrenched X-rated video pornography.
All six State Governments have, through their Attorneys-General expressed unanimous opposition to the circulation of X-rated videos.
We consider the continuing distribution of X-rated videos from the A.C.T. to be reprehensible and to be contrary to the wellbeing of the Australian community in general.
We strongly request urgent Government action to prohibit the distribution of X-rated and excessively violent video material.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Drugs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens showeth:

that your petitioners deplore the Federal Government's decision to remove 53 Pharmaceutical drugs-including the best available for the treatment of high blood pressure, cancer, epilepsy, high cholesterol and uneven heartbeat-and place them for cost saving reasons only on a special list requiring authority from a Canberra bureaucrat, and

that we believe a patient's doctor is clearly the best judge for medication needed for their particular illness and that it is therefore wrong and unfair to force that doctor to waste valuable time referring a case to a person in Canberra who has no personal knowledge of that case.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled will call on the Government to immediately abandon the proposal and keep its election promise of high quality and universal health care for all Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: X-rated Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

We the undersigned, note that a majority of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material has strongly opposed the proposition that a new NVE category will contain that material as defined in the current `X' classification; we call upon the Senate to request the Government immediately to introduce substantive legislation to ban X-rated video material (and its R-rated equivalent) and to refuse classification for the purpose of Commonwealth laws.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Kakadu National Park
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament
The petition of the undersigned shows:
That we oppose any mineral exploration or mining in any part of Kakadu National Park, the Kakadu Conservation Zone, or the Alligator Rivers Region.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
Halt all mineral exploration and mining in the Kakadu conservation zone by revoking current leases and licences and by incorporating the zone in Kakadu National Park and;

Prevent proposed mining in Kakadu stages one and two by incorporating the Jabiluka and Koongarra project areas in the National Park and by proclaiming the whole park under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act, 1983.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Violent and Pornographic Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Australian Capital Territory respectfully showeth; We ask that the Federal Government take immediate action to arrest the spread of violent and pornographic printed and video material within Australia and to have existing material withdrawn to a point where this country once more achieves acceptable standards of social and moral behaviour. As a first step towards this objective, we ask that the Government immediately:
(a) amend the Customs Prohibited Imports Regulations to once more render it illegal for excessively violent and pornographic material to be imported into Australia, and

(b) amend the ACT Classification of Publications Ordinance to prohibit the importation into, production within, and distribution from the ACT of R and X-Rated video material and pornographic literature.

We urge the Government to recognise that it is inappropriate for the National Capital to be the distribution point from which violent and pornographic material can legally be sent by mail order to residents of the various States in which this material has been banned, and to take the steps necessary to redress this situation.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
Recent huge rises in mortgage interest rates have pushed the cost of buying their own home beyond the reach of most Australian families.

Those Australians already paying off home mortgages are now suffering severely and unfairly through increased mortgage payments or longer repayment times so that many will never pay off their mortgage and go further and further into debt unless interest rates fall substantially.

Now, therefore, your petitioners request that the Senate in Parliament assembled require the Hawke-Keating government to cease its excessive reliance on high interest rates as its major economic policy weapon and instead to use other measures which would allow interest rates to return to levels that do not force most Australian home-seekers out of the housing market-and many Australians out of their homes-so that the traditional right of home ownership is returned to average Australian families.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Violent and Pornographic Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of citizens of Australia points out that the community deplores the persistent refusal to ban pornography in X and NVE Videos, Films and Publications, and deplores the resulting escalation of crime and sexual crime in the Australian community.
Because Parliament has a direct and heavy obligation to ensure the safety of women and child-victims, your petitioners therefore request the House:
to ban the importation, and availability of pornography in Videos, Films and Publications,
to prevent black-market trading by banning the possession of X and NVE material,
vote against any recommendation to extend Video and Theatre Film Classifications and Guidelines into television standards,
ensure that Pay Television does not exceed the programme LIMITS of Television STANDARDS,
control ALL censorship criteria and guidelines by substantive legislation,

give earnest consideration to these matters, in order that NO Attorney-General shall ever again have the POWER to change our social and home environment for generations to come, without thorough and full debate in both Houses of Parliament.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This Bill will amend the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954 and will repeal the Aged or Disabled Persons Hostels Act 1972

The major purpose of this Bill is to introduce new arrangements to enable improved planning and financial management in the hostel sector. In addition, the Bill proposes measures that will ensure better targeting of subsidised hostel services to those aged people in need of such care and introduces provisions to assist people seeking to avail themselves of respite care services in a hostel.

The Bill also seeks to overcome an inconsistency between nursing homes and hostels by enabling moneys borrowed or received from Commonwealth or State governments, or from other sources, to be taken into account when calculating the amount of capital grant in relation to a nursing home. This provision already exists for hostels.

The Bill provides for the repeal of the Aged or Disabled Persons Hostels Act 1972 while preserving any outstanding entitlements under the Act through the grant of an approval in principle under the new provisions in the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954.

In 1986 the Government endorsed the findings of the nursing homes and hostels review which recognised that there was a need to develop a total aged care policy with an expanded range of care options to meet individual needs. As part of the strategy to meet this need, the Government has introduced a series of measures directed at the expansion and better resourcing of the sector.

The discussion document entitled Equitable Funding Base for Hostels, released by the Department in October 1987, made a number of recommendations along these lines, concerning, in particular, the integration of funding and planning for the expanding hostel sector. Primarily these recommendations proposed the introduction of an approval in principle and approval process for hostels to ensure that Commonwealth capital and recurrent funding would in future be provided only to those hostels meeting an identified need.

To establish the framework for the approval in principle and approval mechanisms, amendments introduced by this Bill enable the Minister to determine the maximum number of hostel places to be funded on a recurrent basis for each State and Territory in a financial year, and to specify the distribution of these hostel places among planning regions. These maxima will be specified by a Gazette notice.

Clause 9 of the Bill also introduces a provision that prevents the Minister from granting an approval in principle or approving additional hostel places for recurrent funding if the effect of doing so would cause the maximum number of committed hostel places in a State, Territory or region to be exceeded.

The allocation of hostel resources will be determined on the basis of the Government's objective to provide 100 residential care places for 1,000 people aged 70 and over, with a mix, within this 100, of 60 hostel places to 40 nursing home places. In determining priorities in line with this objective, the Minister will take into account advice provided by the aged care advisory committees.

On 15 July this year the Minister for Housing and Aged Care announced that the Government plans to approve 4,244 new places in 1988-89, 4,723 in 1989-90, and 4,738 in 1990-91; 13,705 additional places overall, of which 12,296 will be for hostels and 1,409 for nursing homes. These new hostel places will be accommodated within the State or Territory and regional maxima to be gazetted for the corresponding relevant periods.

Clause 9 of the Bill also introduces the proposed approval in principle and approval arrangements. A primary objective of these arrangements is to establish firmly for both the eligible organisation and the Commonwealth, the extent of the Commonwealth's financial commitment in terms of recurrent and, where relevant, capital funding, and the conditions that must be fulfilled by the holder of an approval in principle before a formal decision to grant capital moneys or to approve the payment of recurrent subsidy is made. The proposed amendment responds to concerns expressed by service providers that, in the past, the Commonwealth has not always been able to provide assurances, in advance of the commencement of a hostel project that, upon completion, recurrent subsidy will be paid, even though Commonwealth capital funding had been provided. The proposed amendments remove that uncertainty.

As with the comparable provisions of the National Health Act 1953, clause 9 enables an approval in principle to be granted for the construction or purchase of a new hostel, for an extension to an existing hostel, for the demolition and reconstruction of an existing hostel on the same site and the transfer of some or all hostel places from one site to another existing hostel or proposed hostel on another site.

In line with the Government's commitment to improved financial management and planning in the hostel sector, the Bill (clauses 15 and 24) amends the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954 to ensure that all Commonwealth funded hostels, existing and future ones are approved for a fixed number of hostel places.

In future, an organisation wishing to receive recurrent subsidy for an extension to an existing hostel facility will first be required to seek an approval in principle for those additional places. These amendments enable the Commonwealth to control growth in the number of subsidised hostel places, to ensure that any additional places are located where the need exists, and consequently, plan for recurrent expenditure by way of hostel, personal care and respite care subsidies.

Clause 17 paragraph (g) concerns the individual entitlement to respite care. In April this year the Minister for Housing and Aged Care announced that one of the new measures to improve availability of, and access to, respite care would be an individual entitlement to respite care services of 63 days across all hostels or nursing homes. To satisfy the Minister's concerns and those of the industry that the respite arrangements operate effectively, the arrangement proposed in the Bill will enable payment of recurrent subsidy in respect of an eligible person occupying an approved respite care place for a maximum of 63 days in the same hostel in a benefit period. This will be welcomed by organisations providing much needed respite care services for aged people and by those who require such hostel respite care.

The Commonwealth has, on numerous occasions, expressed its policy to target subsidised care services to aged people. This Bill (clauses 19 and 20) introduces measures to ensure that approved hostel places are made available to eligible people, that is, those aged or disabled people assessed as requiring hostel or personal care services, a person who was residing with such a person prior to their commencing to receive care services on a permanent basis and who wishes to continue to reside with that person, and persons who wish to receive hostel care services on a temporary basis, or who wish to receive, and are assessed as requiring, hostel care and personal care services on a temporary basis. Subsidised hostel services are thereby targeted to aged or disabled people who are assessed as requiring such services.

In order to ensure that organisations satisfy, on an ongoing basis, the conditions of recurrent subsidy, the Minister's powers, in the event of a breach of conditions, are to be expanded by this Bill (clause 20) to enable the revocation of the approval of one or more hostel places. The decision to take such action will be subject, of course, to appeal by the organisation and review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (clause 23).

Clearly, it is important that existing hostels should not be disadvantaged by the introduction of these new provisions. The Bill therefore proposes transitional arrangements to deal with the entitlements of all hostels presently in receipt of recurrent subsidy and those for which a capital grant has been made (in part or in full) but which are not yet receiving recurrent subsidy. In particular, the Bill proposes an arrangement to allow organisations conducting existing hostel facilities a transition period of approximately 5 years during which to adjust their existing resident population so as to comply with the requirement that approved hostel places be occupied solely by eligible persons. (clauses 24, 25 and 26).

In addition the Bill enables the formulation of principles for determining, inter alia, the number of hostel places for which an approval or an approval in principle will be granted to an organisation to which these transitional arrangements apply. These principles will be tabled and subject to possible disallowance.
By clause 27 of the Bill the Aged or Disabled Persons Hostels Act 1972 is repealed. This repeal is in fact long overdue, as new approvals under this Act ceased in 1975.

The so-called `hostels' Act provided for up to 100 per cent capital funding for hostels approved under the Act between 1972 and 1975. No recurrent subsidies were provided under the Act. However, organisations which receive capital under the hostels Act are eligible to receive recurrent funding under the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954.

There is a small number of organisations which has outstanding approvals under section 5 of the Act for which, to date, the organisations concerned have not sought capital. This Bill proposes that any such outstanding entitlements would be preserved through the grant of an approval in principle under the new provisions introduced by this Bill.

Unless the Parliament provides otherwise, section 66 of the Constitution prescribes a maximum annual sum for the payment of salaries of Ministers. Amendments to the Ministers of State Act, which sets this sum, are thus required from time to time to cover changes to ministerial salaries.

In its submission to the Tribunal in connection with its 1987 review, the Government proposed that the Tribunal hold a conference similar to the Anomalies Conference convened in that year by the President of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The Tribunal agreed that a conference be held to consider whether special and extraordinary circumstances existed, as provided for under the then current wage principles, which would justify consideration of an anomaly under the pre-existing principles. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present a report of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training entitled Education for Active Citizenship in Australian Schools and Youth Organisations, together with a transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to incorporate the tabling statement in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

I present the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training on `Education for Active Citizenship in Australian Schools and Youth Organisations'. This matter was referred to the Committee on 23 March 1988.

The Committee received 135 submissions to its inquiry and held public hearings in Melbourne, Sydney, Perth and Canberra. In the course of the inquiry, the Committee also distributed a discussion paper on the topic to stimulate further public debate. This paper was tabled in the Senate on 31 August 1988.

The report proposes a national program in education for active citizenship directed in particular at Australia's young people. I hope to speak on this in more detail later. At this stage I simply wish to draw the attention of the Senate to some of the facts which made this inquiry necessary. I believe these facts are a warning signal which Australians ignore at their peril.

Surveys over a number of years now have shown a quite astonishing level of political ignorance in the Australian community. A study shortly after the 1984 Federal Election found that only about 60% of Australians even knew the names of the two Houses of the Federal Parliament-quite apart from what their functions might be. About 40% could not say in which House the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition sat. Among 18 and 19 year olds over half did not know this. A 1985 survey of four high schools in the Brisbane area found that nearly 60% of students could not name either House of Federal Parliament, and over 80% could not say in which house the Prime Minister and Leader of the Opposition sit.

This ignorance extends to the fundamentals of our Federal system. In 1987 a survey showed that only about one in every two Australians knows that we have a constitution-let alone what might be in it. In the 18 to 24 age group only 30% were aware of the Constitution's existence. We can perhaps agree that there is a certain incongruity in parliaments solemnly proposing amendments to the Australian Constitution when over half the population does not even know it exists.

A particularly alarming fact revealed in the course of our inquiry is that school teachers, whose responsibilities include education for active citizenship, are themselves frequently ignorant about Australia's political and governmental systems. One submission, from an institution in South Australia responsible for teacher education, reported that in a test administered to student teachers only one student in 55 could pass a rudimentary test, the knowledge tested being little more than that which is required of people to vote. Other evidence we received suggests that many teachers are not only ignorant about Australia's democracy but also apathetic about the whole topic.

It was against this background that my Committee pursued its inquiry. We know that being an active citizen involves much more than simply answering questions in a political quiz. But the ignorance we found is indicative, we believe, of a widespread `don't know, don't care' attitude in the Australian community.

The Committee has called for a national program to deal with this problem. We describe the situation as `a crisis Australians cannot afford to ignore'. It is a sobering thought that only about five nations in the world, apart from Australia, have enjoyed continuous democratic government since the turn of the century. If we are complacent about our democracy we may well find ourselves among those who are destined to lose it.

Finally I wish to draw attention to three particular points of interest. The Committee took the view at the outset of its inquiry that there would be great value in hearing the views of students themselves on the topic it was considering. Accordingly, we included year 11 and 12 students in our list of witnesses at public hearings in Canberra, Perth and Sydney. In all, we heard from students from seven different secondary schools. This was a valuable experience and the students' views made a useful contribution to the Committee's thinking in formulating its report.

Secondly, the Committee formed the view that one of the many aspects of Australia's parliamentary system which is not well understood by the Australian people is the role of parliamentary committees themselves. Accordingly, the Committee suggested to the Parliamentary Education Office that there could be advantage in producing an educational videotape explaining the work of committees, using the inquiry into education for active citizenship as a major focus. The Parliamentary Education Office took up this proposal enthusiastically and I am happy to say that the production of this videotape is now at an advanced stage. The Committee hopes that it will prove a valuable educational aid.

Finally, the Committee has decided to make its report available in large print and on audio-tape for the benefit of print-handicapped people. The Committee believes that this step is particularly important for a report such as this which raises issues of concern to all Australians. I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw particular attention to what the Committee and the community said about the low levels of political knowledge and participation in this country. Many examples were brought to our attention through surveys and submissions. This report provides recommendations to try to overcome that problem. Very quickly, I indicate that the Committee believes that the aims of this Parliament should make itself known to the rest of the community and as a whole and to have the functions of the Senate in particular understood by the community.

SPEECH.PARA: One area of this Parliament that we believe needs promoting is the workings of the committee system. With that in mind we have enlisted the support of the Parliamentary Education Office, which has produced a videotape of the whole inquiry for use as an education aid. As I have indicated in my tabling speech, this report is intended, because of its subject matter, to have wide circulation. So again we have moved in a different direction and asked that the report be made available to the outside community in large print versions and on audio tape for the benefit of print handicapped people. I commend the report to the Senate. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate, on International Women's Day-
(a) applauds the efforts of farsighted and courageous women who have worked to improve the status of other women;

(b) pledges to fully recognise the contribution of women in the family and in the community and to continue to work to improve the status of women towards the goal of true economic, educational and social equality;

(c) recognises the achievements of the women's movement and those who have supported improvement in the status of women, but acknowledges that true equality between the sexes has yet to be achieved; and

(d) notes that true equality of opportunity includes the freedom of choice of women to support children outside of paid employment and that such a choice requires greater recognition of and support for the unpaid work of mothers.

When organising this last night I thought, with the agreement of the Government as well as the Australian Democrats, that we said we would speak briefly so that all those in the Senate who are interested in women's achievements and the women's debate generally would have an opportunity on this, International Women's Day, to contribute. So it was with some surprise that this morning I heard the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Robert Ray) launch into an argument that in some way this motion is disturbing the Government business before the chamber. I guess that is not surprising because the Government, as we read in this morning's press, is highly sensitive to its falling ratings in relation to the women's vote. When Government members read this morning's newspapers not only are they reminded of what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said to them yesterday-that they must face up to the fact that the women of Australia are deserting the Government-but also that their former stalwart, former Senator Susan Ryan, is telling them that what is needed at the moment is more action and less rhetoric. I am not surprised that Senator Ray sought in some way to divert the debate from what is an important issue; that is, the place that the debate on the status of women has reached and what should be done in future to continue that debate in both rhetoric and substance.

I am pleased to have moved the motion on behalf of the Opposition parties-the Liberal Party and the National Party-because both have a proud record on the status of women. According to Joyce Stevens's book A History of International Women's Day, the day has been variously seen as a time for asserting women's political and social rights, for reviewing the progress that women have made or as a day for celebration. Therefore, it seems most appropriate that this motion-the only motion that was given in these terms yesterday-be moved from this side of the chamber. Although the Hawke Government has developed the myth that it invented the cause of equality, on this occasion I want to remind the Senate of some of the substantive initiatives and some of the women who have contributed from this side of the chamber and of whom we are so proud.

Let me start by referring to some of the achievements of previous coalition governments which are conveniently overlooked by the Hawke propaganda campaign. I remind the Senate that the former McMahon coalition Government introduced the Child Care Act of 1972. I also remind the Senate of the introduction by the Fraser Liberal Government in 1976-77 of family allowances paid directly to the mother. This Government has not allowed family allowances to keep pace with inflation. The establishment of the National Women's Advisory Council in 1977 was another achievement of a coalition government. The Office of the Status of Women, formerly known as the Office of Women's Affairs, was established in 1976. It is worthwhile reminding this Government and the Australian community that that was an initiative of the Liberal-National coalition Government.

I also mention the formation of the Office of Child Care in the Department of Social Security in 1976; the Superannuation Act of 1976, which gave equal treatment to female public servants; the establishment in 1980 of the Institute of Family Studies; the extension of eligibility for pensioner health benefits to single parents and dependants in 1979; and the development in 1983 of the family income supplement scheme to assist low income families. I could go on. That is just a taste of some of the achievements of former Liberal-National Party coalition governments in the field of improving the status of women.
Let us consider the achievement within Australian politics of such outstanding womenas Dame Enid Lyons, the first woman member of the House of Representatives--

TALK.START.PARA: —And a Tasmanian.

—And a Tasmanian. I understand that Dame Florence Cardell Oliver, a Liberal, was our first State Cabinet Minister in Western Australia. I also understand that Dame Annabelle Rankin was the first woman government Whip in any Westminster-style parliament. We all know of Dame Margaret Guilfoyle. One could go on and list the many women parliamentarians from this side of the chamber who have contributed so much to the Australian political scene and to advancing the cause of women.
—Amanda Vanstone, for instance.

—Senator Collins is going to attempt to debase the debate in his usual fashion. But I remind you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that the first women elected to each State parliament were from the non-Labor side of parliament. This is something that perhaps is not well appreciated within the community.
—Who was it, Robert?
—Do honourable senators opposite want me to read the names in each State?
—No, we want the first girl. Tell us her name.

—Honourable senators opposite wanted a 10-minute debate; they can have a half hour debate. They want to know who were the first women elected to parliament in all States. In 1921 Mrs Edith Cowan, a Nationalist, was the first woman elected to the Western Australian Parliament; in New South Wales Miss M. Stanley, also from the Nationalist Party, was elected in 1925; in Queensland, Mrs I. Longman, also from the Nationalist Party, was elected in 1929; in Victoria Lady Peacock, from the United Australia Party, was elected in 1933; in Tasmania Dame F. Miller and Miss A. Best, from the Liberal Party, were elected in 1955; and in South Australia Mrs Steele and Mrs Cooper, from the Liberal Party, were elected in 1955. In every State of Australia the first women to be elected to the respective parliaments came from the non-Labor side of politics. If that is the information Senator Collins was seeking, I hope he is now satisfied. The natural place for reformist women, as I was saying, has always been with our parties. As I indicated, their achievements are worth remembering on this day.

SPEECH.PARA: In contrast, the Hawke Government will be remembered for its hype, glitter, and self-glorification, which Australian women are now seeing through. Australian women have been reminded, not only by us but also by such objective bodies as the Institute of Family Studies, by the Government's own chief economic advisory group, the Economic Planning Advisory Council, and, most recently, by the Women's Electoral Lobby at the Women's Tax Convention last Saturday, that in so many material ways Australian women are now worse off under this Labor Government. In other words, Australian women have been cheated, and that is the sad legacy that this Government will leave to history. I make no apology for introducing a moderately partisan approach to this debate because--

TALK.START.PARA: —Moderate!

—Everything I do is moderate. As Joyce Stevens said, `It is a time to review progress and progress is a subjective term'. The Government boasts-I think we heard Senator Crowley boasting last week-of record numbers of women in employment as an achievement. But it is clear that many are there today as economic conscripts.
—So are men.
—Women particularly are forced by falling living standards, as I will demonstrate--
—Men are not economic conscripts, Senator?

—There are many men who are economic conscripts under this Government; that is true. But the important thing is that, while more women have gone into the work force, an increasing percentage are on lower levels of income, below average weekly earnings. That is the point that Senator Collins should take note of and that is the point that Australian women are recognising.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, there are no more appropriate words than `economic conscripts'-forced by falling living standards and a lack of family support by this Government into low paid jobs with little satisfaction or prospects for advancement. More than 50 per cent of such women are now in employment that pays less than average weekly earnings, and that percentage is rising. By the time women pay record high taxes, pay high child care costs and either pay or contribute to enormous mortgages or high rents, they are left with little in material terms for their labour. In other words, the mere fact that more women are entering employment is not necessarily in itself something to boast about. I refer this Government-if it is not prepared to accept my words-to the Secretary-General to the United Nations in his report to last year's General Assembly of the UN under the agenda item `Implementation of the Nairobi Forward Looking Strategies for the Advancement of Women'. This will be appreciated, no doubt, by Senator Giles, who contributed at the Nairobi conference, which should be recognised. I ask the Labor Government to consider particularly the Secretary-General's statement:

Although there may be an increase in women's contribution to economic and social aspects of life, it does not necessarily follow that there will be a proportionate increase in the benefits they derive. Moreover, although the United Nations Decade for Women stimulated the reform of laws that discriminated against women and the adoption of new ones providing for equal rights and opportunities, the improved situation de jure may not be reflected by the de facto situation in many economic and social areas.

That is the picture in this country. The economic position of women, the changes of laws and the new institutions that have been developed have not produced the economic advancement that it was believed would logically follow. I would suggest, and I have always wanted to be fair in these debates, that real progress is better demonstrated by the larger number of young women starting at university. This is another point that Senator Giles made the other day. It is something that we on this side of the chamber are pleased to note. If more were starting in faculties such as engineering or, in other words, non-traditional areas, it would be recognised as even greater progress. Thus we say on this important day that it should not be just a day to assert the political and social rights of women, it should also be a day to assert their economic rights. It is this area that has been primarily overlooked by this Labor Government. Despite all the hype the Government attaches to the women's portfolio and all the self-congratulations which the Government continues to pour on itself, it has overlooked women's economic rights. It is summed up in the expression that I hear so often from women's organisations, namely, the goals of financial independence and financial security. First and paramount, they are expressed to us by women and women's organisations as their goals and they are the principal areas in which they feel they have been let down by this Government.

Therefore, it was not surprising that at last Saturday's Women's Tax Convention-and I take the opportunity to congratulate the National Women's Consultative Council and the Women's Electoral Lobby on organising it-the predominant themes were recognition of the unpaid work of women and mothers; the need for greater support for mothers of dependent children-for example, restoring the value of family allowances, which this Government has let drop; a message to this Government to abandon additional imposts on women in regard to retraining and upgrading of education, and in particular Labor's higher education tax; and reform in such areas as superannuation so that women might have an equal chance to plan their own futures in the same way as do men.

In reviewing progress there is much to celebrate on this day. There are many women to applaud, and indeed many women who should be applauded but who will never be recognised because of the system of reward in this country, which does not necessarily recognise women's achievements. It was most pleasing at the women's 1988 awards last year that an attempt was made to recognise women who had achieved in areas that are not the traditional areas for which reward is given under our system of values. There are many women who should be recognised and who are not.

It is also important today, as we say in our motion, to accept that there is a great deal yet to be achieved. The principal point that we want to make is that the women's issues debate within our community has moved on and that it is now a hard-nosed economic debate. Women are a demanding constituency. They now recognise that they have been sold short by this Government in terms of their economic opportunity and the opportunity to achieve economic self-reliance. For that this Government will suffer the consequences.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator REYNOLDS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Local Government and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that the Senate is having this important debate on International Women's Day. I would like to think that Senator Hill is absolutely genuine in bringing forward this notice of motion and that there is no hint of cynicism in his views. I must admit that, having been involved in international women's days since 1971, and having not been aware of the visibility of Senator Hill or indeed of any other Liberal member on such days, I cannot help having a trace of cynicism about today's notice of motion. However, I am trying very hard to put that behind me. I know that there are Opposition members who genuinely want to see a bipartisan approach to the recognition of the status of women and what has been achieved. Senator Hill was gracious enough to point out some of the achievements that I believe he attributes, somewhat grudgingly perhaps, to the last six years of the Hawke Labor Government. His predecessor, Senator Vanstone, was much more generous in a speech to Liberal women some time last year, when she said:

SPEECH.PARA: We agree that the Commonwealth Government's economic policies are the means by which the Government can best ensure a bright and secure future for present and future members of our nation.

That is a direct quote from the National Agenda for Women. On election night last year, when describing the relationship between the Liberal Party and the Australian Labor Party, John Howard remarked:

What unites us is far greater than that which divides us. It is equally true when used to describe the relationship between the Liberal Party and the Labor Party women and issues affecting the status of women. There are many areas where there are improvements to be made and we share with Labor a commitment to find the right solutions.

That is a very constructive way for us to move forward in this debate. Obviously I support a number of the sentiments that were expressed in the motion today. My colleague Senator Pat Giles will talk about the contributions of a number of key women from our side of politics to all that has been achieved to raise the status of women over the last 15 years or so. Regardless of the views that have been put forward about the lack of progress of the Hawke Government-I think Senator Hill described the Government's contribution in this regard as `glitzy hype'-at least it attracted Senator Hill's attention. It has certainly put status of women issues on his agenda, if not necessarily on that of his party. I understand that it is fairly difficult for the status of women policy committee of Senator Hill's party to meet. It certainly does not meet with the same degree of regularity that the Government's status of women policy committee meets.

For the record, I will run through what we have done to change the type of Australia in which Australian women now participate and in which young women will participate. Since 1983 the annual employment growth rate for women has been 4 per cent, and there has been an historically high women's participation rate of 51.3 per cent. A number of Opposition members have criticised that and said that women do not want to work in paid employment, whether full time or part time. That was not the message I received at the Women's Tax Convention. Certainly, the question of choice is and always will be vital. Women are entitled to a choice.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you are not giving that choice.

—Senator Walters claims that we are not giving the choice, but she is not able to come forward with valid reasons as to why women are entering the work force in greater numbers. The unemployment rates for women and young women have dropped from 13.7 and 9 per cent in 1983 to 11.2 and 7.5 per cent respectively. The Government has taken legislative measures to ensure that women have a protected role within the work force. We have seen a dramatic increase in the education participation rate of girls. It increased from 44 per cent in 1983 to 61.8 per cent in 1988. All these measures, coupled with a dramatic increase in the numbers of child-care places, the young homeless allowance, the great expansion of the supported accommodation program, indicate that the Government has been very serious in putting status of women policy issues firmly on the agenda.

SPEECH.PARA: Nobody would claim that all goals have been achieved. Of course, enormous problems still face women. The mere fact that 90 per cent of one-parent families are headed by women indicates that women have a tremendous task in balancing and juggling the demands of child-care responsibilities with their responsibilities of making ends meet. We understand the problems that they face in this regard. For this reason, the Government introduced payments targeted at low income families with children. Of course, that has particularly benefited women. I remind honourable senators that in 1983 payments for children had fallen to 11.1 per cent of the married rate of pension. We have committed ourselves to payments of 15 per cent of the married rate of pension for children under 13 and 20 per cent of the married rate of pension for children under 16. We have increased payments for children seven times in seven Budgets, from $10 a week in 1983 to $24 a week for children under 13 and $31 a week for children up to 16 years in 1989. I contrast that with what the Opposition did when in government. It claims that it has a commitment to improving conditions for women, but when in office for seven years it increased payments for children only once.

We now have this debate about who has done more to ensure that status of women issues are on the political agenda. Senator Hill rightly pointed to the role of Liberal Party women in terms of their participation in the Parliament. He also rightly outlined a number of initiatives of the former Liberal Government. It is only fair to point out that although the Opposition had an Office of the Status of Women, it was not located at the centre of action within the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. I have continually tried to demonstrate to a number of honourable senators on the other side the role of the Office of the Status of Women. Its role is to act as a catalyst, a coordinator, and a monitor of so many things that are happening across all government departments. Under this Government, a women's budget has been brought down. We never had a women's budget statement in the days of the Fraser Government. We never had an automatic monitoring by each government department of precisely what is happening in the Public Service in terms of policies for women and their participation within the Public Service.
The Liberal Party says very little about its policies. It is very quick to attack the Government, but we hear very little about its policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —You'll hear all about it.
—We wait breathlessly for them.
—I am glad you are waiting, because our policy will be an improvement on what you will achieve.

—When I paid for my copy of Future Directions-I think I paid for it-I was under the impression that all the answers would be in that publication. I thought that if I read Future Directions I would be able to understand what the coalition had in mind for the next election, or at least be well informed about its discussion. During debate on Monday, Senator Vanstone said that Future Directions was not a policy document. If it is not a policy document, what is it?
—It is a con job. It is a bigger con than instant lottery.

—Talking of a lottery, perhaps on this International Women's Day we could launch a competition asking: what is Future Directions? If it is not a policy, what is it? People around Australia could give their opinions about what it is.

SPEECH.PARA: I will ask Senator Hill a few questions which I hope he will ensure are answered by contributors to the debate this morning. The Liberals need to answer some questions about what a coalition government would mean for women. We know what happened when there was a change of government in Tasmania. When Robin Gray took over as the Liberal Premier of Tasmania, he dismantled the women's unit in Tasmania and dismissed the women's adviser. In fairness, the Premier of New South Wales has not gone that far. But he has certainly marginalised the women's unit in New South Wales by taking it away from the Premier's Department and placing it in the Department of Community Services.

Of course women are vitally concerned with community services. But they are also concerned with health, education, housing, Treasury and Attorney-General matters, et cetera. If women's units are not located at the centre of government decision-making, women and women's issues will be marginalised. As I have said, the women's unit in Tasmania has been abolished and in New South Wales the Liberal Government has marginalised women's issues by putting the women's unit into the Department of Community Services.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under a woman Minister.

—Yes, under a woman Minister. Is this what the women of Australia can expect from a coalition government-the dismantling of the Office of the Status of Women? The author of Future Directions talks about a review of the role of the Office of the Status of Women and gives absolutely no clear commitment.

SPEECH.PARA: Furthermore, on page 34, Future Directions commits a coalition government to the immediate abolition of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. Senator Hill says that he is committed to equal employment opportunities for women and I do not doubt him. Equality of opportunity is actually mentioned in Future Directions. But how is a coalition government going to implement our sex discrimination legislation? How is it going to implement affirmative legislation? Is it going to abolish the Affirmative Action Agency as well? It has been very quiet about this agency. At least it has come out and said, `Yes, we will abolish the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission', but it is quieter about the Affirmative Action Agency. Would it actually repeal legislation which entrenches equality of opportunity in the work force? Would it support the Government's forthcoming amendments to the Sex Discrimination Act which remove the general exemption for superannuation?

Future Directions, at pages 46 and 74, wants to encourage private child-care provision. Would this result in the dismantling of the children's services program? Would a coalition government retain the nexus between education and income security allowances for young people? Would it retain the Child Support Agency which, to date, has effected a $47 a week increase in income for 83,000 sole parent families? Would it continue the Hawke Government's commitment to benchmark payments for low income families with children under the family allowance supplement? Would it question the adequacy of those benchmarks? How would it amend the taxation system and at what cost? Would this be done through universal payments, income splitting or child-care rebates?

The last policy of the coalition stated that the dependent spouse rebate would be decreased by $30. Would that rebate now be increased to fit in with the broad sentiments of Senator Hill's motion? Does this mean that a coalition government would return universal, indexed family allowances to real 1976 values? That would cost an estimated $1.7 billion. Is that what is meant by the statement of page 1 of Future Directions that the coalition is committed to smaller government with less interference? Yet, apparently Senator Hill wants to introduce some form of homemakers allowance. What is this allowance going to cost? Will it mean the introduction of income splitting, as mooted by the coalition in the last election as part of a tax package that would have had to be funded with a $2.5 billion cut in services? Senator Hill should remember, as should Senator Newman when she returns to the chamber, that income splitting was rejected by the Women's Tax Convention, as was a commitment to cutbacks in public expenditure.

I have a number of concerns about what the coalition government would do if it were ever given the chance to implement its policies regarding the status of women. We hear a lot of rhetoric from Senator Hill. Frankly, I believe that he would like to do more than his Party and the coalition would probably be able to do. We know that the Liberal Party does have progressive small `l' liberals. We know that spokespeople, like Senator Peter Baume and Mr Ian Macphee, have a very high regard for the issues which the Government sees as very important in raising the status of women. I believe that Senator Hill has the same kind of commitment, but the problem for Senator Hill, Senator Baume and Ian Macphee is that they have to contend with the troglodytes from the National Party of Australia-and I do not include Senator Bjelke-Petersen in that remark. I think on International Women's Day 1989 there is a great deal which women can look forward to under a Labor Government, but there are many uncertainties if a coalition government were to be elected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion before the Senate states:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate, on International Women's Day:
(a) applauds the efforts of farsighted and courageous women who have worked to improve the status of other women;

(b) pleges itself to full recognition of the contribution of women in the family and in the community and to continue to work to improve the status of women towards the goal of true economic, educational and social equality;

(c) recognises the achievements of the Women's Movement and those who have supported improvement in the Status of Women but acknowledges that true equality between the sexes has yet to be achieved; and

(d) notes that true equality of opportunity includes the freedom of choice of women to support children outside of paid employment and that such a choice requires greater recognition and support of the unpaid work of mothers.

Certainly, there is not going to be any argument from the Australian Democrats on any of those points. Senator Hill will have to realise that far more than mere words is needed to secure the vote of women across the country if the Opposition parties wish to gain government. Just as Mr Hawke's rather patronising comments last week, ordering his Ministers to clean up their language so that they can continue to appeal to women voters, will not work, neither will the Opposition's words in this motion convince most women-especially those on low incomes, those who are sole supporting parents and those working women blamed by the conservative forces for youth unemployment-that the Liberals are really committed to equality. He will have to do much more than simply moving a motion on International Women's Day which says, `We have still got a long way to go', and praising the efforts of those people who have got women where they are today.

Senator Hill ran through a list of women who have been elected to parliament, pointing out that until well into the fifties most of them belonged to the Nationalist Party or the United Australia Party. However, I would also point out that one of those women, namely Joyce Steele-not, I might add, as Senator Hill said, Jessie Steele-was elected to the Legislative Council in South Australia in 1956. However, she had to face a challenge by another member of the Liberal Party who argued that women were not `persons' under the meaning of the Act. That sort of thing has happened before. In 1907, a judge in Western Australia ruled that women could not be lawyers or notaries public because the legislation said that persons who had achieved the academic qualifications could go into the professions and that women were not defined as persons. He argued that if the parliament had wanted them to be defined as persons such a definition would have been in the legislation. He therefore threw out the request by the women who had qualified, as a lawyer, to engage in their profession. That was bad enough for 1907, and on numbers of occasions something similar has happened in Britain and the United States, but the Liberal Party pulled the same trick in 1956. The number of women in the parliaments around Australia who come from the Liberal and National parties has not improved a great deal since then. There is one only in the House of Representatives. Certainly, there is a fair share, and a high quality share, of women in the Senate, but if honourable senators look at the chamber parties which form government around Australia they will see that there are very few women indeed.

It is no good Senator Hill patting himself and his Party on the back for establishing child-care facilities either, when for years when they were in government they allowed businessmen to claim lunches as a tax deduction and refused to amend section 51a of the Income Tax Assessment Act so that child-care could be a tax deduction or rebatable. The fact of the matter is that in this country, like most other countries, more women than men live in poverty, women are worse off economically than men after divorce, and the majority of children living below the poverty line are living in single parent families headed by women.

While I am on the question of single parent families, I wish to scotch for all time the belief that is very strongly held in the community, particularly among conservative forces, that sole supporting parents are almost entirely a group of women made up of nymphomaniac teenagers who wander around this country getting pregnant on an annual basis, probably to different men, in order to become millionaires on the sole supporting parent benefit. There is a myth in the community that somebody on a sole supporting parent benefit has never been married and behaves in a highly immoral way simply in order to live off the welfare system. That is not the case, yet there is still prejudice and antipathy towards women who are raising children on their own. Certainly, they are given none of the assistance-nothing similar, for example, to the dependent spouse rebate-that is given to a husband whose wife is able to stay at home and look after the children.

I agree with Senator Hill that we need to acknowledge the far-sightedness and the courage of women who have worked to get other women into the position that they are in today. It is a very great pity indeed that more young women today-and at my advanced age I refer to young women as those under the age of 35 basically, but certainly those under the age of 25--

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, grandma!

—Senator Collins should not knock grandmotherhood-not today. I think it is a great pity that more young women today are not aware of the courage and the persistence needed to win those young women the rights that they take for granted: the right to vote and the right to be elected to parliament-two rights, I might point out, that were not given at the same time. I think it was 1923 before Victorian women were given the right to be elected to the Parliament. In fact, the right to vote was not something benignly granted to women by Premiers--
—It was 1969 in South Australia in the upper House.

—No; I am talking about the legal right to be elected, not the actual fact of being elected. The right to vote was not something that was given to women because Kingston in South Australia or anybody else thought that women should, as a matter of principle, be given the vote. Women were given the vote because they were expected to vote conservatively and to keep a conservative government in power-and that, of course, was what happened for a long time. There was no altruism in that little bit of legislation, but we got the vote anyway, around the country and slowly around the world. Women fought to be given the right to have access to a university education despite pamphleteers, politicians and medical professionals who said that if women were given the right to have access to a university education it was going to cause all sorts of physical and social problems like atrophy of the uterus, that it would impede lactation and cause marital and nervous breakdowns. They had to fight this sort of prejudice.

SPEECH.PARA: Women had to fight for the right to own property after marriage. In fact, it was something like 1935 before Tasmanian women were given that right, but again the argument was that women did not have the right or, indeed, the capacity, to look after their own property, property which they brought with them into the marriage, including children. Women had to fight to be given the right to keep their children after divorce. They had to fight for the right to be employed after marriage and the right to equal pay. I do not think there is a woman in this chamber who does not recall starting work in an era when, if she was with the public sector, she had, on marriage, to resign from the permanent working force and become temporary staff or, if she was in the private sector, she was fired outright and when, in all the professions, a woman doing the same job as a man was paid less. We still do not have things like equal pay for work of equal value, and that is a sore point in a number of female dominated professions such as the nursing profession, speech therapy and so on, and women are paid a lot less than men in some other jobs.

Women had to fight through things like the sex discrimination legislation and the affirmative action legislation for the right to access to finance in their own right instead of having to find a male guarantor. We have had to fight for things like government subsidised, and hence affordable, child-care, rape crisis centres and women's shelters generally. We are still fighting for the right not to have to leave our own home with our children in the event of domestic violence. I am not sure that we have yet achieved the right to be regarded as intelligent, capable, multitalented members of the human race. We certainly do not appear to have achieved it if we read some of the things that are said about women by members of the business community or the unions. For example, last week's Bulletin quoted a response from somebody in the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) who, when asked if there were any women on its board, responded with a very concise and rather terse, to say nothing of horrified, `God, no!'. Why have women on the board of BHP!

TALK.START.PARA: —Disgraceful.
—As my colleague behind me says, that is obviously regarded as disgraceful, outrageous and improper--
—Not to mention blasphemous.

—Not to mention blasphemous, by the gentleman-and I use the word loosely-who was asked the question. So I say to Senator Hill: yes we are indebted to women such as the Pankhursts and others who faced ridicule, harassment, gaol, force feeding and an assortment of other indignities in order to win the fight for women to vote, to be regarded, at least in that part of the social system, as equal. In Australia we can thank women such as Rose Scott and Vida Goldstein for leading the fight and then being prepared to be role models-not an easy task for anybody moving into a new situation-because they too had to face the abuse and the antagonism directed against them. It does take courage to swim against the tide and these women deserve our thanks and our remembrance for changing laws which discriminated against women as a whole.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been very disturbing indeed in this chamber occasionally to see the number of women on the conservative benches-who would not be here if other women had not fought to change the law, rather than waiting for social attitudes to catch up with it-argue that we should not use the law to improve the status of women any more; that the sex discrimination legislation and the affirmative action legislation were social engineering because not all Australians were unified in wanting it. As I have said, these women would not have been here if, over the last 80 years, laws had not been changed to give them access to this chamber. I might add that this says nothing of one of Senator Hill's male colleagues who argued in 1983 that the Sex Discrimination Act was imposing `compulsory close cohabitation' on men and women in the work force, and he got his knickers into a right twist in this place. One night, no doubt after a jolly good dinner--

TALK.START.PARA: —Life is a learning curve, Senator.
—If life is a learning curve, this man's gradient is indeed steep. This senator came in here and said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister-
who in those days was Senator Susan Ryan-
would be aware that great difficulties have been created by close proximity working relationships between men and women.

Prior to this little piece of wisdom, I might add, he had complained about Telecom workers working underground with poles between them and the fact that long distance truck drivers were going to have somebody of the opposite sex sleeping in the cabin as they drove between Melbourne and Perth. However, this was the one that outdid the lot:

Frequently, marriages of members of parliament and of staff have broken up as a result purely and simply of the close proximity of the couples working together. A sexual relationship may not necessarily develop.
Not, by the way, if we listen to half the rumours that go around this place. To continue:

I have tried to explain to the Minister, but she apparently does not seem able to grasp it, that a wife who is at home caring for three or four children, trying to get them off to school and trying to keep them clean, is aware that her husband is at work surrounded by glamorous women who may very well be endeavouring to use their guile to woo him in some way.
I do not know how you feel about that, Florence, but it worries me a lot. The honourable senator continued:

It is a matter of grave concern to many women in this country that their husbands may in some way be subjected to improper influences. It is a fact of life that that happens, and it is one of the causes for the break up of such marriages.

All I am suggesting to the Minister is that if an employer can see that a difficult situation might arise as a result of such circumstances, and if he can establish that it is reasonable in all the circumstances to discriminate, he ought to be entitled to make that discrimination.
That is a quote from Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —It wasn't one of Senator Lewis's better speeches.

—No names, no pack drill, Senator. It seems to me that, notwithstanding Senator Hill's motion today, we still have a long way to go. Senator Hill raised in his motion questions about the recognition of the contribution of women in the family; the need for true equality between the sexes; and the need to recognise and support the unpaid work of mothers. There is no question at all that those things need to occur, yet in many cases they can be achieved only by changes in this place. I remind Senator Hill that, for women to have true educational equality, they need to have equal access to education. Things such as the imposition of a tertiary tax, to say nothing of the full fees that a Liberal government would impose, will not go any way towards helping women to get into the work force through improved education; nor, might I add, do things such as taking 45-year-old women off the class B widows pension when their youngest child turns 16 and putting them on unemployment benefit help them achieve employment, economic equality or an improved self-esteem. Yet the Opposition supported the Government's move to do just that. Taking 15-year-old children off Austudy when they are in years 11 and 12 will not help either the young girls in that category or the mothers who are trying to keep them at school in order to give them a better chance. Yet the Opposition supported the Government's moves in that regard.

SPEECH.PARA: None of this goes close to matching an attempt by the Fraser Government to seriously penalise women caring for children at home through its attempt to ram through this Parliament what was called then the `wives of strikers legislation'-an attempt by the Fraser Government to penalise the wives and children of men who were on strike by cutting off their access to social security benefits, as if somehow those women and children were in a position to influence the decisions made by their menfolk at or out of the workplace. It still appears that members of the Opposition favour the payment of something like the dependent spouse rebate to the husband and that they regard it as more important than the payment of the family allowance to the wife; otherwise, why do they continue to talk about that while at the same time supporting the Government's heavier means testing on the family allowance? There is more to it than simply talking about the need to achieve true educational, social and economic equality for women. Supporting or opposing legislation in this place is one of the things Opposition senators need to look at.

Maybe the Opposition could go some way towards introducing true equality among the sexes by talking to some of its mates in big business and in the advertising industry, so that women are no longer depicted in the sort of sexual stereotypical way that we see so often when we turn on the television, listen to the radio, or turn the pages of magazines that have advertisements for fax machines consisting primarily of the long legs of what one presumes is an attractive model.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or get them onto the Board of BHP.

—As my colleague from New South Wales has said, we should get them on to the Board of BHP-or at the very least change the attitude of other BHP Board members so that the next time somebody asks them whether there is a woman on the Board they respond not with `God, no' but with `Not yet, but we are working on it'. In between times the men in this chamber might like to look at their own actions with regard to the way they talk about and treat their wives, their daughters and their female staff. There should be a bit of soul searching about their own sharing of work in the home, their own encouragement of their daughters to take advantage of the opportunities that Senator Hill says are so important and that are now available to them, and a recognition perhaps that they could not do any of their own work in this chamber or outside if it were it not for the research and secretarial work of their female as well as their male staff. I am tired of male colleagues walking into a room full of women and saying, `There is nobody here'. They might like to watch the language that they use--
—They don't walk out again, do they?

—That depends, Senator. They might like to watch the sort of language that they use, not whether it is profane-although that would help-but whether they are using pronouns which assume that maleness is the norm and femaleness is abnormal.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the last part of Senator Hill's motion is vitally important. It is about time that recognition and support of the unpaid work of mothers, indeed, unpaid work overall, was acknowledged in this country. It will never be done until we confront Australia's system of national accounts, based as it is on the United Nations system of national accounts which arbitrarily defines as productive only those activities for which money changes hands. Until we challenge that, we will remain in the situation where gross domestic product in most countries that use the United Nations system of national accounts ignores the role of women in the home, to say nothing of voluntary workers, male or female. Any unpaid work will be regarded as irrelevant because it is considered non-productive as far as the arbitrary definition of gross domestic product (GDP) is concerned. It is what is included in GDP that determines government allocation of resources. We can have some of the biggest companies in this country paying no tax but being regarded as productive and getting tax concessions, subsidies and other benefits from governments, while women at home see themselves as being on the end of spending cuts time and again because they are regarded as being non-productive.

I have a vision of a bunch of women at a kindergarten one morning getting together and one saying, `Look, we have got to do something about this. What say, after we've dropped the children off, I come back and I go into your house and I will do your cooking, your cleaning and your shopping?'. I will leave out the rest of the marital obligations for the time being. `You will pay me for that. While I am doing your housework, you can go next door to Beatrix's house and you can do her cooking, cleaning, shopping and mind the baby, and she will pay you for that. By the time we have got around the block, everybody will have been paid for the work they normally do for nothing. GDP will have blown out of all perspective and maybe there will be a recognition that what women do in the home for nothing is productive'. Maybe when that happens we will not see governments of all persuasions arguing that when we are in a tight spot economically it can cut welfare payments, payments to families, payments and funding for education, health care and housing. We will never see any improvement in the status of women, the standard of their living, their economic or educational equality until we recognise that unpaid work is as productive as, and frequently more productive than, some of the paid work that is done in this country and around the world.

The economists will say, `But we can't do that'. Economists are always saying we cannot do things. But they did it for home ownership. If somebody buys a home to rent out, money is changing hands. Money is being earned. Rental property is defined as productive. Living under the roof of one's own house is not defined as productive because one is not earning any money from it. That would have distorted the GDP in most Western countries which have high home ownership levels. What did the economists do? They imputed a value for home ownership. They said, `What would it have earned had it been rented out?'. Why can we not do that for the unpaid work done by women in the home? Insurance companies do when they want to encourage men to take out walloping great insurance policies in the event of the death of a spouse. Most of them have argued that $30,000 is what it would cost to pay someone to do what women do in the house on an annual basis for nothing. So why do we not do as Senator Hill suggests and give recognition and support to the unpaid work done by mothers in the home, impute a value to it and recognise that it is productive and valuable by including it in the gross domestic product? We will then be able to justify allocating the resources necessary to those women to give them real choice about whether to work, full or part time, in the paid work force or whether to stay at home. Then and only then will women have real status, real equality and real economic and other viability.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I personally feel grateful to Senator Hill for proposing this notice of motion and then organising to have it brought on as a debate this morning. It gives us the opportunity to speak once again-for the third time in just a week, which is quite extraordinary-about the status of women in Australia. It occurs to me that, particularly on this side of the House, we do not do very much talking about our achievements in relation to the status of women. We are actually too busy undertaking and carefully implementing the measures that have been carefully thought through during the course of many years and during this decade.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a chance, of course, to remind the Senate and the people of Australia of the status of women and the ways in which the Hawke Government has taken up the challenge to raise that status. Many of the issues covered in the notice of motion have already been debated very effectively this morning by the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women (Senator Reynolds). Senator Haines has also contributed a very fine analysis, particularly of the way in which the status of women has changed over the years.

I would like to take up the points that Senator Hill made about applauding the efforts of far-sighted and courageous women and recognising the achievements of the women's movement. I have no intention of taking any partisan approach to this. I will concentrate mostly on women who have been particularly prominent in the Australian feminist movement, going back to the turn of the century. I suppose Vida Goldstein was one of the women who were most prominent then. She stood for the Senate very early in the century. She was not successful but she led very many important debates in Australia and travelled overseas as well. She obtained a place for Australian women via the League of Women Voters at the International Alliance of Suffragists. There were Australian women working in the suffrage movement in England earlier this century. One of them, of course, was Dora Meeson, who painted our wonderful banner-the `Trust the Women, Mother' banner-that came home to Australia during the bicentennial year. Another Australian woman who was in London was a Western Australian, Muriel Miller, who floated over Westminster in a hot air balloon crying out through a megaphone, `Votes for women'. She was imprisoned for that little piece of activism. But she came back to Western Australia, worked in a country school and taught, amongst her little pupils, Irene Adelaide Driver, who became Irene Greenwood, a remarkable woman who has worked all of her long life for feminism and peace. Her great talents and wisdom were recognised by her appointment to the International Women's Year Committee in 1974 during the time of the Whitlam Government. She has also been honoured by an honorary doctorate, by an Order of Australia, by having a State ship named after her and by being awarded a United Nations medal for peace.

Marion Phillips is another woman who went from Australia to London. An economist, she became very influential in the British Labour Party and organised women as part of that mass party. She became one of the first women members of the British House of Commons in 1929. Unfortunately she died only three years later. Her obituary bemoaned the fact that she had concentrated her not inconsiderable talents simply on issues of concern to women. Muriel Heagney, of Victoria, was at the first International Labour Organisation meetings in Geneva in 1919. One of the very few women who were prominent at the Australian Council of Trade Union (ACTU) level, she did a great deal there to sensitise the otherwise male hegemony to women's issues. In the 1930s she wrote a book entitled Are Women Taking Men's Jobs? Her work was commemorated by the fact that the first ACTU child-care centre which was opened in 1982 at Moorabbin was named in her honour.

Jessie Street is a name that is well known to Australian women these days, particularly as the celebrations of the centenary of her birth are gaining momentum. In 1948 Jessie Street was at the United Nations-once again, one of the very few women there. As a result of her efforts, and others-but she was one of the leading lights among the women's contingent-the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights includes sex as one of the elements in ensuring the rights of individuals.

Among other women who where very influential early in the century were writers and artists of various kinds. In a new book called Courage a Grace, a biography of Mary Gilmour by W. H. Wilde, there is an account of how Mary went daily to the Worker office in the city.
