During 1912 she brought out a series on the lot of women and I read from a catalogue of the issues which she covered: the prostitutes who were rigorously treated by the law while the male customers went free and blameless; the married women whose lives were an endless round of child bearing; the right of women to retain their maiden names in marriage if they so chose, and not to have to promise to obey in the marriage service; the need to reform the divorce laws to make them more equitable for women; the difficult life of women on the land; equality of opportunity and equality of wages for women in employment; the need for financial assistance for unemployed women; and her main crusade which was for the maternity grant-the baby bonus that was introduced by the Labor Government of Andrew Fisher in 1912.

I recommend strongly that Senator Hill and others add to their obligatory reading a book called 200 Australian Women edited by Heather Radi. They will not find reference to Irene Greenwood because she is still alive, but it is an extremely valuable and very easily accessible book put together as a bicentennial project by women historians from all around Australia. I was delighted to hear Senator Hill quote from Joyce Stevens's excellent account of International Women's Day, which we are celebrating today.

I think that we should put on record the excellent contributions that have been made by the women who have been involved in one way or another with the structures that have been developed by both coalition and Labor governments in Australia over the last 20 years and whose names, I believe, should be honoured, particularly on this day. We go back to the days of the Whitlam Government and the appointment of Elizabeth Reid-the first time ever that a female adviser had been appointed in an Australian government. I pay great tribute to her pioneering work in that extremely difficult and demanding job. Elizabeth was followed by Sara Dowse in a role that had changed somewhat by then, and then by Kath Tapperell. When the Australian Labor Party returned to government in 1983, we restored the Office of the Status of Women to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, led successively by Anne Summers, Sue Brooks and Helen L'Orange. On the non-government side, a fine advisory committee was appointed for International Women's Year in the mid-1970s under the chairwomanship of Elizabeth Reid, comprising such luminaries as Irene Greenwood, Margaret Whitlam and Susan Ryan.

The advisory committee set up during the time of the Fraser Government, under Beryl Beaurepaire, as has been mentioned this morning, was extremely valuable. I think that Beryl Beaurepaire's place as the convener of that committee should be recognised as a very fine contribution to the status of women in Australia. Beryl Beaurepaire was succeeded by Quentin Bryce, another extremely prominent woman in non-governmental politics. When the National Women's Consultative Council was set up by the Hawke Government as a means of representing, for the first time, non-governmental organisations at the national level so they could give their advice to the Government, Edith Hall chaired that for the first two terms of its existence and was succeeded by Anne Byrne.

Because there has been a litany of Liberal-National Party women, I would also like to pay tribute to Edith Cowan, the first woman ever elected to an Australian parliament, in 1921, and to draw the Senate's attention to the fact that in 1923 Edith Cowan introduced into the Western Australian Parliament a sex discrimination Bill which became an Act and is still on the books. The effect of that Bill was to make it possible for women to enter into the professions. The first, palpable practical effect was to allow women to become barristers. I also pay tribute to Dorothy Tangney who entered the Federal Parliament from Western Australia in 1943 as the first woman senator. She was in that position for 25 years. During those years she was one of the very few women in the Federal Parliament. She did not have the great advantage that we women parliamentarians have these days of the support, company and encouragement of our fellow female parliamentarians.

I realise that this debate, despite its importance, is seen to be taking up the time of the Senate which many people would prefer to see spent on legislation, but I wish to pick up a couple of points made by Senator Hill when he gave us an account of the achievements of coalition governments in relation to the status of women. The Child Care Bill was introduced by Mr Peacock, I believe, in 1972 in the dying days of the McMahon Government. I remember listening to the debate on the radio. If I recall rightly, the effect of that legislation was to provide subsidies, chiefly to industry to set up its own child-care centres. I do not deny that that was a progressive move at that time. Unfortunately, the credit which the then Government might have received from that move was totally nullified by the fact that, at the same time, the McMahon Government opposed the equal pay case before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. When the Whitlam Government was elected at the end of 1972, one of its first actions was to call for the reopening of the equal pay case, which was supported by the Whit- lam Government.

I am sure that the Opposition did a number of important things in 1976. Unfortunately, what it did to the Office of the Status of Women was reduce its status. The Minister who had responsibility for the status of women was not the Prime Minister, as was the case at the time of the Whitlam Government and as has been the case again since the Hawke Government: it was reduced to the portfolio of one of the most junior Ministers whose other responsibilities were museums and shipwrecks. That did not go down particularly well with Australian women.

A point I wish to make quite strongly is that structures that have been developed, principally by the Labor Party, are very highly regarded internationally. We would be very grateful to have some sort of indication from the coalition of its attitude to those structures-for example, the ways in which we have made it imperative for secretaries of government departments to consult at regular intervals with the Office of the Status of Women. Each year we require a report from each department to be incorporated in our women's budget. This is an official Government document. We have a method, through our National Women's Consultative Council, of consulting with the non-government organisations, which have such an enormous amount to contribute from their collective wisdom, experience and talent. We do not `do' things to women; we work with women, through the Government and through our consultative mechanisms, to discover what they believe we should be doing to enhance their status.

As I said when I started my speech, we have a program which does not start just with a headline-and that is it. We have programs that started years ago, that are continuing and that will continue into the future. The implications of many of those programs are very difficult to quantify, but I have no doubt that the fact, for example, that we have been able to persuade young women to stay at school and complete their secondary education and thus prepare them- selves much better for the rest of their lives is one of our most important achievements. The effects of that will go on, possibly for ever. We can look to a future where our children and our grandchildren have a vastly improved range of genuine options open to them. No matter how conservative or radical any woman is, she cannot deny that her children, her grandchildren and her nieces will have a greater range of opportunities in their lives, opportunities that will open up the chances they will have to support themselves, to achieve independence and to ensure that their own children have a better range of opportunities. This process is never-ending and it gives us all a great deal of satisfaction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —On this International Women's Day I am pleased to be able to support Senator Hill's motion, the first part of which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate . . .
applauds the efforts of farsighted and courageous women who have worked to improve the status of other women;

I do not want to debate the need for further affirmative action, as claimed by Susan Ryan in today's newspapers, which eventually seeks to push women into 50 per cent of jobs. I believe that many women have been able to achieve on their own merits. It is demeaning to push women into jobs regardless of whether they are the best persons for the job or not. I certainly agree with what Senator Haines said, that there should be equal pay for equal work. That is very important.

International Women's Day is an excellent opportunity to recognise not only the women who have risen to prominence in this country but also those quiet achievers, the many women across this nation who maintain the homes and keep the families together. It is their achievements, so often forgotten in all the statistics and studies into society, that we should remember. Too often, we take too few opportunities for reflection and self-analysis. It seems to me that we can use this occasion of International Women's Day well if we allow time for some thought to be given to the direction and part we want women to play in improving the lives of all Australians.

I would like to take this opportunity to reflect on the achievements in the lives of some of the women who have been central to the growth of society as we know it today, and not necessarily politicians. One woman I would like to pay a tribute to is Sister Kenny, who led the fight to give substantial help to victims of polio. Her treatment was revolutionary in her day but it was successful. I can speak in a personal way of this because my husband had polio at the age of eight. In those days that illness could have proved fatal but because of Sister Kenny's treatment he was left with only a small limp.

I also wish to refer to other women. Nurse Edith Cavill was killed for her part in helping troops to escape in World War I. I want to pay a tribute to all the nurses and servicemen who have played a part in helping to keep Australia free over the years and those members of the forces who will continue to do so. Recently we witnessed the achievement of our around the world solo sailor, Kay Cottee, who took on in her boat Blackmore's First Lady not only the physical hardship of the task she set but nature itself, the elements, loneliness, hunger and boredom. She proved that she could achieve in her own right. Now she is busy raising money for life education centres in their fight against drugs. This is another real achievement by a woman who is playing a very vital and important role in Australia.

I could talk, too, about Lady Cilento, known to so many people as `medical mother'. She believed in vitamins when not all doctors agreed with her. I do not know whether Senator Peter Baume would agree with all her ideas about vitamins but her patients swore by her and her methods.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been roughly treated by her one or two times over the years.
—I am sorry to hear that. Lady Cilento's column, `Medical Mother', was every housewife's medical bible. She recognised the importance of natural health long before it became fashionable.

SPEECH.PARA: Many women have forged a path in political and public life. As a Queenslander, I would like to pay a tribute to Dame Annabelle Rankin, a senator from my own State of Queensland, who eventually became the first woman party Whip in the Federal Parliament. She was a well-loved politician right throughout our State. But perhaps the most outstanding woman in this field was Dame Enid Lyons, from Tasmania. Senator Hill referred to her earlier, so I will limit what I have to say about her. Not only was she the wife of a Prime Minister but also she raised a family of 11 children. She was the first woman elected to the House of Representatives and the first woman appointed to Cabinet, as Vice-President of the Executive Council. She saw an opportunity to be of service to the nation in another capacity and by doing so she took a big step forward for the women of Australia.

All these women have been to the forefront; they have been in the public eye. But there are others we should recognise on a day like today, others who perhaps have made a far greater and as yet unrecognised contribution to the Australia of today. They are the quiet achievers in the home, in the suburbs, in the country towns and on out- lying properties who work tirelessly to maintain the family unit. The family has been the basic unit of Australian society, despite the great changes that have taken place in recent decades, and all the evidence indicates that the family will continue to be so. It is true that behind every great and humble man there is a mother upholding the values of the family.

The development of the pastoral lands and the opening up of the outback have depended very largely on the robustness and stability of family life and the often unacknowledged courage of the wives of station owners and workers who had to put up as best they could with the isolation and loneliness, the lack of amenities, remoteness from medical care and social and cultural deprivation.

Most Australian families are urban dwellers-that is obvious from the statistics-and are unfamiliar with the hardships and problems that are still the lot of country folk, despite the vast improvement in their living conditions. I guess I am lucky that although I live in the country I am only a five-minute drive from our town of Kingaroy. But not everybody is so fortunate. Urban life increases the vulnerability of family life to social problems that undermine the family-problems such as peer pressures, competitiveness, the quest for status, the acquisition of goods, domestic and street violence and drugs.

In earlier days the family was closely knit and its extended members remained in close touch with each other. Increasing mobility in society regretfully breaks up these close networks, as people move from one part of the continent to another and even overseas. There has been greater exposure to hostile social forces which are increasing rather than diminishing. I speak here of the loss of work opportunity, increasing poverty, a widening gap between the affluent and the needy, violence in society as well as in the family, the threat of war and a prevalent sense of apprehension, acquisitiveness and the search for immediate gratification. Yet throughout all this the family with its pivotal head, the mother, persists. The truth is that the family, large or small, as I said before, is the basic unit of society, and the health of society depends ultimately on the stability, well-being and harmonious functioning of that unit.

Then there are the migrant women: those who came in the 1940s and 1950s who were largely of European extraction; and those who came later in the 1960s and 1970s, who were, in the majority, from Asian backgrounds. They are the quiet women working behind the scenes in most migrant families, where they ensure the continuation of the importance of cultural and family values. They have helped to maintain the integrity of the family. It was once said that civilisation can be lost in a single generation if the value systems are not preserved and passed on through the family.

While speaking on this International Women's Day, I want to recognise the importance of rural women in the outback: the women who spend many hours of loneliness doing back-breaking work; the women who have stood side by side with their husbands clearing the land, tending the animals, fighting the elements and then turning to their homes to make them nurturing hearths for their families. These families are being penalised today. They are suffering at the hands of people who fail to recognise the contribution given to society by those in the outback. They should not be penalised by what is sometimes called the tyranny of distance. I say once again that I hope that this Government will reconsider the position of women in those areas. They do not have the opportunity to send their children to conveniently located neighbourhood schools, enjoy good roads or have access to modern conveniences that are not provided to isolated families. I wonder when the Government will recognise that, in farming, by its very nature, liquidity is a major problem and that many farmers do not have the means to afford the cost of schooling. By the discriminatory nature of the assets test on the isolated children's assistance scheme, rural children have been forgotten. They have been given no help and no hope.

TALK.START.PARA: —The figure is $600,000. This is a bit rich.

—The Government has failed to recognise when it asset tests the family farm that capital invested in farming earns a very low return. I believe that discrimination now exists for geographically isolated families. We need to ensure that children in the country have the right to education-and not only the boys but also the girls.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I would like to pay tribute to many of my women colleagues in the Parliament, particularly the Senate. They are playing their part as they see it in their own way, though I confess there are times when I do not always see eye to eye with them, in the same way that Senator Crowley just indicated that she did not quite see eye to eye with what I was saying. I remember that when I was first elected to this Parliament many people would say to me, `You must be busy now that you are a working woman'. In my opinion I was a working woman before I came to the Senate. I was proud of my family, of being there for my children, working on the school committees and tuckshops and, of course, looking after the home.

I am interested in the fourth part of Senator Hill's motion, which talks about greater recognition and support for the unpaid work of mothers. It has been assessed that if a woman was paid for all her working hours at home-the washing, ironing, cleaning, cooking and shopping that we were reminded of before, and looking after the family-she would be worth $38,000 a year. I know that because of the part that I have played in the home many of the worries and interests of these women are similar to mine. However, I remind my colleagues that we are here as women senators representing not only women's interests but also those of men, children, families and singles.

Many times government pieces of affirmative action-type policies are claimed to represent the interests of the average woman in Australia. However, the implication of these theories is that women are not already fulfilling their roles as citizens unless they are in the work force-an implication I strongly reject. I accept that many women are out in the work force because of economic necessity and because one income cannot meet rising costs these days due to the policies of this Labor Government. Of course, there are some women in the work force by choice, and I suppose I could say that I am one of those. I want to point out today that women who are at home looking after families are already in the work force doing an excellent job training children. These women are unpaid educators, unpaid psychologists, nurses, doctors, financial planners, administrators, mechanics, teachers, trainers and counsellors in our society. On this International Women's Day I am happy to pay tribute to them all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad that Senator Hill recognises in his motion:

SPEECH.PARA: True equality of opportunity includes freedom of choice of women to support children outside of paid employment.

To my mind the other side of that choice-or the obverse-is the freedom of women to make two other choices: the choice whether or not to have children at all and the choice to work and support or to assist in supporting children or to work simply because they wish to, regardless of economic circumstances. The question of choices of this nature is necessarily linked to the opportunity for women and girls to have a full education, both at school and in later life. That education must include the right to education about fertility and its control in the framework of full health and human relations or personal development education. Otherwise, that other choice-whether to have children at all-may not be available to them.

I would like to focus on Liberal policy in the area of education, such that it is, in contrast with the policies and, more importantly, the record of the Hawke Labor Government in this area. But before I move to education, I want to refer briefly to another, related, point in the Liberal Party document Future Directions which, incidentally, devotes just over one page to its policies for women. This document states that women:
will derive a greater benefit from our policies for more flexible labour market conditions . . .

From what I have learned from the Opposition, both in this place and listening extensively to the radio and colleagues opposite, about the meaning of the greater flexibility in this context, it seems to me to be about breaking down working conditions and working counter to protection and against exploitation. To the extent that this does happen, women will be further disadvantaged because on the whole they have less bargaining power in the workplace. Women, particularly those who are mothers and those who have a broken work force record through looking after children and families, are more likely to be restricted as to where and what hours they work. Therefore, they are more subject to conditions which exist at the moment. If working conditions were to be further broken down under a Liberal government, as to the mobility of women, or their ability to say to the boss, `No, you might want to be flexible but this is going to disadvantage me', they will be worse off.

I would like to pay some attention to this Future Directions document. As I said, it has barely more than a page dealing with equal opportunity for women, and there is very little elsewhere in the document referring specifically to women that I have been able to find. It talks about what the next Liberal and National government will do-and these are, I think, laudable aims. It makes these points:
Expand and make more flexible the higher education system;
But from what I have been reading recently of Liberal policies, making the higher education system more flexible will not advantage women or students in general. The document continues:
Promote changes in community attitudes towards acceptance of the greatest possible range of choice for female students.
Again, I do not remember any previous Liberal government doing very much about that at either State or Federal level. To continue:
Promote the acceptance of women into all kinds of apprenticeship and on-the-job training schemes.
Again, there will have to be a radical change in attitudes compared with what the Liberals have done previously. I shall come in a moment to what Labor has done in that area. The next point is:
Encourage the development of re-training schemes, both private and government, for women whose work patterns have been broken.
Again, we have seen nothing under previous Liberal governments to give any support to the belief that such a thing would happen.

I leave that very sketchy document in order to refer to what the present Government is doing and has done in this area. The Liberal document refers also to participation in the work force. Again, the past Liberal record has not helped in that regard. On the other hand, in 1987, in terms of participation in education, 57 per cent of girls stayed on to the end of secondary school compared with only 44 per cent in 1983-at the end of the period in office of the Fraser Government. That was a significant rise. The Government has announced a target of 65 per cent retention by 1992, and some States under Labor governments are already approaching that. In 1988 women enrolled in universities and in colleges of advanced education comprised over 51 per cent of all enrolled students compared to 46 per cent when we came to power-again a significant rise.

There has also been expansion of women's participation in technical and further education courses. The Government is undertaking a major expansion of the higher education system from this year, and, over the triennium to 1991, 40,000 additional student places will be created. An additional 110,000 places have been created since 1983. Women have benefited and clearly will continue to benefit from greater access to the system that higher education expansion will achieve. That is one of the aims of creating those extra places. Appropriate income support is also necessary if women are to participate in higher education. The Labor Government has recognised this, and since 1983 has implemented major reforms to student assistance that have increased access to education among low income families, significantly enhanced levels of payments, and targeted extra assistance to particularly disadvantaged groups such as sole parents, who of course are mainly women, and Aboriginal women.

The National Policy for the Education of Girls in Australian Schools, which was launched in September 1987, is promoting increased access and educational choice for girls. This needs to be done if we are to increase, for example, the range of apprenticeships which girls enter. This national policy will also promote coordination between Commonwealth and State governments on the progress of girls in education. This is already happening. To enable women to benefit from increased participation in higher education, the Commonwealth is developing a statement of national equity goals, using the national plan of action for women in tertiary education as a base, which will identify gaps in current provisions and develop guidelines for education institutions to take up in their planning. There are also specific programs and developments which will contribute to this process. These include the allocation of $1m in the current financial year for a project designed specifically to increase the number of girls taking maths and science subjects at the secondary school level, which in the past has been a factor preventing girls from entering many of the traditionally male professions. Initiatives are also being taken in tertiary institutions to address issues such as low participation rates of girls in science, mathematics and engineering courses.

The Liberal document referred to women returning to the work force after a period outside it. Our Government has recognised that and has introduced a program called JET, which stands for jobs, education and training, a package designed specifically for sole parents who wish to return to the work force. It is an integrated and voluntary program. In other words, we are not saying to women, as has been implied by some speakers opposite, that they have to be in the paid work force. This will provide sole parents with counselling, access to education, training and employment opportunities and assistance with child-care provision. This is now getting under way, and I think will prove to be of great benefit to that group of women.

A major step we have taken in the advancement of women and the rights of women in the time Labor has been in government is the child support scheme. I know that there are some Opposition members who also have supported that scheme, but it did not happen until the advent of a Labor government-until somebody was prepared to grasp the nettle and explode the myths in that area, making sure that the people who create children are also responsible for their upkeep.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This motion moved by the Opposition, through Senator Robert Hill, being discussed today, 8 March, International Women's Day, will, we hope, enjoy unanimous support. It is a proper declaration for the Senate to be making on this day. In its various clauses it sets on record matters of history, a recognition of the contribution of many women, and an acknowledgment of the variety of contributions, whether paid employment or home making or family care, or combinations of all these.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate cannot undertake this task too often. For generations, until recently, women were not given a fair go. To use the language of some economic rationalists, they were asked to compete on a playing field which was not level. They were constrained by history, by law, by force and by their biological role. They had to fight for every small token of equality. Women had to fight for equal common law rights, for the right to own property, for the right to serve on juries. They had to fight for the vote, for the right to education, for employment, for employment security, for equal pay, for access to superannuation, for promotion, for recognition, and for power. It is amazing that so many apparently otherwise liberal people could enforce-could tolerate-a situation for so long where the talents and energies and contributions of half the population were so denied, so restricted in scope, so little recognised and so little encouraged. It is a matter of pride that so many philosophical liberals were prominent in moves-eventual moves-to correct these structural inequalities.

We have come a long way in just a few years. Let us think about what has happened in this Senate in the last four or five years. The debate on the Sex Discrimination Bill here in 1984 was a disgrace. The dire predictions raised in that debate in some quarters have not come to pass, of course. The debate two years later on the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Bill went a long way to redeeming that situation, and that Bill enjoyed support from all sides of this chamber. But the debate a year later on the provision of equivalent equal employment provisions for women working in Commonwealth statutory authorities was again something to be forgotten. Actually, I find it hard to forget, as it was that Bill and my determination to support it, together with a quarter of the Liberal senators here, including my colleague, Senator Hill, that led to my resignation from the shadow Cabinet and from the front bench. But that is a matter of history and not what we are looking at today.

We have come a long way in two years. We have in place Commonwealth equal employment opportunity legislation, where none existed before. It now covers women in the Commonwealth Public Service and in Commonwealth statutory authorities, where they were not covered before. The Liberal Party was part of the process by which equal employment opportunity legislation was developed and it assisted its passage through the Parliament. I remember that Mr Howard led for our party in the other place. Even in that debate some speeches by some parliamentarians were less than edifying, but in the light of two years experience with the working of the Equal Employment Opportunity Act, we can say that the dire predictions of some have proved to be groundless, as they knew they would, and that the Act is working. It is accepted generally and it has not led to quotas in employment. It has not required the employment of unsuitable persons and it has codified rights that all people should enjoy simply by virtue of their humanity, but rights which until the passage of the Act were not available to women as a right.

With the motion moved today in the Senate, we are making an affirmation of our belief in the right of all people to choose how they will develop and use their talents and to do so in a society which recognises their right to choose their role and be supported in that choice. This motion places the Senate where it should be: unanimously in support of the positions sought by women through the bitter struggles of a century and more. As the motion asserts, there is much more to do. Equally the opportunity remains the goal, not yet the reality. It is something yet to be achieved; in spite of all the progress and all the achievement, we have not yet reached that goal, but we are closer today than ever before. This motion, with its declaration of belief and purpose by the Senate today, indicates with clarity where we see the future to be. I support the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As have other speakers, I also welcome the opportunity to debate on International Women's Day this motion. I just note in passing, for the benefit of those listening to a broadcast of proceedings, that many women members today looked carefully in their wardrobes so that they could come out with some apparel which reflects the feminist colours which were first used in 1908. For the record, those colours are purple, white and green. The purple symbolised dignity and, to quote from the women of that time, `that self-reverence and self-respect which renders acquiescence to political subjugation impossible'. The other colour is white, `for purity in public as well as in private life'. The other colour is green, `for hope and for the green fire of a new springtide in women's history'. Those are comments from 1908. I had a little trouble with my wardrobe so I had to resort to ribbons. Nevertheless, those are goals and aspirations of women which are reflected in International Women's Day.

SPEECH.PARA: First, I endorse the statements that have been made about women who have gone before us and who have made contributions to politics and the wider community and Senator Bjelke-Petersen's `quiet achievers', my own mother included. I go from there to a point focused on in paragraph (c) of Senator Hill's motion, which reads:
. . . the recognition that true equality between the sexes has yet to be achieved.
I note the comment of a former senator, Susan Ryan, in this morning's edition of the Australian, in which she is reported as saying:
It's inevitable that men will feel threatened by women's progress.

I want to address that issue very briefly, as our time is limited. It is a key thought for us on International Women's Day. If we want to achieve that true equality, as the motion exhorts us and as we all want, we have to address the question of how men feel about the progress of women. Some statements have already been made about earlier responses to affirmative action proposals, about whether affirmative action is working. I just draw attention to the fact that while we now have legislative affirmative action proposals and programs, an awful lot of negative action still takes place out there. For instance, last December I was appalled to pick up my copy of the Bulletin and see the cover page headline `Women take over the law'. Thinking that was wonderful, I read the article. I invite honourable senators to guess what I discovered. In that year, 1988, almost 60 per cent of law graduates at the University of Western Australia were women. Many of those graduates will practise as solicitors. The article pointed out that fewer women will become barristers. It states:

Women are beginning to dominate the law, if not yet in status then certainly in numbers: they already monopolise the jury system-probably because they are more available-and most state police forces aim at a target of between 25 and 30% females in any intake.

The article pointed out that although women had long been in the legal profession, their record numbers were not reflected at the most senior levels. When I read that in Lyndall Crisp's article, I began to be sceptical about the earlier claim that women were taking over the law, and I was still on the first page of the article. I was busy at the time, so I skipped a few pages to a chart showing the numbers and positions of women in the judiciary. At the top of the same page, the article pointed out that Australia has only four female silks, or QCs. The chart showed that, of 338 QCs in Australia, only four were women. Of the 92 QCs in Victoria, there were no women and only two of the 158 QCs in New South Wales were women. Those figures are indicative of the other figures across the chart. I did not feel very much as though the big headline emblazoned across the front of the Bulletin really reflected the facts. It more particularly reflected the comment that Senator Susan Ryan was reported as making in this morning's paper:
It's inevitable that men will feel threatened by women's progress.

I regret the fact that the Bulletin article was written by a woman. I could quote many of the comments in the article by women who have achieved senior positions in the legal profession. They point out the same things that we have heard from those in other professions and which we will continue to hear. I refer to problems of attitude, for example. Justice Mathews of the New South Wales Supreme Court pointed out that a lot of incompetent men were at the Bar, fewer women, but that, when women did not achieve the utmost in competence, they were blamed in a way that their male colleagues were not. It is the same sort of line that we have heard across a number of other professions and a number of other areas. I refer also to the practical problems of women performing their caring and nurturing roles as well as being professional women.

The point I most want to make about the article is the fact that the newsstands of Australia sold a major magazine, one to which many people in this community turn for informed opinion, which carried a front page story saying that women were taking over the law, simply because the numbers at the lower levels were getting close to those of men and were even greater than the numbers of men at the undergraduate stage. As people concerned with issues of equity who believe that we should achieve full equality, we must be concerned not about affirmative action, but about the negative action that this sort of thing reflects. I have not read the latest issue of the Bulletin, but there is something about `Working girls and Success Bitches' on the cover. It is about a new spate of movies which are coming on. The article by another two women journalists, Lenore Nicklin and Jan McGuinness, is about women in the corporate area. It is the same story and outlines the same problems.

Senator Haines quoted from the story when she pointed out that the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd is aghast that there might actually be women on its board. Again, we have to be very conscious of the fact that while there has been progress there are still many hurdles to be leapt over. I do not believe we will get over those hurdles unless we address the question of how men feel about what is happening. I do not think we can afford to leave men out of the debate. We must listen to men, talk to them and include them in discussions about this issue.

At the end of last year the Age magazine, Good Weekend, ran a story, written by Alan Ramsey, on women politicians. Alan Ramsey commented-and this was highlighted in a box-that he could think of only three or four women who were in the Federal Parliament for anything more than cosmetic purposes. Mind you, only one in 10 parliamentarians are women. I felt personally insulted by that comment, as should every other woman who is currently sitting in this chamber. He could not even name the four women-he could only name our colleagues Ros Kelly and Kathy Sullivan, in the other place, and Senator Haines. What does he know? He has never spoken to me. I doubt whether he even knows what I look like. I certainly do not believe I am here for cosmetic purposes. I would say that perhaps a number of male members of parliament, past and present, might only be here for cosmetic purposes. That kind of response to the struggles of women must be addressed and discussed.

In March 1988 Eva Cox suggested in the Age that if we really wanted to look in an economic sense at women's contribution versus men's contribution we would realise that men actually are a great cost on the community. They are involved in mass killings; they make up 90 per cent of the prison population; and they constitute 70 per cent of our alcoholics. She listed all of those facts and suggested that if we tackled the problem of the high cost of excessive masculine behaviour with a program of equitably calculated knackering, we might actually make an economic contribution to this nation. I would not want that to be the response in this debate to the attitudes of men and women. Nevertheless, the economic vision which Eva Cox has, and the economic vision which the Australian Democrats represent, must be looked at or some of the horrific attitudes to affirmative action, which apparently surfaced in debate before I came to this place, might actually win the day.

I would also like to make the point that there is evidence that women have distinct advantages over men. Recent figures from the Small Business Development Corporation in Victoria show that women are beginning new businesses at three times the rate of men and that they are achieving twice the success rate. This was attributed, in large part, to the fact that many women were beginning their businesses with the opportunity of having first looked at themselves, some of their life experiences, and then getting into something which was more appropriate. My feeling is that many men have expectations placed upon them at a very early stage of their lives. They have a one-track path down which to go in much the same way as women in the past have had expectations heaped on their shoulders and have been denied other aspects of community life.

I am sorry that our debating time is limited. The theme of this debate needs to be developed. I would certainly endorse Senator Hill's motion. However, bearing in mind what I have said, I think the final part of the motion, which calls for freedom of choice, must recognise that that freedom should also be available to men. The call for recognition of support for the unpaid work of mothers should also include the unpaid work of anybody who is caring and nurturing the young in our community. By recognising the unpaid work of mothers and women, and thereby making those roles more socially acceptable, we will encourage and assist men to undertake such roles. I think this is one of the impediments we face.

I was told a story last weekend by an equal opportunity officer, who now works as a very high-level executive in an oil company. She went into the office of one of her male colleagues who had a couple of small children sitting in the corner and a bag of shopping. She did not think it was much to comment on and she went on with her business. Soon afterwards, during the lunch break, she overheard a group of other colleagues say what disgraceful behaviour it was for their male colleague to be bringing children and shopping into the office, that it was not the done thing and that there must be something wrong with him. That happened in a major corporation in this country only a few weeks ago.
In supporting this motion, I want to make it clear that I think our major goal has to be true equality among the sexes, because that will be to the benefit of men, women and their children.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.
