SPEECH.PARA: We have acknowledged all sorts of good true women from times past. One woman whose name was mentioned by Senator Powell, and whose name I would certainly want to put on the record again, is former Senator Susan Ryan who, in large part, steered through achievements for women in the last six years of the Labor Government. Anyone who was around this place at that time would know of the success, and the great battle involved, that was largely achieved by the then Senator Susan Ryan. Senator Peter Baume alluded to some of the achievements of this Government which enjoyed some bipartisan support. Certainly, the sex discrimination legislation, and later the affirmative action legislation, were based on a considerable amount of consultation by Susan Ryan to ensure that, as much as possible, all views were taken into account and that the objections that might have been raised in the debate were anticipated and dealt with.

The affirmative action legislation was so successful precisely because of the considerable work done by the pilot committee in the years leading up to the introduction of that legislation. I believe that Senator Peter Baume was a member of that committee. I am very pleased to take the opportunity to put former Senator Susan Ryan's name on the record today as one of the great achievers for women in this country. She is part of an ongoing history of achievement for women.

I would like to take up one small point. Senator Bjelke-Petersen talked about women as quiet achievers. I would like to put on record my endorsement for the noisy ones. Women are very often encouraged to be docile, quiet, submissive and peaceful and are even celebrated as quiet achievers. I am not suggesting that we all rush around breaking chairs or shouting, but women are not just quiet, docile, passive, submissive creatures.

One small example is the number of gold medals won by individual Australian athletes. The last time I looked, I found that women outnumbered men-10 out of 13 medals had gone to women. So, they certainly can run, although it could be said that they were not talking while they were doing so. But women are strong, capable, fit, bold and tough. Some of those points are perhaps alluded to in the first point of this motion, but I need to make it clear that we need to celebrate women in terms of all their activities, representations and capacities. Women did not pioneer Australia by wimping around, taking instructions from people. They did it by having initiative, by having gumption and by having oomph. I certainly want to see those words applied to women.

Women have achieved in sport, inventions, building, architecture, writing and drama. They have achieved in all areas of activity, both in this country and overseas. What they have not had is suitable recognition. They have very often been written out of history. There has been a campaign to denigrate the achievements of women in a constant effort to reduce them to quiet, docile little creatures. I would ask Senator Bjelke-Petersen to check who really did the work in establishing the merino in Australia. Any record would suggest that Mrs Macarthur was at home to do the work while Mr Macarthur was in England. Proper records do acknowledge Elizabeth Macarthur in the history of the establishment of the merino. I will not go through all those achievements because I want to make two other points that are probably more important than running through a litany.

Senator Hill moved this motion, which seems to say what a good thing it is to have women, how proud we are of them and what a lot of important things they have done, and then took the opportunity to bore it up the Government for failing to do all the things that it is supposed to be doing for women. He said that perhaps it had done some but that was not enough or perhaps it had done some and they were contradictory. Senator Hill had better get it straight. He has ducked and twisted in saying what he would do to improve the lot of women, but he seems to want to do nothing more than criticise us for what we have done. He suggests that where we have achieved it is not substantial; where we have not achieved it is not enough.

I would like to point out, by way of evidence, that that is not the view of everybody on the other side. Senator Chaney, speaking in this place on the Appropriation Bills, as recorded on page 2632 of the Senate Weekly Hansard, stated:
With respect to assistance to families, I condemn the Government for the fact that the only families it has been prepared to help have been those on the lowest incomes.

Having condemned us for having our priorities right, he then condemns us for actually assisting families. I can take that condemnation because clearly Senator Chaney was saying-those opposite have also said it in Future Directions-that this Government has tried to protect only families at the bottom end. He then says that we have not done much for families. He said that we have done it, and then he says that we have not done it. I ask him please to make up his mind. Families on the lowest end of the income scale in this country know what benefits they have had under this Labor Government. This Government has made it a priority to ensure the economic advantages and protection of those people. Payments for children have dramatically increased under this Government-not for all children because of a recognition of the economic constraints of the time, but for the children of families at the lowest end of the income scale. As part of our commitment to try to help those children out of poverty the Government quite clearly has made this area the focus of its contributions. Those opposite recognise those contributions and then say that we have not made them. It is a contradiction inherent in this motion and in all that Senator Hill has had to say.

Honourable senators opposite say that we have not done much for the economic advantage of women. What about the increased opportunities for education? What about the retention rate, which has gone from 30 per cent plus to well over 60 per cent in the State of South Australia? What about the fact that more than 50 per cent of students finishing year 12 are girls? What about the fact that more than 50 per cent of people in tertiary colleges are women for the first time ever? I say again, just to see the hackles rise and hear the abuse start, that the achievement of a labour force participation rate for women of more than 50 per cent is a huge success. We need only ask the women who now have job opportunities. They may be there out of economic necessity, but they would much rather have a job than be at home on unemployment benefit or the single parent pension and that kind of restricted income. They are making their choice. They are saying, `We prefer those advantages'. Besides, if I listened to the Opposition, I could presume that all women are in the work force because of economic constriction. That is a very insulting remark to the many women who have chosen to go to work for whatever reason. It is not for me to say that their reasons are right or wrong; it is for them to make that choice. We have provided that opportunity. Of the one and a quarter million jobs provided since 1983, 58 per cent have been taken by women. That is advantaging women economically.

Senator Newman comes into this place and says by way of interjection, `Why aren't you doing more about child-care for the defence forces?', and at the same time endorses a policy that does not want government expenditure. What kind of child-care does she want in the defence forces? I understand that she is advocating government expenditure. Are defence forces walled around in Senator Newman's thinking? She wants child-care for the Defence Force spouses and she does not want women to go to work. Are Defence Force spouses some kind of new category? That is another contradiction in Senator Newman's paper and thinking. If she understood our child-care policy, she would know that since its beginning we have argued for a range of options in the child care area so that women who are principally at home can use the occasional care provisions which give them the opportunity to do many things that women do-we all know them; they have been listed today-without having to go into the full time work force. Other women in full time work or part time work use child-care provisions to ensure that they have comprehensive quality child-care that is accessible and affordable under our child-care program. This enables them to enjoy their work knowing that their children are being adequately cared for. That assists them economically.

I do not understand the Opposition forever telling us that we are not concerned about the economic conditions for women. Yes, we are, and, yes, more remains to be done. There is the challenge, but that is not something that we shrink from; it is something that will be a continuing part of our commitment to women and policies for women and our recognition of the rights and the dignity of women, their strength and their opportunities. These things are all endorsed in some way in Senator Hill's motion. In offering to support the motion, I would have to say that I hope at a later date we have more opportunity to debate what I think are, in effect, inherent contradictions within it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with great pleasure that I support the motion moved by my colleague Senator Hill on this International Women's Day. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate, on International Women's Day-
(a) applauds the efforts of farsighted and cour- ageous women who have worked to improve the status of other women;

(b) pledges to fully recognise the contribution of women in the family and in the community and to continue to work to improve the status of women towards the goal of true economic, educational and social equality;

(c) recognises the achievements of the women's movement and those who have supported improvement in the status of women, but acknowledges that true equality between the sexes has yet to be achieved; and

(d) notes that true equality of opportunity includes the freedom of choice of women to support children outside of paid employment and that such a choice requires greater recognition of and support for the unpaid work of mothers.

Courageous women have always been the backbone of any nation and Australia is certainly no exception. The courage of our women during the days of early settlement points that out. The first settlement at Sydney Cove would never have been expanded into the wonderful country we have today if they had not been so courageous. It is all very well for the men to have set forth to pioneer the outback with a gun in their hand and the promise of great gains, but for women to have followed knowing that their very isolation would render them so vulnerable while they were having their numerous children makes us all pause and wonder at their courage. Theirs was the responsibility for their families-their health, education and moral fibre. How many of us today would care to take on those risks with no doctors in place and no support systems available?

Yet we do have many modern day examples of extreme courage shown by women working to improve the status of other women. One only has to mention Mother Theresa to understand that women today have not lost any of the courage of those earlier women. The women's movement must have rejoiced at the exploits of people such as Kay Cottee, who has just sailed single-handed around the world. We have so many very good examples, both present and past. I would like to touch on them very briefly. Sister Elizabeth Kenny, a bush nurse in Queensland, was the first woman and the first person to come up with some treatment for poliomyelitis. I will read a very short section out of her biography. It states:

A year later she was called to a drover's cottage where she found a little girl lying crippled on a cot. Alarmed, she galloped several miles to the nearest telegraph office where she cabled the child's symptoms to Dr McDonnell, He replied: `Infantile paralysis. No known treatment. Do the best you can.'

Drawing on her experience with her brother and improvising in the best traditions of the Australian bush, she cut strips of blanket, dipped them in hot water, wrung them out and packed them gently about the child's paralysed legs and arms. Soon her whimpering ceased. After a few more applications she went to sleep. Later, when the child was awakened by the pain she said: `I want them rags that wells my legs'.

Sister Kenny resumed the treatment, coupled with vigorous massage, and after several tension-filled days the child recovered. When she told Dr McDonnell what she had done the man was flabbergasted. `But that's completely contrary to every accepted idea of polio treatment', he said.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I inform the Senate that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, left Australia yesterday on official Government business overseas. He will be absent from Question Time today and tomorrow. Senator Evans will, amongst other things, represent the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) at a major international conference in the Hague on the protection of the atmosphere. He will also be meeting a number of ministerial counterparts in the United Kingdom, Europe and the United States of America. Any questions which would normally be directed to Senator Evans in relation to his portfolio or those he represents should be directed to me.

—Would the Minister representing the Attorney-General now tell the Senate, as on Friday he said that he would, when he, the Attorney-General and the Attorney-General's Department became aware of the extraordinary deal under which in late 1987 the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) agreed to drop its well-advanced inquiries into Rothwells merchant bank? I also ask: Did he, the Attorney-General or the Department ever express a view about the wisdom or propriety of such a deal, which effectively put the whole matter under wraps and out of public view for more than a year and, of course, meant that there was no continuing investigation? What was that view or those views? Finally, is he aware of a report in Monday's West Australian newspaper which purports to quote from the confidential NCSC report presented to last week's meeting of State and Federal Attorneys-General? In view of the apparent leaking of sections of this report, will the Minister, as a matter of urgency, contact the Western Australian Attorney-General and seek his agreement to tabling a suitably edited version of the report in this place so that the full facts can be known without having to wait until the resumption of the Western Australian Parliament later this month?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first part of Senator Chaney's question recollects a question asked last week which I think followed a question asked by Senator Durack which purported to call on a question asked earlier in the week by Senator Lewis. The question relates to the knowledge of either me, the Attorney-General or departmental officers of an undertaking apparently given by the NCSC to Rothwells that it would not undertake investigations into matters prior to a certain date if certain undertakings were given. The first time that either the Department or the Attorney-General became aware of those matters was when the litigation was a matter of public knowledge in the media. I think that is an adequate answer to Senator Chaney's question. It is certainly the same case with me.

ANSWER.PARA: At the time there was some confusion in my mind only in so far as Senator Durack's question related to that. Senator Lewis actually asked about the decision not to publicise the inquiries that were being undertaken by the NCSC into Rothwells, and I think there was some confusion in Senator Durack's mind when he asked that question. But I believe that I have answered that question. As I have said, it became known to Ministers and to departmental officers only during the course of litigation.

As to the confidential report that has been leaked, I am not in a position, because I obviously have not seen that report, which is to the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities, to confirm that the alleged extracts printed in the West Australian of Monday, 6 March, are extracts from that report from the National Companies and Securities Commission to the Ministerial Council. I reiterate that it is extremely important in this case as in other instances-for example, the war crimes trials which were mentioned earlier this week-that publicity not prejudice the proper resolution of these matters, should charges eventually be laid and the matters come before the courts. I think it is extremely unfortunate that these purported extracts from a confidential report to a ministerial council should have been published in a way which may lead to such prejudice.

Senator Chaney requested that an edited version of the report be tabled in this place. Of course, the Ministerial Council requested that the report be looked at extremely carefully and edited in a way which, should it be placed before a parliament and thereby attract privilege, would not do harm to persons who might face a court. I will give consideration to Senator Chaney's request. But I believe that the Ministerial Council, which has responsibility for these matters-not the Attorney-General of the Commonwealth-has made a determination that the report be tabled in the Western Australian Parliament. It may be that Senator Chaney's question could be forwarded to the Chairman of the Ministerial Council and perhaps it could consider his request.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister again seems to have answered the question as though it has nothing to do with him. I ask him as the Minister for Justice-and this is the part of the question he did not answer: When he became aware, through the litigation, of the rather extraordinary arrangement made by the NCSC, did he ever express a view about the wisdom or propriety of such an arrangement, given that it effectively put the matter both under wraps and on hold, as far as any investigation was concerned, for more than a year? Did he, as Minister for Justice and as one of the Ministers in this Government responsible for legal matters, have any view and did he express that view? I note the Minister's reply with respect to the publishing of the report. I ask the Minister: Given that it would appear that portions of this report have been leaked to the media, will he give consideration to the potentially greater damage which is done by the selective leaking of the report rather than the tabling of a report which is properly edited simply to protect the question of a fair trial for those who might be charged, rather than something which has clearly been leaked for political purposes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the first matter, I did not express a view on this matter which was the subject of litigation and, I believe, determination, although this does not suit the political attack which Senator Chaney wishes to wage against me on this matter. The Ministerial Council exercises supervision and control over the National Companies and Securities Commission. We have on that Ministerial Council, for example, the Attorney-General of New South Wales, Mr John Dowd, the Attorney-General and Minister for Justice in Queensland, Mr Paul Clauson, and the Attorney-General of Tasmania, Mr John Bennett. Although I am not privy to the deliberations of the Council, I cannot believe that a body of Ministers charged with responsibility for the National Companies and Securities Commission is not properly constituted as the proper body to undertake the supervision of the actions of the National Companies and Securities Commission in regard to Mr Connell. I believe that the responsibility for making statements in relation to that matter that came out in litigation properly lies with the Ministerial Council.

ANSWER.PARA: I agree with Senator Chaney that the leaking of purported extracts from a report can be extremely damaging. But that does not lead me to the conclusion that we should rush into publishing the matter in a parliamentary chamber, where privilege is attracted, until the most careful examination of the documents is undertaken. The Western Australian Opposition asked for the report to be published in a speedy fashion. I do not think that would be a proper discharge of the responsibility of the Ministerial Council to those who may face charges. I believe that this matter should be allowed to be examined in a proper and considered way and not in haste.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance and Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) publication `Government Financial Estimates 1988-89' which was released on 1 March? What information does that publication contain regarding the net financing requirement of the Australian public sector as a whole in 1988-89? Do the figures suggest that the State and local government sectors are bearing an appropriate share of the burden of fiscal restraint?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The short answer to the last part of the question is no, and I will give the details later. I have seen the Australian Bureau of Statistics bulletin. It is worth noting, for those who follow these things, that the ABS has decided to change the terminology. In future it will refer to what used to be known as the net public sector borrowing requirement as the net financing requirement of the public sector. The publication shows that for this financial year the net financing requirement is, in fact, negative for the public sector in Australia as a whole. In other words, there is a small surplus on the government account.

ANSWER.PARA: Between the previous financial year and the present financial year, the Commonwealth sector increased its surplus from some $2.7 billion to $4.1 billion, that is, an increase of slightly more than 50 per cent in the Commonwealth surplus. During the same period the State and local government sector not only failed to reduce its deficit but increased it-I am using rounded figures-from $3.8 billion to just over $3.9 billion; an increase of nearly 4 per cent.

If one looks at the breakdown of the government finance statistics, one finds more evidence of the State and local government sector having not exercised fiscal self-discipline on anything like the scale of the Commonwealth sector. As to the government final consumption expenditure figure, the most important component of which is the wages and salaries paid to public servants in general, but State public servants in particular, the Commonwealth sector's figure is a nominal growth of just over 5 per cent, which is, of course, a real reduction. For the State and local government sector, the figure is a nominal growth of 8 per cent, which represents a real increase.

In addition to that, for those who are interested in this-Senator Stone may have seen it already-Dr Shann published an article in the Business Review Weekly a couple of weeks ago in which he suggested that the States have been substantially escaping from the fiscal discipline that the Commonwealth Government is trying to have applied to the public sector as a whole by selling off assets. He did not quantify that. I understand that it would be extremely difficult to quantify. If Dr Shann is correct-there are certainly some reasons to believe that he is-the States have exercised even less discipline or, to put it the other way, have been more undisciplined than the ABS bulletin suggests.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. In view of the alarming resignation rate of armed forces personnel, will the Minister investigate the possibility of the traditional bounty-that is, an incentive paid to staff to re-enlist at the end of their enrolment-being reinstated? Why was this traditional bounty withdrawn in the first place? Is it also a fact that other incentives for personnel such as tax free commodities and concessions are also under threat?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Referring to the last part of the question, on tax free benefits, first, Senator Sheil probably would be referring to the uniform allowance, which has received some publicity in recent times. It has recently been assessed by the Commissioner of Taxation as being taxable. That reassessment occurred in the context of the general reassessment of what was taxable and what was not over the last few years in the general community. It is not a specific penalty placed upon the defence services. But, to get back to Defence Force manpower, which is at the heart of the question--
—The bounty.

—As I understand it, Senator Sheil asked about the bounty and whether we will restore it. Senator Sheil referred to the Defence Force and suggested that its strength was going down. I forget the exact words that Senator Sheil used, but I think that is the import of his question.
—The alarming resignation rate.

—Let us settle on `the alarming resignation rate'. The paid strength of the Australian Defence Force (ADF) for the first six months of this financial year was 70,203, which is on target to achieve the Budget estimate of 70,279. I might say that the number of women in the permanent ADF has continued to increase, and that is a good sign. The total number of voluntary separations from the trained force or trainee or cadet separations for the first six months is 3,025, which is 8 per cent below the number for last year.

ANSWER.PARA: Preliminary indications are that there will be a higher level of separations in the month of January 1989 due to the introduction of open ended enlistments. That higher level of separations, however, is not expected to continue for the rest of the year. Generally, one can therefore accept that there has been an improvement in the separation results, and for that the Government is grateful.

In terms of what we do about the future, the recruiting effort certainly will be maintained and hopefully improved. We are experiencing some difficulties in attracting experienced recruits in some technical employment categories. Hopefully, we can direct the recruiting effort to remedy that situation. In terms of whether we need to reintroduce the bounty to which Senator Sheil referred, I shall certainly take that up with the Minister. But, in view of the fact that the separation results are improving, I am not certain that that would be necessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a claim by the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association (APEA) in yesterday's Australian that the Government needs to give more encouragement to petroleum explorers? Can the Minister comment on this claim in the light of a number of government initiatives previously acknowledged by the APEA as effective in improving the environment for oil exploration?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can comment on--
—And read about it as well.

—I hope that Senator Chaney does read about it because it is very important to the energy policies of this country. I have seen the articles referred to by Senator Beahan. I must say that at about this time every year there is a rash of articles of this sort. The articles suggest that there is a sudden and heated row between the Government and the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association. That is not true. There has been an ongoing difference of view between the APEA and the Government over excise. It has been going on for some time and it will continue to go on for some time into the future. We will not resile from imposing an export levy on the exportation of hydrocarbons from Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: The reason why it occurs at this time of the year is that the APEA is heading into its annual conference next month and this is a conference teaser. The theme of the conference is `Prospectivity for Australia'. I am happy to give this commercial by saying that the conference will be held next month. Prospectivity will be the theme. I urge all oil explorers to go.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to open it?
—I am attending. I will be giving a speech about this subject. I will give Senator Boswell a copy. I hope that it will be a very successful conference because it is an important subject.
—We do not need another copy, do we?

—I am surprised that Senator Puplick disdains so comically the issue of energy policies for this country. I would have thought that it was central to our basic economic position and our possibilities for economic growth. Let me, however, go on with my answer to Senator Beahan because it is, indeed, his question.

ANSWER.PARA: We have in place in this country a positive regime of oil excise which is cast in a mould similar to those of countries with like prospects to Australia's. Therefore, by comparison, it is not unduly onerous internationally, but it does meet what I think is a fundamental and necessary test; that is, philosophically this Government is dedicated to the proposition that the oil and gas reserves of this country are public property and if private companies wish to exploit those reserves to make a profit they are entitled to pay some economic rent to the Australian community. That economic rent is in the form of the excise we extract for the right to use those resources.

What has been referred to in this debate is that that economic rent somehow is a disincentive for exploration. The truth is that at present oil prices, while firming since the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries managed to organise its affairs in a more orderly way, have been low in recent months. The price of oil on the world market is the key-as the price of gold on the world market is the key-to whether or not companies commit efforts to prospecting in this area. The tax regime is also a component. The tax regime, in the case of oil exploration, is cast in a way so as to provide the Australian community with an economic rent from those private companies which exploit the resources.

The other aspect of this debate, which has surfaced in the last day, concerns some quotations of the Chief Executive of Esso Australia Ltd-the company that exploits the Bass Strait fields-that the Commonwealth Government has been slow in meeting that company's demands for a reduction in excise. I should perhaps take the opportunity of using this answer to make an observation about that remark. Esso and Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, the joint owners of the lease for the operation of Bass Strait, approached the Government late last year, when it looked as though oil prices would crash through the $10 a barrel mark, and sought some specific tax relief.

Consistent with what I have said about the way in which we pitch our policies on excise, we met their demands by proposing a sliding scale which would have reduced excise and, had the price of oil fallen dramatically, would have meant that they would still be able to produce from all of their fields and earn a reasonable margin of profit. It is the companies themselves that rejected that reasonable proposal by the Commonwealth. Because they have rejected it there is no reason for the Commonwealth now to try to alter or renegotiate the sliding scale in any way. It is certainly not my intention to do that. I make the point that here is a clear example of where there was a real need to provide some tax relief, because of the low price of oil, and where the Commonwealth moved to address that directly by proposing a reviewed scale which provided that relief and, in this case, the company knocked it back.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. I refer to the Heard and Macdonald Islands Environmental Protection and Management Ordinance passed in December 1987. The ordinance required the Minister to prepare and table a management plan for these sub-Antarctic islands which are located equidistant between Australia, Africa and Antarctica. Is the Minister aware that the islands are the last intact sub-Antarctic island group without human-introduced plants and animals and that the islands have been recognised by the international scientific community, including the Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research and the International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources, as being of outstanding global significance? Is he also aware of the threat to the islands posed by the visits of tourists and fishing vessels which could introduce rates, which would jeopardise native bird life? Is it also a fact that the management plan has not yet been completed? If so, why has it not been completed, when will it be completed and what steps will be taken to protect the area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the significance of Heard and Macdonald Islands. They are the only sub-Antarctic islands to have no introduced species, so far as I am aware. As I understand it, it is also the location of the only active volcano in Australian territories. Obviously the islands are of some extreme significance environmentally. It should be noted that the management ordinance for Heard and Macdonald Islands was tabled on 17 February last year.
—Don't lose your place.

—I cannot hear the honourable senator's interjection, but I am sure that what she said was not worth listening to anyway. Because of the geographical isolation of the islands concerned, obviously it is not practical to station officers there permanently. I notice that Senator Sanders did not ask for that in his question. We certainly have no plans to do that and I do not think that we would be terribly successful in a recruiting campaign to organise officers to do so.

ANSWER.PARA: The ordinance contains some fairly strict environmental measures, including a requirement for a permit to gain entry to the islands. Hopefully, that will be something of a measure of how many people attempt to visit them in the very near future. The ordinance provides for severe penalties for introducing any organism-not just rats but plants as well. It also requires the preparation of a management plan `as soon as practicable' after the commencement of the ordinance. Work has commenced on the draft management plan. Unfortunately, the officer who began that work, who was from the Antarctic Division, resigned late last year. We have been unable to continue work on that in the last few weeks due to the constraints we have on staff in the Antarctic Division-the difficulties we have in getting a sufficient number of staff to handle the tasks that are given to them. However, even in the absence of a management plan, entry to the territory is controlled by the permits to which I have referred. We shall certainly get to work on the management plan as soon as we can. I shall keep Senator Sanders and the Senate informed on the progress of its development.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Attorney-General to amendments which I moved to the Family Law Amendment Bill, which received quite substantial support here but were defeated five years ago. Those amendments would require a party to a marriage 12 months prior to applying for a dissolution thereof to undergo, together with the other partner, counselling for the purposes of considering the legal, social and financial consequences of the dissolution of the marriage and, in particular, the effect of the dissolution of the marriage on any children of the marriage. The Minister would have observed that the report on homeless youth Our Homeless Children states that a very substantial percentage of homeless youth are from parents whose marriages have broken down. Did the Minister hear the Minister for Social Security in the other place, Mr Brian Howe, state publicly that one of the causes of our homeless youth is the irresponsibility of parents? Would it not be an appropriate time now to reconsider the propositions that I put forward at that time so as to ensure that those who are separating and are considering applying for a dissolution of marriage should have special regard to not only the legal, social and financial consequences of the dissolution of that marriage but also, and in particular, the effects of the dissolution of the marriage on any children of that marriage?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a fact, and a cause for great regret within our community, that many young Australians who find themselves without shelter are in that tragic predicament because the household which ought to offer them warmth, security and care has become intolerable for them, perhaps because of disputes between the parents or other factors. When the parents go further and seek to formalise the breakdown of their marriage by seeking to have a decree of dissolution of the marriage ratified-that is what it amounts to-children can once again be put in jeopardy. For one reason or another it might be impossible to find the normal care and protection that ought to exist within the households of either of the parents who have separated or divorced.

ANSWER.PARA: Therefore, anything that can be done to try to reconcile a couple who are contemplating separation or divorce ought to be undertaken. For that reason, the Government, under the Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, has increased the funding available for marriage counselling and marriage education. We see this as an investment in trying to secure the family unit against disintegration, which can, as I say, lead in some situations to a destabilisation of the normal expectations of young people who may find themselves on the streets and homeless.

There has been a dramatic increase in the financial commitment to marriage counselling under this Government. I think Senator Harradine would acknowledge that this financial year $7m has been allocated to marriage counselling organisations compared with $4.74m only two years ago. In my own State of Tasmania, for example, the contribution to marriage counselling organisations this financial year is $331,000. That contribution is playing a very significant part because it has helped to secure the continuation of the offices on the north west coast, which are an important part of marriage counselling in Tasmania.

As Senator Harradine's question suggests, there is an important role in trying to ensure that such counselling occurs. Whether it ought to be further formalised in the way he suggests as a condition precedent, as I understand it, to seeking a decree for the dissolution of the marriage by requiring counselling which gives particular attention to the possible plight of children of the marriage, perhaps could be considered once again. I believe that it is important to note that over the past five or six years there has been a decline in the number of divorces involving couples with children. I do not say this in any partisan way. Obviously this is the result of various factors, demographic and social. But it may be of interest that in 1982 there were 27,157 divorces involving children in Australia and, since the change of government, there has been a steady decline, dropping to 23,279 in 1987. This important sociological factor is not often adverted to. I believe that marriage guidance, marriage counselling and marriage education are important matters to which this Government has shown its commitment over the last several financial years.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, relates to the Government's decision to remove the pharmaceutical benefits scheme subsidy for a number of brand name drugs from 1 April. Can the Minister indicate what consideration has been given to the consumers of the delisted drugs who not only have the physiological need for which the drug has been prescribed, but also have developed a psychological dependency on the brand name drug? Is the Government prepared to make provision for such people who, notwithstanding that the generic alternatives to withdrawn brands have identical active ingredients, may not respond to the generic alternative? Will these consumers, many of whom are pensioners, simply have to find the money to pay the full price of the brand name drug themselves?

—Last week I answered a similar question that was asked by Senator Janine Haines. The point was made in that answer-and this is intrinsic in Senator Reid's question-that while some drug manufacturers chose, when we moved to generic names, to have their drugs removed from the list, there are identically chemically active drugs to the drugs that have now been removed. So the actual medication for the treatment is available on the list, as I understand it.
—That is not the point of my question.

—I know that is not the point of the honourable senator's question, but it is a very important point in the consideration of the issue because drugs, presumably, are prescribed to treat particular problems. The drugs are available, but not under the brand name. They are available under a generic name. Senator Reid has asked whether this creates a mental trauma in some patients who have developed an affinity to the brand name product. I do not believe that it is a major problem, but as Senator Reid has raised the question I will take it up with Dr Blewett, the Minister whom I represent in this place, to see whether further elaboration can be given to my answer. But I repeat that I do not believe that it is a major issue.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources. Has the wholly Japanese owned company Harris-Daishowa applied to the Department of Primary Industries and Energy for a permit to export an additional 150,000 tonnes of hardwood woodchips during 1989 over and above its export licence for 850,000 tonnes? If so, are these woodchips to be derived from Victorian sawmills, partly from the chippings of thinnings from thinnings trials in public native forest and mostly from the sawmill residues from D-grade sawlogs which are fed directly to a chipper? If Harris-Daishowa has been given permission to export an additional 150,000 tonnes of hardwood woodchips, could this resource be used to remove the urgency to log Tantawangalo and Coolangubra and the Egan Peaks region nominated for National Estate listing? Has Senator Richardson been informed of Harris-Daishowa's most recent export licence application? Has there been any environmental impact statement on this proposal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can confirm that Harris-Daishowa has applied for an additional export licence for woodchips of 150,000 tonnes to export during the calendar year 1989. The additional chips will be derived from residues from Victorian sawmills. Most of these residues will be produced from the milling, as the honourable senator has said, of D-grade sawlogs but some will also be produced as a result of thinnings trials in crown native forests. The forest operations proposed by the New South Wales Forestry Commission in the Coolangubra and Egan Peaks forests are primarily for the production of sawlogs to supply the local sawmills in that area. Woodchips will be produced only from timber which is unsuitable for sawmilling or which is left over after sawmilling. It is likely that the operations will proceed regardless of whether approval is given to export the waste material as woodchips or not.

ANSWER.PARA: The proposed forest operations in the Tantawangalo forest involve the logging of 81 hectares and are part of a research project being conducted to determine the effects of logging on water quality and quantity. As the Victorian residues are not associated with sawlogs going to New South Wales mills, there is no impact on proposed New South Wales operations in areas on and nominated for the register of the National Estate. The possibility of changes to the logging plans for those areas will be the subject of discussions in the near future between me and the New South Wales Minister for Natural Resources, Mr Causley, and arise from advice to me by my colleague Senator Richardson, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. I had hoped that the discussions between me and Minister Causley would have been completed by this date, but that has not been possible. I hope to have those discussions completed and the issue finalised in the near future.

In the meantime, however, the Commonwealth has not approved the export of any pulpwood material from the areas to which I have referred. The Department of Primary Industries and Energy has referred the application that Senator Dunn has spoken of to Senator Richardson's Department for comment. No environmental impact statement has been prepared on the additional 150,000 tonnes as yet. The proposal is being considered by the relevant Commonwealth departments-that is, the Department of Primary Industries and Energy and Senator Richardson's Department-and the Victorian Department of Conservation, Forests and Lands and Department of Planning and Environment to determine whether further detailed environmental impact assessments are necessary.

I am advised that most D-grade sawlogs are, in fact, sawn by millers to extract the available millable material after appraisal at the mill. Then they are chipped. But the economics of the operation are such that the sawmillers must maximise the sawn material as well as sell the residue as chips. I also point out that D-grade logs have, by definition, a low proportion of millable material. They are graded by the Victorian Department of Conservation and Lands and are regarded as essentially rubbish from which it might be possible to extract some sawn timber. But in the main they are regarded as material which would probably be chipped in any case.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Resources prepared to consult with the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association and to review the impact of current taxation in the light of concern expressed by the Executive Director of the APEA, Mr Orchison, that tax treatment of offshore platform removals and cash bonus bidding for oil search permits were having a detrimental effect on the industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite frankly, I find this a somewhat extraordinary question. The honourable senator asks whether I am prepared to consult. I consult with Keith Orchison of the APEA as often as he desires it and as frequently as I require it. Sometimes our competing desires for consultation overlap; sometimes they do not. But there has never been any issue of failure to consult or lack of availability when consultations are necessary. I have discussed with Mr Orchison the subject of tax deductability for the removal of offshore platforms. That is a matter that the Government has before it and it is not appropriate for me to comment on it any further, but Mr Orchison is aware of that.

ANSWER.PARA: In terms of the whole excise regime, I answered a question earlier in Question Time today on that matter. The Government's position is that the excise is an appropriate levy for oil producers to pay and approximates what in our view is the economic rent for the exploitation of the resource. I guess this question is prompted by the rash of newspaper articles which are appearing as a prelude to the APEA annual conference next month.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not going to be blessed by your presence, are they?
—The conference will be blessed by my presence and I will present an erudite paper on oil exploration in Australia and the prospects for the Australian industry.
—I was thinking of going until I heard that.
—I do not think Senator Chaney ever intended to go.
—Oh, you just happen to have a copy, do you?

—Since this question of exploration has arisen, I just happen to be able to tell Senator Hill that, in terms of the exploration activity in Australia, last year the number of offshore oil wells drilled in this country was double the number drilled in 1987. It is estimated that offshore activity by the APEA itself will be higher this year. The number of onshore wells drilled last year represented a drop of about 40 per cent from the number drilled in 1987, but there is no Commonwealth excise paid on the onshore drills. We expect that in 1989 the number of drillings will be about 70 per cent of the 1988 total, and that is still a high level of activity.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Has there been any change, and if so what, in the Government's program for charging overseas students at Australian education institutions? Have the students who commenced courses as assisted students in Australia before the changes were made been affected in any way? If so, in what way?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the last part of the question, overseas students who began their courses of study under the subsidised program will be able to complete those studies as subsidised students. I am sure that Senator Cooney will be very pleased to hear that. I will provide a few other details. In December 1988 the Government decided to phase out the overseas subsidised student program. From January next year all new overseas students will enter Australia on a full fee paying basis, but a selection of them will be on scholarships. Australia's education aid and foreign policy objectives will thereby be more efficiently pursued by applying the funds previously used for subsidies to a program of targeted scholarships for overseas students.

ANSWER.PARA: Under the subsidised program, overseas students paid 55 per cent of the average full cost of tuition, while the Commonwealth, through the aid budget, met the balance, which was a subsidy of approximately $80m a year. Much of this went to students who could afford to pay for the other costs of their tuition. The new scholarship scheme, which is to be administered by the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau, will provide full scholarships to students from developing countries on the basis of both equity and merit. It is to be known as the equity and merit scholarship scheme and it will more readily meet Australia's foreign aid objectives than did the former subsidised system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications accept that efficient sea transport, for both coastal and overseas trade, is very important for the whole Australian economy? Does he accept that the Australian flag ships at present are, by the standard of the ships of nations of comparable economic standing, grossly overmanned, both in the numbers of crew on board and in the time they spend on leave, and that recent changes have left even the most modern ships still 40 per cent overmanned by international standards? Is it a fact that the main argument for using uncompetitive Australian flag ships has been the effect on our balance of payments? I quote, for example, the remarks of the Government Minister in introducing the Ships (Capital Grants) Bill when he said that reliance on foreign shipping placed a heavy burden on Australia's balance of payments. Has the Minister seen a major new study on the impact of Australian flag shipping on the balance of payments, which shows, I think quite conclusively, that Australian flag ships, as operated at present, contribute negatively to our current account, not positively as the Government has always assumed? In view of this, will the Government expedite arrangements to make our Australian flag shipping competitive by the standards of comparable countries and open up all our shipping operations to proper competition, without which there can be no efficiency?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of parts to that question and of course I agree with the assumptions in the first one or two, in which I am asked whether transport is important in terms of international competitiveness and so on. I agree that it is very important. Senator Hamer then moved to his very old chestnut, which is the manning scales on Australian ships. In addressing that question he by implication made the point that, although the manning scale position has improved, it is perhaps not comp- arable with the best international standards. When I say `the best international standards', I do not mean the standards which prevail in ships registered in Panama or somewhere like that, and I do not think Senator Hamer does either. I mean ships of Norwegian and other Scandinavian lines and so on. I make the point that an analysis which I recall of the costs of the Australian shipping industry indicated that the total element of labour costs was between 12 and 14 per cent of the total costs of the shipping industry here, which made the industry uncompetitive in international terms.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Hamer then asked me whether I was aware of a new study on this matter. He was probably referring to a study commissioned by the Business Council of Australia together with the Australian Mining Industry Council and the National Farmers Federation, in which some estimates were made of the excess costs in the transport sector and the effect on the balance of payments. I am broadly aware of the nature of that study. In essence it is a positive contribution to the information available on this issue, although, like many studies of this kind, it tends to make some rather wild claims about the behavioural consequences of some of the matters it recommends. That is taken as par for the course in many of these studies. Having said all that, I think Senator Hamer is fully aware that the transport and shipping industries, particularly the wharf industries and coastal shipping, are high on the Government's agenda for consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have been for a couple of years.

—A number of both industry and Inter-State Commission working parties have been working on these issues, which are not capable of simple resolution and require, as Senator Stone indicates by way of interjection, a period of steady and informed work. The Government will address those reports in the near future.

—I address my question to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Is the Minister aware of a National Women's Consultative Council press release of 3 March 1989 which makes some quite specific recommendations about Government housing policy, including the need to develop a national women's housing strategy, to continue its commitment to the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, and to ensure tenancy protection in the private rental market? Can the Minister inform the Senate what the Government's reaction to the National Women's Consultative Council's statement is and say what she intends to do to ensure the Council's views are considered in developing housing policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The specific recommendations of the National Women's Consultative Council in its press release last Friday cover a range of matters which I shall take one by one. The Council recommends that the Government should implement the recommendations of the 1987 National Women's Housing Conference. The main recommendation of that conference was that a Commonwealth-State women's housing strategy should be developed. The women's housing issues working party is responsible for coordinating the Commonwealth-State Ministers' responses to the National Women's Housing Conference, and will be reporting to the housing Ministers April conference. Secondly, Council recommends that the release of Commonwealth land for housing should include a component for public housing. The Commonwealth's submission at the housing summit last Friday included references to the appropriateness in many cases for land to be offered, in the first instance, to State and local governments, and that the provision of land for public housing purposes would be looked at on a case by case basis.

ANSWER.PARA: Thirdly, the Council recommends continuation and expansion of the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. In 1987-88 the Commonwealth provided a total of $1.563 billion to housing under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, Loan Council nominating arrangements and departments of Social Security and Veterans' Affairs rent assistance. A figure of $1.6 billion went to public rental housing. Total Commonwealth assistance provided under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement to State and Territory governments has increased from $567m in 1983-84 to $700 in 1988-89.

In points 4 and 5 the National Women's Consultative Council recommends the establishment of monitoring mechanisms on service provision to women under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement and collection of gender based data on mobility patterns. In a letter of 22 February 1989, responding to representations I had made about women's housing, Minister Staples pointed out that provision of gender based data is an agreed principle of the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. Officers of the Department are currently involved in a Commonwealth-State working party on that data collection, which aims to ensure collection of gender based data by State.

The Council's sixth recommendation relates to tenancy protection in the private rental market, and such protection is very much a matter for States. The final recommendation relates to the establishment of a national program for short, medium and long term housing for women. The Government has established a review of Commonwealth housing policy. Senior officers of the housing review have met with the women's housing interest working party and the Office of the Status of Women has also provided advice. As honourable senators will be aware, the outcomes of the housing review and matters concerning housing funding in 1989-90 are yet to be considered by the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister consider tabling the document from which she has been quoting?
—That is a decision for the Minister. Is the Minister happy to table the document?
—Yes.
—All of the document.
—The Minister does not have to table briefing notes.
—Mr President, I am happy to table the document. I was trying to find the press release, which I thought was of great relevance.

—My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women and follows her detailed answer on the matters raised in answering the previous question. Is she aware that the waiting list for public housing has increased during the term of the Hawke Government by some 60 per cent? What advice can she give the Senate on the extent to which that has affected women in the community? What proportion of women are affected? Has it impacted negatively on them?

—I have given indications of the increase in funding allocated to public housing. I suggest that the waiting lists will grow if the recommendations in Future Directions are implemented under which a proposed government comprising those opposite-if it were ever to have the opportunity to do so, which I doubt-is committed to the reduction of public expenditure.

—I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister dispute that, notwithstanding the substantial increases in expenditure on public housing under the Hawke Government, the waiting lists have increased by approximately 60 per cent? Does she dispute that fact? If she does not dispute it, will she explain why that has occurred to the obvious detriment of so many women in Australia?
—Would Senator Chaney mind repeating the question? I did not hear some of the detail.

—My question was as follows: does the Minister dispute that the waiting list for public housing has increased by some 60 per cent during the term of the Hawke Government, notwithstanding the substantial increases in public expenditure on housing during the term of that Government? Does she dispute that a substantial proportion of welfare cases are women? Can she explain how the Government's programs have been such a failure?
—I do not dispute the figures. I am well aware of them.
—Are you ashamed of them?

—I am certainly ashamed of the extent of waiting lists in Queensland, Senator Boswell. Senator Chaney is quick to point the finger at the Federal Government, but housing is also very much a responsibility of State governments. In a number of States, notably Queensland, there is not the commitment to public housing that there should be. There are certainly waiting lists in a number of States. I would be interested to look at waiting lists on a State by State basis and compare them according to the politics and commitment of the government concerned. I do not dispute the fact that there are waiting lists; I do not dispute the fact that women are affected. But Opposition senators continually ignore the very real commitments given by this Government on housing and on a whole range of other issues which vitally affect the lives of Australian women and their families. It would be a good idea if Senator Chaney were to adopt the bipartisan approach that Senator Vanstone was suggesting at the Liberal women's conference last year.
—Bipartisan does not mean that the Minister should not answer the question.

—We all acknowledge that there are waiting lists, but it is also important to acknowledge the work that has been done by this Government. The supported accommodation assistance program has increased by--
—Five dollars a child.

—Yes, there have been enormous increases. The figure has increased by $71m. Given the fact that the Opposition comes into this place and talks about what the Government should be doing, it should be pointed out that the Opposition's own policy document-the document that is not a policy, I was told by Senator Vanstone yesterday-commits it to reducing public expenditure. If Opposition senators are committed to reducing public sector expenditure, I would ask how Senator Chaney intends to change the waiting lists for housing.

—Is the Minister for Consumer Affairs aware that used cars from Japan are being dumped on the Australian market? Is he also aware that these cars fail to meet Australian safety standards in that they are not fitted with anti-burst door locks, safety glass, side intrusion bars and seat belt anchoring points, and are therefore a danger on our roads? Is he aware that more than 4,000 of these substandard cars have been shipped here in the last six months and that a ship called the Hercules is soon to arrive carrying more than 1,000 unsafe vehicles? Is it a fact that insurance companies are refusing to insure some of these cars, that many spare parts are not available in Australia and, most importantly, that litigation following an accident involving one of these cars would be a legal nightmare? What is the Minister doing about this? Will he take action to ban the import of these unsafe cars?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Powell for the question. The matter has had some publicity in recent days. Accordingly, I am aware that used cars are being imported from Japan in commercial quantities. I have heard allegations that these cars do not meet Australian design standards. Some of the allegations and concerns expressed have come from the Australian automobile industry, which claims that the cars might possibly breach Australian vehicle design rules. I would also have a major concern that the manufacturers' recall provisions which apply in Australia may not be able to be used if the allegations are correct.

ANSWER.PARA: Some of the specific allegations that Senator Powell raises are ones that I am not closely apprised of. The registration of motor vehicles is obviously within the ambit of State authorities. However, on the national level we can take and are taking a number of actions. I have asked the Trade Practices Commission to examine the application of the Trade Practices Act to these vehicles to see whether the provisions of this Act have been breached. I am also consulting urgently with my colleague the Minister for Transport and Communications to see whether any ongoing hazards involving safety are associated with these vehicles. The other ongoing activity is to bring the States into this response as well. I am consulting with State Ministers to ensure that their consumer protection provisions also apply in cases of substantiated allegations.

In the meantime, however, I think that, we should advise consumers, firstly, to have whatever car they buy checked by an independent association, such as the National Roads and Motorists Association or the Royal Automobile Club. Secondly, when buying a car consumers should check the compliance plate to see whether Australian design rules have been complied with. That plate is under the bonnet of all motor vehicles. The allegations and the publicity have been of concern to me. That is why I have embarked upon this course of action.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEFENCE EQUIPMENT: SALES TO COUNTRIES IN SOUTH EAST ASIA

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —At Question Time on Friday, 3 March, Senator Newman asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade a question relating to a defence industry sales mission to South East Asia. I do not think I need to repeat the question, but will do so if need be to make the reply intelligible. The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows: The trade mission to South East Asia late last year was a joint Defence and Austrade initiative, undertaken with the full knowledge of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. The mission report made a number of recommendations to enhance the level of trade in this area, one of which concerned export finance packages, which was the subject of the honourable senator's question, which need to be competitive with those currently being offered in the region by other countries.

ANSWER.PARA: Thirdly, the Government is currently looking at the whole question of financial assistance for exports generally. Indeed, late last year, as Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, I appointed a committee of review chaired by Professor Helen Hughes to examine this question and to report by June this year. I understand that the Department of Defence has made a submission to Professor Hughes's committee, based on recommendations from the South East Asian industry mission. That submission notes that current policy is inconsistent with the intent of changes in export approval procedures announced by the Government in order to enhance the level of defence exports.

The Export Finance Insurance Corporation (EFIC), administered by Austrade, is able to provide finance packages for exports of both defence and non-defence items. The Australian International Development Assistance Bureau makes available the development import finance facility with which EFIC can combine with finance packages. This facility is not currently available for defence equipment sales. Future action by the departments will involve further consultation and the outcome of the review by Professor Helen Hughes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Tuesday, 7 March, Senator McLean asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business, a question without notice about the HIFAR research reactor of the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation at Lucas Heights. I answered part of the question, but undertook to provide a further answer. As Senator McLean is not here and I am not sure that there is universal interest in this topic, I ask that the answer be incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-
(1) No. All staff who are performing the duty officer role have been fully accredited under the relevant safety requirements.
The Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business last week issued a press release to rebut similar claims made by the Opposition about the safety of the HIFAR reactor.

The facts of the matter are not as the Honourable Senator describes. An extensive external review of staffing arrangements at HIFAR was undertaken in 1984-85. After a very long period of consultation with the relevant unions and reactor engineers, ANSTO implemented the new staffing arrangements on 13 January this year.

(2) There is no breach of safety procedures involved in current staffing under the new arrangements, in which a number of reactor engineers have refused to participate in the rostered after hours duty officer system.

All safety requirements are fully met. Although reactor engineers will no longer be on rotating shift duties, they are performing more important engineering work associated with the reactor. A HIFAR accredited engineer is readily available at all times when the reactor is operating.

(3) The Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO), after being unable to reach agreement with the APEA in relation to the five HIFAR engineers involved, filed an application on 22 February 1989 with the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to vary their award.
The new arrangements have been operating satisfactorily since 13 January. The safety of reactor operations is not an issue, so there is no urgency on safety grounds for the hearing to be reassigned.
(4) Representatives of the APEA and the reactor engineers met with the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business on 16 February 1989 and could not come to any agreement on the matter.
The Minister wrote to APEA on 22 February to advise that he considered the issue is essentially a management one and should be resolved within the organisation.

(5) The safe operation of the reactor is the responsibility of ANSTO management and this safety is monitored and reviewed by the Nuclear Safety Bureau, which is established under the ANSTO Act as an independent body reporting directly to the Minister.
The Bureau has advised that the revised arrangements are acceptable on nuclear safety grounds.
(6) The last part of the question is not relevant to the issue.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AFFAIRS: FUNDING FOR HOPEVALE COMMUNITY

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

John Gayler, the member for Leichhardt, whose name was mentioned in the statutory declaration tabled in the Senate on 28 February, issued a press statement rejecting the claim made in this declaration. That would be well known to honourable senators.

ANSWER.PARA: Regarding the funding for the Hopevale community referred to in the statutory declaration, I take this opportunity to set down some chronological facts. On 1 December the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs met with Hopevale representatives, including Mr Gibson, and discussed a $6m funding for a community infrastructure program. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to make a brief statement to correct an error.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not referring to me, I hope.

SPEECH.PARA: It has always been my view that when dishonest or incompetent white advisers end up misappropriating or mismanaging funds intended for the white community it ultimately ignites an environment in the community which causes ill will and creates a cradle for foment of prejudice and racism against the very people that the funds are designed to give support to.

As I am speaking I note that Senator Tate has his earphones on, listening to the House of Representatives debate. He has little regard for and little care about these matters. We are not able to get a response from him to a report which was provided to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs in August last year by Mr Dunlevy and Mr Lyne. Senator Tate said yes, but the answer is no. By any measure he has misled the Senate. I asked, `Are the departmental officers sufficiently skilled to deal with the matters?'. Again Senator Tate said yes. He said that the officers were sufficiently skilled. Mr Dunlevy and Mr Lyne say that they are not-far from it. They described them, in another way, as incompetent. I asked, `Are these officers incompetent by definition of the Department? Are they being paid a level equal to that intended for an officer capable of efficiently discharging duties and responsibilities?'. Of course, we got no answer to that. Senator Tate, all I can say to you is this: the answers you have given are unsatisfactory to say the least. The disregard that the Department, the Minister and presumably you have for the Senate does not, at least for my part, go unrecorded. I foreshadow that if all those questions are not answered--

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 8 March, from Senator Vallentine:

INTERJECT.PARA: Dear Mr President
