Is the proposal supported?
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for the Government to acknowledge
(a) that the new guidelines on arms sales and defence exports mean that Australia can no longer be considered a country which chose to refuse membership of the arms club

(b) that the decision means that the export of arms and defence material by Australia is more important than the point of impact: the people in other countries, primarily the Third World, who will suffer and die because of Australia's decision to improve its balance of payments in this way; and

(c) that there is therefore an urgent need for the Government to reconsider its decision to change its policy on the export of military equipment and to refuse to join the accelerating competition around the world to market and export such equipment.

I put forward this matter of urgency as a result of a concern long held about the dangers of increasing the international trade in weapons, or arms transfers as they are now called. For many years Australia refused to have much to do with arms transfers as we had very strict export controls and we were proud of the fact that we had not joined the arms club. We could be critical of those countries that sold arms to both sides in the Iran-Iraq war from 1980 to 1988, we could criticise the flow of arms into south-west Asia, and we could view with disfavour those countries, such as France and the United Kingdom, that quite blatantly promoted the sale of arms to repressive regimes in imitation of the United States of America and the Soviet Union. Until recently these two countries controlled most of the global arms trade, which no longer is solely in the hands of the merchants of death but also is in the hands of governments.

According to the 1988 report of the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute, world arms sales last year totalled $US35.1 billion at 1985 constant prices, compared with $US32.3 billion in 1986. At the same time, however, there has been a significant drop in the share of the arms trade controlled by the United States and the Soviet Union as competition has come from new exporting nations such as Israel, China, Taiwan, Argentina, Brazil, South Africa, India, Singapore and South Korea, among others. These countries produce cheap but effective military equipment for export at competitive rates. As a result, we have increasing competition in a decreasing market. An article in the Current Affairs Bulletin of February 1988 pointed out that, from a high of $43.6 billion in 1982, Third World orders for new arms dropped to $29.9 billion in 1985.

The major powers still control the export of sophisticated military equipment, such as jet fighters and nuclear submarines, but the day-to-day lethal hardware used in wars going on around the world at this moment is increasingly being supplied by countries trying to offset their own defence purchases by exports, primarily to other Third World countries. They are not strict about export controls and much of the equipment turns up where it was not designed to be; hence, the use of the term `arms transfers' rather than `arms sales'.

It is therefore disturbing that, at a time when many countries are showing increasing concern about the international arms trade and transfers, Australia should decide to join in. This is despite the strong statements made by the former Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Mr Hayden, at the United Nations Special Session on Disarmament in New York last June. I think it is worth reminding the Senate of two statements he made at that gathering:

It is also clear that arms exports should not be turned to as a way of solving domestic economic problems. Arms transfers must not become a new cash crop. It should also be recognised, especially by those whose development needs are great, that the purchase of arms is at the cost of the purchasers of the investment goods essential to the creation of employment and economic growth.
Ten days later the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) announced a new export drive for military equipment. Mr Hayden said:

I can't go to the United Nations Special Session on Disarmament, as I did a fortnight ago in New York and talk about our commitment in Australia . . . to work to try and cut back the arms trade . . . and then come back home and talk about a huge burst in the sale of conventional arms.

But that is exactly what happened. Bit by bit this Government is changing the old controls to free up military exports. Already we have had a sales drive through the national security states of South East Asia last September although apparently we did not make any sales on the spot. Not surprisingly, Senator Newman has already complained that, unless we also make a competitive soft loan package available to potential buyers, we cannot meet the demands of the Defence Manufacturing Council, which claimed in its February 1989 newsletter:

Until the Australian Government is prepared to match the financial packages provided by the governments of Australian industries international competitors there is not much prospect of selling major equipment.

At least the writer is honest in stating that Australia needs this strong export trade in order to improve the balance of trade figures. However, much of the present imbalance is caused by the import of expensive items such as computers for the Department of Defence and the Geraldton spy base, as well as the FA18s and submarines.

What else are we prepared to do to compete in this market? Should we follow the example of Sweden, where four executives from Bofors face trial for illegally exporting weapons to Iran and other Persian Gulf states, while two businessmen are on trial for illegal gunpowder exports? Yet as Paul Palsson, the President of the state owned Kockums Marine Co., said recently:
Sweden is too small a market to carry the arms industry it has. You have to get out and export.
This sounds rather like the words of Senator Evans, who last week said during Question Time:

From a narrow commercial perspective, the encouragement of defence exports can contribute to the development of our domestic industrial domestic base which enhances Australia's overall defence self-reliance as well as our economic position.

Then again we might take note of an article in the New York Times last month which quoted India's Defence Minister. He said that India also plans to increase exports of its own arms industry to raise funds to import high technology weapons systems and to upgrade its military forces. I suppose one of the things they have to pay for is the new naval base out of Goa which is being built by an Australian-Dutch consortium. The contract is worth $2 billion.

When the competition becomes hot, corners get cut, corruption becomes rife and export controls, if they exist, are progressively slackened. That is what happened in Sweden and the trend is now evident in Australia. It is made more likely by the climate of secrecy around arms transfers and the cynicism that flourishes in this murky atmosphere. Virtually the whole world condemned the Iran-Iraq war, but, according to the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute, 40 countries supplied arms to the warring parties while a number of them supplied arms to both sides. These included the United States of America, the Soviet Union, Switzerland, North Korea, China, Brazil and Italy. When it comes to a deal, ideology does not seem to make much difference. It is interesting to note that one of Iran's best suppliers was Israel, which made covert shipments to Tehran worth hundreds of millions of dollars.

Another example of the covert market is South Africa, which is now one of the 10 largest exporters of military equipment in the world, despite global sanctions imposed by the United Nations in 1977. According to the South African Armaments Corporation, South Africa now sells to 32 countries. Jane's Defence Weekly reckons that South Africa sold $A1,090m worth of arms to foreign countries last year and expects to sell $1.45 billion worth this year.

I make these points because this Government claims to maintain strict controls, although the reality is that they will be slackened with the new changes which the Minister for Defence announced last June and which he hopes to implement this year. It is therefore worth noting the example of Sweden, a country much admired in certain circles of the Australian Labor Party. It is one that has often taken the high moral ground in international affairs. It too has strict military export controls. Sweden's biggest exporter of military equipment is Bofors. It has been estimated that its exports would be three to five times bigger without these restrictions.

It is extremely instructive to read the book by Ingvar Bratt, who worked at Bofors for 14 years and whose involvement with the Swedish Green Party after 1981 led him to question the export of arms to the Third World. This was after the Swedish arms exports increased by four times during the last years of the 1970s. A major part of these exports was directed to the Third World. Ingvar Bratt discovered that a project he was working on as technical project manager for an anti-aircraft system, the RBS-70, was being sold to Dubai and Bahrain, although the whole of the Middle East was a forbidden area for arms exports.

Subsequently Bofors was involved in the scandal which I have already referred to as well as allegations of enormous bribes paid to Indian officials to secure a contract there and the diversion of military supplies to Libya. Singapore, Britain and Yugoslavia have also been named as countries reselling Swedish made weapons or munitions to circumvent Swedish regulations, although no charges have been laid in these cases.

On a historical note, it also appears that Swedish State Arms Firm FFV flouted an official arms embargo 20 years ago by selling the Carl Gustav anti-tank system to Australia between 1966 and 1972 when we were engaged in the Vietnam conflict. Company officials admitted the sales and claims that the Government knew about it at the time.

What defence exports are we talking about in relation to Australia? Thus far they have been essentially restricted to small arms and ammunitions and associated equipment, although we have sold or are about to sell some larger items such as artillery pieces and missiles. The emphasis for the future appears to be on high-tech equipment with markets envisaged in South East Asia as well as further afield in countries like the United Kingdom, Brazil, the United States and New Zealand.

I would next like to consider the controls on these exports. Under the new policy the controls have been reduced and the Department of Defence will become the dominant party in the export process. In effect, future military exports are to be governed more by narrow defence and bureaucratic concerns than by broader political, economic and humanitarian considerations.

Preceding the decision to promote the export of arms and defence equipment, there was a struggle between the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Department of Defence, but Minister Beazley was able to trade on a climate of political and public opinion that increasingly believed the main enemy in Australia was the balance of payments. Exports of anything, including defence material, were therefore regarded as in the national interest. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, perceived by the industry to date as the more intractable on exports, has now been relegated to the sidelines.

We do not yet know in detail what the new guidelines are but some indication may be given by recent sales drives in the Indian subcontinent. There was a big push to get the contract for the new naval base in India and to make sure that it did not go to France. At the same time we extended, at Pakistan's request, the tender closing date for countries wanting to buy 50 ex-Royal Australian Air Force Mirage fighters. Pakistan is planning to extend its air force by acquiring 125 planes-75 from China and the other 50 from Australia.

If there were ever two countries which had a bad record of conflict over the last 40 years, they would be India and Pakistan. Yet Australia is busy doing deals on both sides while defence commentators write endless articles on the arms race in the Indian Ocean and the rapid expansion of the Indian navy. Indeed, some of the more conservative analysts have said that Australia should respond by acquiring nuclear submarines, which will no doubt have to be paid for by selling more arms overseas to prop up our trade deficit. I waited to hear some objections to the contract for the new naval base but there was a deafening silence. Obviously a dollar is a dollar. The defence industry benefits either way despite the spin-off effect of the diversion of resources at home, whether India or Australia.

The new export controls will apply only to items specifically designed or adapted to military purposes and to products which are inherently lethal or destructive. What is included under the heading of `non-lethal' equipment? That is not entirely clear, but there appears to be an assumption that if one cannot shoot somebody with a piece of equipment one is not supporting military establishments which are engaged in human rights abuses. Jeff Atkinson, Education Officer for Community Aid Abroad in Melbourne, has observed:
We think this is a retrograde step.

Where do we draw the line between offence and defence? In countries which have no external enemy, where are the police and military deployed after they have learned to shoot at these training targets we sell in South East Asia? Michael Klare, Associate Professor of Peace and World Security Studies at Hampshire College, Massachusetts, noted:

We find that many countries which import conventional weapons supposedly for defensive purposes actually use these weapons more often than not on their own populations. Rather than to resist aggression . . . the bulk of the military infrastructure is engaged in internal security against social forces which are suffering for one reason or another in those countries. The arms trade is actually contributing to the perpetuation of an authoritarian regime.

It is, therefore, ironic that our first big sales drive last November and December-the Australia-South East Asia industry mission-visited such bastions of human rights as Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore, Thailand and the Philippines. The sales push cost $90,000, plus the salaries of officers on the mission. Yet almost all of those are countries where Australia has had to make representations on human rights in the last couple of years. So we have this ludicrous contradiction of our sales people popping in through one door while human rights people follow through another. In other words, Australia is taking precisely the same path as all other countries which have turned to arms exports to pay for their own arms imports, or to improve their balance of payments position.

The global economic recession has meant a drop in demand at the very time when Australia decided to enter the market along with countries such as China, the two Koreas, India, Israel, South Africa and Singapore. It was embarrassing to witness the hypocrisy of Australia's words at the United Nations Special Session on Disarmament last year, when I was in New York, with the reality back home. The Ambassador for Disarmament supported motions calling for a database to be established on arms transfers as the first step from the United Nations in eliminating the transfers of armaments worldwide and, at the same time, the Minister for Defence said that we would double Australia's exports in the near future. Of course, it was not so embarrassing for other people at that stage because they did not understand the hypocrisy. But it is a fact that our government delegations are sometimes forced into the situation where they act a lie because they do not tell the whole truth about what is going on in Australia. So the fine words were spoken at the same time as our defence export industry was taking off at home.

Another issue I wish to touch on is what I have described as the point of impact. The export drive is designed to help us reduce our trade deficit and pay for all those expensive planes, ships, submarines and computers that we import to fend off threats to our security, wherever they come from. What we forget too often is that innocent men, women and children get killed in war, and in modern warfare 90 per cent of the victims are civilians. Over 20 million people have been killed in wars since 1945, almost entirely in the Third World. Despite the gradual ending of a number of regional conflicts, there are still 36 wars being fought around the world today, according to the latest Stockholm International Peace Research Institute handbook.

Even when people are not being killed there is enormous injustice being done to the countries which buy military equipment, whether lethal or non-lethal. We criticise those poor countries which spend so much on the military while their people live in poverty without access to clean water, basic health care, education or decent housing; yet at the same time we cheerfully go to those countries to sell expensive military equipment. I doubt that the members of the South East Asia industry mission bothered to visit the slums of Bangkok or Smoky Mountain in Manila-the garbage tip where thousands of Filipinos eke out an inhuman existence.

On 3 March, in a debate on the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (General Capital Increase) Bill, Senator Macklin suggested that maybe multilateral finance institutions should start making arms reductions a condition of loans to developing countries. Such an idea is fine in principle but, at the same time, we cannot try to sell military equipment to countries with a huge debt already and whose people often live in degrading poverty while the military plays with its new toys. I remind the Senate of the former Foreign Minister's oft-quoted conditions which he emphasised in 1986 that we should not sell arms to countries which are at war, preparing for war or which would use those weapons against their own people. That just about cuts out the whole market, particularly when one considers the third item.

The military hardware which is being sold today is becoming increasingly lethal. It is not surprising that so many countries sent official representatives to Iraq last year after its use of chemical weapons to find out how they could acquire the poor nations' nuclear weapons. At the same time, both the United States and the Soviet Union are showing concern over the proliferation of ballistic missiles which can now be made by countries such as India and China. What I am saying is that either we want to be part of this club or we take a stand against it. We cannot declaim against global arms transfers at the United Nations and proclaim our human rights record when at the same time Australian officials are busy selling military equipment to countries which cannot afford it and will use it against their own people. I know that the usual response will follow, that if we do not sell it someone else will. That is the old argument of the dope pedlar or the drug pusher and it is no justification for getting involved in this evil trade. Finally, I draw the Senate's attention to a press statement put out by the Reverend Neville Ross, Chairman of the Australian Council for Overseas Aid, last July. He said:
Australia does not need to abandon its traditional and internationally respected stance against the arms race for the sake of a few easy dollars from the merchants of death.
The statement was sent to the heads of the Council's 85 member organisations and church leaders, most of whom endorsed it, including my own denomination-the Religious Society of Friends or Quakers.

I agree that Australia needs to improve its trade deficit, but I suggest that there are better ways of doing it and that there are more socially useful items that we can manufacture and export. We might also contemplate a decision to stop importing expensive new military equipment that is not relevant to the defence of Australia and thus promote real security in the region rather than joining the growing arms race around us, which benefits only the dealers and is to the detriment of everyone else. I commend the motion to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is only dollars that count. Ideology has nothing to do with it.

SPEECH.PARA: The next paragraph of Senator Vallentine's motion states:

It is an exaggerated claim that denigrates the motion completely. Australia has an active overseas aid program which last year amounted to over $1 billion. As a senator, I have taken an interest in observing and promoting that aid program. I certainly know that Senator Vallentine has also shown interest in the overseas aid program. I believe that all members of parliament would like to see Australia being able to afford an even larger overseas aid program to help the developing countries.

As part of that aid program we also have a defence cooperation program for the provision of patrol boats and other equipment to countries of the South Pacific. Those countries need to patrol boats because they want to protect their economic interests, particularly fishing, from being exploited by illegal fishing by Taiwanese, Japanese or American fishing interests. I am again bemused that Senator Vallentine should be jumping up and down in the Senate, being extremely critical of American foreign policy. Yet, we are providing equipment to South Pacific countries under a defence cooperation program so that they can protect their economic interests in their fishing industries against the tuna boat fishing association of America. Senator Vallentine should be consistent, and say that at times our aid program is to the benefit of Third World countries, even to the detriment of the interests of the tuna boat fishing association of America.

The final part of the motion asks that the Government reconsider its decision. Senator Vallentine should be in no doubt that the Government's revision of Australia's defence export controls has been done in a carefully considered way. Australian industry makes a vital contribution to the self-reliant defence of Australia. Defence exports help provide a more balanced workload for the Australian companies involved. The honourable senator's approach would undermine Australia's capacity to provide for its own defence in a self-reliant way. The honourable senator has also greatly overstated the nature of the changes we have introduced. I will not repeat the clear restrictions on defence exports now. I will come to them in a moment. The new policy clarifies just what equipment is subject to control. The new controls will focus on those goods that are designed for military purposes and are either lethal or of major military significance. The Government has moved to streamline the old cumbersome process that led to anomalies and inconsistencies. The new arrangements will enable a sensible balance between Australian commercial, defence and international interests.

I will now give details of the export policy changes by the Government and outline the differences between what occurred before June 1988 and the new policy announced by the Minister in June 1988. I refer here to the defence export controls in schedule 13 of the Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulations. The old schedule 13 failed to differentiate between lethal and non-lethal military goods and between military goods and non-military items like sporting firearms and commercial explosives. The old schedule included items devoid of real military significance, for example, uniforms and obsolete items such as barrage balloons. The old schedule failed to include items of obvious military significance, for example, naval ships and military aircraft. It failed to define the scope of controls in broad terms only, for example, firearms.

The new schedule 13 confines controls to export of those goods which are, firstly, specifically designed or adapted for military purposes and inherently lethal, incapacitating or destructive or, secondly, of major military significance. The new schedule 13 will also distinguish between exports of, firstly, military goods and, secondly, items like sporting firearms and commercial explosives which could be used by terrorists or insurgents but which also have widespread perfectly legitimate use by bona fide private citizens. The new schedule 13 defines items subject to control more clearly and includes technical notes for this purpose.

The second part of the policy concerns government endorsement of defence exports. Under the old policy there was a widespread perception in industry that government opposed defence exports, although defence exports had been going on for many years. Senator Vallentine is trying to give the impression that we are suddenly going to start defence exports. Under the old policy of the endorsement of defence exports, firms were content to supply limited Australian peacetime defence requirements. Under the new policy, the presumption is that defence exports will proceed, subject to clearly defined constraints. Under the new policy, public affirmation of government support for defence exports will help motivate firms to pursue legitimate opportunities overseas. There will be a presumption to approve an export application where our friends or allies would supply comparable equipment and the export would not prejudice any Australian military advantage.

The third part of the policy deals with policy constraints on defence exports. Under the old policy, guidance was confined to a few broad principles, for example, no arms were to be exported to countries engaged in military conflict or where the risk of conflict is high. Officials had to interpret these broad principles. This left the door open to anomalies and inconsistencies. Under the new policy, circumstances precluding defence exports are more tightly defined in terms of mandatory arms embargoes, international sanctions, Australian strategic interests, the violation of human rights with exports favoured where there is no reasonable risk of the equipment being used against the citizens of a country with a dubious civil rights record. I trust that Senator Vallentine will take note of that point. Defence exports are also precluded where specific foreign policy interests outweigh export benefits or are in opposition to private traffic in arms.

On the question of balancing our interests, under the old policy defence export applications could be vetoed on general foreign policy grounds. Under the new policy, balanced consideration of Australian commercial, defence and international interests is required. Defence strategic or foreign policy objections must be specific and must outweigh the export benefits in the particular case, for example, human rights. There is now a clearer responsibility. Under the old policy, no clear distinction was drawn between, firstly, the provision of policy advice by non-defence Ministers and officials and, secondly, responsibility of the Minister for Defence and his officials for defence export approval or denial.

Under the new policy, the controls will be administered in accordance with agreed policy guidelines by defence officials delegated authority by the Minister for Defence. The Minister for Defence and his officials will consult the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce in preparing specific practical policy guidelines. The Minister for Defence is clearly responsible for developing and applying defence export policy. Interdepartmental consultation will be confined to a denial of export permission or to particularly sensitive cases. Under the old policy a decision could take several months or more than a year in extreme cases. Individual applications were handled as if each one was completely new. Under the new policy export applicants are to be advised within 21 days. Previous approvals will be used as precedents to expedite approval of follow-on buys of equipment, spare parts and stores.

Finally, under the new policy guidelines will be published for exporters. Under the old policy guidelines for administering defence export controls were classified as confidential. Exporters had to rely on officials for authoritative guidance. Under the new policy defence export guidelines will be published. I am sure Senator Vallentine will welcome that in particular. She and others who share her viewpoint will be able to see those guidelines and to argue in this and other forums in the community if they believe that the guidelines are being objected to or if they oppose, as they obviously do, according to this motion, any arms trade between Australia and overseas. The newly published guidelines will enable the export control system to be made as transparent as practicable with the nomination of contact officers. Again, Senator Vallentine will be able to use that information. This will facilitate necessary and welcome dialogue between exporters and responsible officials.

I believe that the guidelines outlined by the Government in this new policy will enable an industry already operating in Australia, and already exporting weapons under a complicated system of guidelines, to do so in a more clear and coherent fashion. It will enable people with viewpoints which differ from those of the Government to more readily identify what is happening and make those issues public in Australia. That will contribute to the debate. It will ensure that more of the Australian people know what is happening in regard to the export of Australian arms overseas.

I reject completely the suggestion that Australia is developing an arms trade that means that we will be in some sort of arms club on a similar level to the Soviets, the French, the Americans, the Swedes, the West Germans, the Chinese or the Czechoslovakians. That is an absurd suggestion which does proponents of Senator Vallentine's motion no good and affects considerably the credibility of their point of view.

I would like to conclude on Senator Vallentine's remarks about the inconsistency of our position in the United Nations. I had hoped that she would have the good grace to congratulate the Australian Government on achieving a significant breakthrough during the past week concerning the chemical weapons treaty. This is something the Australian Government has pushed considerably. The Bush Administration has now taken that matter up in the United Nations and it has become a major policy agenda item for that Administration. It looks as if we will be able to achieve a significant improvement in the position of the use of chemical weapons and their proliferation in the world. I agree with Senator Vallentine on one point: she described chemical weapons as the poor countries' atomic bomb. I think that is correct and I think that Australia's influence with the American Administration, resulting in its taking up this issue, is a great breakthrough. It also further underlines the fact that Australia, through its alliances within the Western group of nations, is able to influence countries such as the United States to adopt such attitudes. That is an improvement. If we adopted Senator Vallentine's general attitude that we should be neutral and non-aligned, we would not have had that influence to achieve what could be a significant breakthrough in controlling chemical weapons use in the world. I ask the Senate to reject the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating a motion on a matter of urgency moved by Senator Vallentine. We have all sat here before hearing some of this diatribe. SPEECH.PARA: This motion is all based on a principle which lies behind it and which is virtually unsaid-that by having no arms a country will be safe from aggression. There is no way that we in the Opposition can possibly countenance any motion based on that principle. That is the basis on which Senator Vallentine approaches any defence debate in this place. Senator Vallentine's motion refers to three matters. The first is:
The need of the Government to acknowledge-
(a) that new guidelines on arms sales and defence exports mean that Australia can no longer be considered a country which chose to refuse membership of the arms club;

(b) that the decision means that the export of arms and defence material by Australia is more important than the point of impact: the people in other countries, primarily the Third World, who will suffer and die because of Australia's decision to improve its balance of payments in this way;

We in the Opposition would not be able to accept any one of these points. First, it is a badly worded motion. It displays awkward use of the English language and is turgid in the extreme. I would ask which new guidelines Senator Vallentine is referring to. Is she referring to some guidelines that she has already seen? The motion contains a misleading and emotive use of the term `arms club', a matter that Senator Schacht has already successfully dealt with.
