Judging by the information put out publicly by the Government, it appears to cover items that have uses other than solely military which can then be sold without government intervention and items of a purely military nature which have to be treated on a case by case basis depending on who is buying the equipment and how necessary it is to keep the secret technology to ourselves. I draw attention to the statement put out by the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, on 14 June last year, in which he said that the Government announced `new principles for the control of defence exports that will speed up approval and rationalise the type of goods affected'. He said:

the Government aims to promote our defence exports without prejudice to important defence, international and human rights concerns. The new export controls will focus on those goods that are designed for military purposes and are either lethal or of major military significance.

The controls are to focus on those, but there will be a freeing up of controls in some areas. In the past, the exporters had no access to the old defence export guidelines, which were classified. It was reasonable that the Government should take action to deal with things that were out of date or inappropriate if our defence industry were to be able to make headway overseas.

I am glad also to draw to the Senate's attention the fact that on the same date the Opposition spokesman on defence, Mr Peter White, announced in a press release that the Opposition welcomed the Government's decision. He said that it was:
. . . a sensible policy towards defence exports which will do a great deal to assist Australian industry and to give Australia a further degree of defence self-sufficiency.

Mr White went on to say that commonsense appeared to have triumphed and that another Opposition policy had been implemented. The Government and the Opposition are looking at the matter very much from the same point of view, but the left wing elements in our society have a different agenda and find difficulty in accepting what we think is the right future direction for Australia.

Paragraph (b) of the motion refers to `the export of arms and defence material'. This is extraordinarily important to Australia. Senator Vallentine will dispute my reasons for arguing on these lines, but I believe that Australians must first think about the enormous trade deficit that this country faces. The figure for January was the worst on record, at $1.537 billion. Do we have the luxury of deciding that we will not allow any of our defence industry production to be sold overseas when we face such an incredible trade deficit? We also face a reduction in our living standards which is due entirely to the problems involved in having such a trade deficit. With our economic standing so low, it is nonsense to prevent legitimate exports such as those proposed by the Government. We would not agree with any prohibition on legitimate exports.

I also draw attention to the fact that the effort that is put into trying to stop these legitimate exports is similar to the efforts that are being put towards the prevention of legitimate exports of paper pulp. The same groups are dead keen to see that Australia does not improve its balance of trade position with regard to wood pulp exports. There is a group of people in this country which has no recognition of our diabolical economic position and which would try to push its unrealistic economic views down our throats, to the disadvantage of the nation.

Apart from that, the arms industry and defence related industry could be of critical importance in terms of our defence self-reliance. It is quite impossible, in a country of this size, to have production runs in industry which are large enough to keep unit costs down to an affordable level for our own defence requirements. Defence is an enormously expensive item for taxpayers to fund and an enormously important and vital area. Unless we can spread some of the costs by greater runs in industry, we shall be hard pressed to be able to provide any sort of self-reliance in equipping our own forces.

I draw attention to the lessons learned in this area during the Vietnam war. Senator Vallentine referred to this aspect, but did so pretty inaccurately, in my view. In fighting that war, we had soldiers whose lives depended on our ability to keep them supplied. Sweden refused to supply us with Carl Gustavs and also with the guns and ammunition for the helicopter gunships. In the case of the gunships, eventually Australia was supplied because Sweden sold the items to England, which in turn, sold them to Australia. But the fact remains that, when our troops needed this equipment desperately, there was a country remote from Australia which did not approve of our involvement and therefore sought to exercise its will upon us, thereby harming our troops. We must not be in that position, and we must do all we possibly can to see that never again are we in the hands of people who would defeat our war effort.

The people in other countries referred to in the motion also put great store in our ability to supply them. Senator Schacht mentioned the needs of the Pacific island countries with the Pacific patrol boat. They also need to be well equipped to meet the possibility of aggression in their countries. It is unrealistic to assume that the Pacific can possibly stay peaceful forever. We need countries that are well-equipped to defend themselves. We cannot be the defenders of the entire Pacific. If our neighbours are well-equipped and can operate with us in times of instability in our region, there will be more opportunity for us to enjoy peace with our neighbours.

Paragraph (c) of the motion refers to the urgent need, as Senator Vallentine sees it, for the Government to reconsider its decision to change its policy. I say that no way should the Government change its policy. There is an urgent need for the guidelines to be published quickly, for the sake of certainty, because that is an area of difficulty for industry. Industry needs to know exactly what the Government intends. I draw attention to the fact that the Cooksey Review of Australia's Defence Cooperation Programs and Policy on Export of Defence Equipment called for the Government to reach a decision on revised procedures for handling applications for defence exports by the end of 1986 and to have the related administrative structure in operation by July 1987. That action has not occurred and we criticise the Government for its lack of action. Things have taken far too long, and it is believed that it was the former Foreign Affairs Minister, Mr Hayden, who delayed action in that area. We are glad that the Government has moved in that area.

The Government has not yet moved in the area in which we believe it must move, and this relates to a question I asked Senator Evans last Friday. There is a desperate need for our neighbours to be able to get finance from the Australian Government if they are to make meaningful use of the purchases available to them. Until that time, our Australian industry will not be able to take full advantage of the new procedures. Nevertheless, we support the Government's action and totally reject Senator Vallentine's motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Australian Democrats, I support the urgency motion. I hope to do so in a manner more gracious than that in which Senator Newman opposed it. The Australian Democrats identify with the three elements of the urgency motion. Senator Vallentine, in moving the motion as a matter of urgency, drew attention to the fact that the Australian Government, in bringing down its guidelines and stating emphatically its policy on arms exports, had placed Australia firmly in the membership of the arms club, the arms exporters.

SPEECH.PARA: The second element of the urgency motion cites the fact that by virtue of these guidelines and policy we are placing Australia's export interests first, over and above the impact of the export of those arms on the recipients. In other words, the policy gives an approval to the export of weapons, guns, weaponry and instruments of war, because it happens to earn for us dollars and cents, irrespective of what the impact is upon the recipient country. Those two things being so, it seems eminently sensible to call upon the Government to reconsider that policy. Indeed, that is the third element of the urgency motion.

Before going on to develop the Australian Democrats' argument in support of the urgency motion, I devote a minute or two to one or two things that Senator Newman said. She mentioned the fact that she was somewhat embarrassed by the fact that the Opposition finds itself aligned with the Government on this question. I am surprised at that. If we look at the Hansard record, we find that the Government and the Opposition were aligned time and time again. A look at the record of voting patterns in this chamber over the last 12 or 18 months would show that on more than 50 occasions the Opposition and Government sat on the same side of the chamber confronting between seven and 10 Independents and Democrats. The fact is that ideologically they are one. The electorate is beginning to find it increasingly difficult to differentiate between the ideologies of the Opposition and the Government. I, for one, am not in the slightest bit surprised to find that the Opposition is aligned with the Government on this issue, in the same way as I am not surprised to find them aligned on other issues.

Where do we begin to address this urgency motion? In Australia we do not seem to question propositions such as that which states that a free society is better than an enslaved society. We would not even begin to question that proposition. Neither would we question the proposition that a just society is preferable to an unjust society, or that a more democratic society is preferable to an undemocratic society. However, for some reason or other, when it comes to questions and issues of peace and the eminently sensible proposition that a peaceful society is vastly preferable to a warlike society, we find that people like Senator Newman, other members of the Opposition and, indeed, the Government, have a hangup about peace.

It seems to me eminently sensible that in 1989 and into the 1990s, a nuclear age, quite clearly we have to do everything in our power to move towards global peace. Therefore, we in the Democrats do not for one moment wonder whether we should question a policy and a set of priorities which make Australia a manufacturer and an exporter of arms to Third World countries in the pursuit of dollars. We are really talking about a handful of dollars, relative to our gross domestic product. It strikes us as being an unethical, indeed immoral, position for the Government to place us in.

Therefore, in summary, the Democrats have grave reservations about these new policies. We believe they have no ethical basis. Australia has made many statements recently in the United Nations and elsewhere calling for the curtailment of the international arms trade; acknowledging the link between military expenditure and social hardship, particularly in developing countries; and urging nations to embrace non-military approaches to guaranteeing their security. These are the sorts of statements we make in the world forums, yet these are the sorts of policies and priorities being put in place by our Government. They stand in total contradiction to the statements that we make in world forums. They lie. They project to the world contradictions. Despite this, the Government now announces a policy of targeting developing countries for arms sales; reducing controls on sales of Australian arms and commercial explosives; defining whole categories of products and services as defensive, irrespective of the military position of the purchasing country; making the presumption that we will export to any country to which our allies export; and that exports to our allies will be unrestricted in any way.

The Government is locked into the mentality which said that we would fight in any country where our allies fought; we would go `all the way with LBJ'; we would export arms to any country to which our allies exported arms. It is a flawed rationale which historically has been tragic for us and all mankind. We must stop this insanity. This change of priorities and policy does nothing to stop it. Indeed, it reinforces the negative spiral and the negative processes that have been in place in the postwar period.

The Democrats, therefore, are disgusted by the Government's stand on this issue. We will push for parliamentary scrutiny of Australian arms exports, because details of military exports are currently not reported to the Parliament. We find that situation totally unacceptable. Approval of arms exports should be a joint decision by the Minister for Defence and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, because in this case trade priorities override the other two sets of priorities. In fact, they contradict them. Even if they were reinforced by what is argued by the Opposition-and presumably by the Government-to be defence priorities, they fly in the face of our foreign affairs priorities. The Government's policy is not only unethical, but also inherently illogical and contradictory. It must surely be a millstone around the neck of our new Ambassador for Disarmament, Mr David Rees.

We are trotting around the world stage, assuming leadership on the issues of chemical warfare, calling and convening international conventions in Australia to discuss the issue of chemical warfare and how it can be brought under control and how chemical weapons can be stopped in their production and distribution. On the other hand, we are turning our back on the issue of conventional weapons, somehow or other pretending that to be destroyed by a grenade, a bullet or a rocket is somehow less offensive than death by chemistry. It is farcical, hypocritical, contradictory and insane.

The position I have just stated has been stated in world forums by those who represent our Government in those forums. I will quote some of the things that we have said to be our official position in relation to the need to reduce the arms trade and military spending, precisely the question under discussion now, in some of those world forums. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade was quoted in an article in the Peace and Disarmament News of May 1988 as saying:

. . . Australia would like to see included in . . . an agenda for the UN Third Special Session on Disarmament . . . an enhanced approach to the problem of reducing conventional weapons including legitimate and illegal arms transfers between states . . .
At the same conference, Mr Richard Butler, the former Ambassador for Disarmament, said:
The absence from the multilateral disarmament agenda of the Conference on Disarmament of serious consideration of the problem posed by conventional arms and international arms transfers-
that is, arms trading-
is entirely inappropriate to today's circumstances.
Mr Butler further said:

This is the case for review of the Conference on Disarmament's agenda, but I would add one other reason, which is the shocking, the continued expansion of the global arms economy and the international trade in conventional weapons. How much longer can we ask people to take us seriously on the issue of global disarmament if we retain an agenda which does not address the horrible phenomenon of international trade, both overt and covert, in conventional weapons?

Yet, today the Government is saying, `Let us get in on this rat race. Let us get in on this insane trading of conventional weapons because we have a balance of payments problem and it will earn us a few bucks'. That is the mentality of drug pushers.

I was in Senator Newman's State of Tasmania only recently and saw opium being grown for medical uses. One might as well say, `Let us double, treble, quadruple, the acreage of opium and sell it overseas in order to rectify our balance of payments problems'. That is precisely the same mentality. The same moral code could be used to justify that proposition as is being used to justify the massive production and exportation of and international trade in conventional weapons. Yet, on the other hand, we argue against the production and distribution of chemical weapons.
Mr Hayden, whom I respected as a Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, said:
Arms transfers must not become a new cash crop.
That is a phrase I heard Senator Vallentine use at the beginning of this debate. He continued:

It should . . . be recognised, especially by those whose development needs are great, that the purchase of arms is at the cost of the purchase of the investment goods essential to the creation of employment and economic growth.

What is being suggested is that the whole business of selling arms to Third World countries simply disadvantages those countries in two ways: it prepares them to slaughter one another, usually for the most spurious reasons, and it simply drains their economies of the absolutely essential dollars necessary for their inherent positive growth.
Our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made the following statement in India about two weeks ago:

About 25 billion dollars are being channelled every year from the developing to the developed countries in the form of a reverse flow of resources. The most heavily indebted countries find themselves diverting to debt repayment more than half the value of their mercantile exports and close to 5 per cent of their gross domestic product. Developing countries face serious shortages of finance to manage their balance-of-payments problems and meet their requirements of development. Yet, sources of development assistance are drying up. . . . It is a sad comment on the inequity and inefficiency of the current order that developing countries are, in effect, financing the developed.

What is more, they are financing them in terms of the purchase of conventional arms. This abominable situation should not be tolerated by the Australian public, or by the world community. It is a situation that should not be argued about in our parliaments or tolerated politically. It is the essence of hypocrisy for the Government to put in place these policies and our Prime Minister to make these sorts of statements while strutting the international forum as a statesman. That is the view of the Australian Democrats in support of this urgency motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion with the qualification that I already consider Australia to be a member of the arms-exporting club, although it must be said that it has shown, up to now, more discrimination in both the material exported and its destination than have many other nations, like the United States and the United Kingdom, which we would expect to know better. This may have been merely a by-product of the tangled inefficiency of the bureaucratic approval system that Cooksey condemns in his report-in other words, anyone who wanted to kill anyone quickly would not have come to Australia for his military equipment. For all its possibly benign effects, I would not support the existing system. Apart from any- thing else, it has been impossible to know exactly what and how much military equipment is being exported. I believe that it is time that all such transactions were collected in a central registry where they can be subjected to the most open review possible.

SPEECH.PARA: We have all been sold a rather cunningly wrapped package by the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley). He has tied his defence policy of `self-reliance', with its stirring suggestion of the national self-respect that Australians have always hoped for but will not achieve while the Government persists in its current inequitable alliance, to a strong defence export industry which will more cheaply and more efficiently supply us with so-called `self-reliant' arms. If less had been spent on totally unsuitable and aggressive equipment in the past, we might be able to be truly self-reliant. Mr Beazley has also tantalised us with promises of large sums of money. A passing reference to the latest escalation in the trade deficit and the use of the word `banana' would seem to peel away moral reservations about selling arms. But I strongly suspect that Mr Beazley has sold himself his own market-place spiel and I agree with our Governor-General, Bill Hayden, who doubted that Australia would be broadly competitive in a market with many new suppliers.

If Australia does succeed in qualifying as a full-fledged `merchant of death' arms supplier, I do not see how we could avoid the further moral compromises-in addition to the moral problems associated with the fact of selling arms-that are likely to follow. The arms trade has a reputation for inducing corruption that is in no way inferior to the reputation of the heroin trade, as has been pointed out several times in this debate. The temptation to resort to bribery in a market-place where `everyone else is doing it' will be enormous, especially when dealing with countries with what I will call `alternative' ethical mores.

This is relevant to the widely publicised Bofors affair, where different moral imperatives were in conflict. Sweden, with half our population, faces a disproportionately larger threat and depends heavily upon its defence exports. The individuals involved faced a conflict between an abstract principle and the well-being of their families and work communities. Mats Lundberg was a prime mover in the clandestine shipment of explosives to Iran. He now faces criminal charges. But in speaking of local reaction to his offence, he said in a Four Corners program on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation:

It's a pleasure for me to go to the grocery store or the mail office. People are noticing me, people are talking to me much more than they did before. They keep slapping my back, wishing me luck and so on, so I have no problems at all at home, in that sense. Whatever I did, right or wrong, it was not for my personal gain or anything like that. It was concern about the company and the employees of the company, and they give me credit for that.
So, local and even national loyalties will always prevail over the welfare of distant and anonymous people.

When the Swedes found out, after his assassination, that Olaf Palme had been involved in brokering a corrupt artillery deal with India, they realised that the `prophet of our time' had been only a politician after all. Honourable senators will sympathise with the Swedes and will know the shock they must have suffered, but in Australia we are used to seeing our heroes fall off their clay feet and we have no excuse for not anticipating these problems. For instance, there will be a strong temptation, when negotiating substantial arms deals involving military weapons, not to inquire into the provenance of end-user certificates. The Swedish example, of course, provides a salutary lesson for Australia. I doubt whether the length of time that is proposed in the new legislation for an examination of end-user certificates-namely, only 21 days including weekends-will provide the sufficient time necessary for investigations into these matters.

It seems likely that any substantial growth in Australia's arms exports will arise from sales to nations in our own region. Even if we avoid arming them against ourselves, we may well end up arming them against each other. This would represent a further decline in our Government's much cherished but not much respected peace-promoting international image. It is up to this Parliament to investigate thoroughly the moral implications of an increased arms export trade. The Parliament will have an opportunity to do so in detail in April when the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill is debated in this chamber.

As I see it, there are three possible positions that Australia might take on this question. The first is virtually to export no arms at all, perhaps with the exception of small patrol boats to Pacific island states. The second is to establish clear guidelines defining defensive weapons that would be exported to nations not in conflict and not in breach of human rights conventions. This position is probably closest to Australia's current policy, but is much more clearly defined than the current slack regulations which govern exports. I am afraid the new regulations will do nothing to tighten up controls on exports-quite the contrary. The third position is to adopt the actual policy of the major arms exporting states. This position assumes that peace can be maintained only by a balance of terror. Australia could easily end up adopting this stance under the proposed new regulations. This Parliament, and particularly this chamber, has an obligation to raise the ethical questions of an expanded arms export trade and force the Government to face all the implications of its new policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously, I am opposing Senator Vallentine's urgency motion. It must be very comfortable to be elected to this Senate as essentially a one issue senator and not to have to worry about balancing the competing elements that go to constitute the national interest. It is one of those flaws in the proportional representation system that it throws up people who do not have to purport to govern and do not have to weigh the competing interests that go to making judgments about the national interest and bear the responsibility for those decisions. Apart from not having to turn up at the Parliament when it is not convenient, one also does not have to bear it in mind that sometimes foreign affairs, defence, industry and economic issues interrelate and that we need to look at them all and make a balanced and considered judgment.

SPEECH.PARA: When we peel away the rhetorical flourishes from this motion, it is not quite clear what it actually means, what it is saying should be the policy of the Government. Does it say-it is not quite clear to me-that Australia should not have any defence exports at all? That may well be what it says. It is probably the most logical interpretation of the words, although it does not actually say that. If that is the case-and it was not clear from the debate; listening to what people had said, particularly Senator Vallentine, I still was not sure-it seems to me illogical. I do not see why the world would be a safer place or war would be less likely if Australia-this is not inconsistent with what Senator Dunn was saying in the last few moments of her contribution-were to sell quite widely the minehunter catamarans that we are developing very successfully or the patrol boats which seem to contribute significantly to the defensive capacity of many nations, and not just in our region. In selling them in the short term we might make the world a safer and more peaceful place. We might wish nobody ever had to buy them.

If the world were a better place government would be easier and we could all adopt policies that would be more appealing to the people in Senator Vallentine's constituency, but it is hard to see why anyone would advocate that we should not sell minehunter catamarans or patrol boats but that we should continue to sell those things that are turned into weapons so often such as iron, steel and computers. Those who have a longer memory will recall the story about Malcolm's wool keeping the Russians warm at the time of the so-called trade boycott of the Soviet Union after its invasion of Afghanistan. Australia is contributing in a wide number of ways to the military endeavours of countries around the world, many of which, if we had our choice, we would oppose.

I am also somewhat perplexed about the part of the motion that implies that Australia used to refuse to be a member of what is so graphically called the `arms club'. Australia has never refused to be a part of that, if there is such a thing. Certainly, Australia has a long established tradition of arms exports. It is somewhat loosely controlled by byzantine and outdated regulations; nevertheless, the estimate by Bob Cooksey, the consultant who prepared a report on Australia's defence exports, was that our defence exports are currently worth $250m. But we have some restrictions. For example, it has been a part of the regulations that control defence exports that we cannot sell uniforms. I am sure that that is a very substantial contribution to world peace and that people around the world are calling off their coups and military interventions because we do not make our uniforms available! We need to maintain rigorous controls, bring those controls up to date, make sure that the principles for which this country has a proud record of standing, and certainly for which this Government stands, are maintained while maximising the defence, economic, and industrial benefits and the foreign affairs advantages for Australia.

It is very difficult, if not impossible, to name a country with the capacity to undertake arms exports which has more rigorous controls that those which have been introduced in Australia. Some people have on paper slightly more rigorous controls, but we all know that they are there just as a facade to cover very substantial arms exports to people who are not in conformity with that process. That has not been a problem in Australia, to our credit. I am optimistic. These improved, enhanced and simplistic controls should guarantee that it will not become a problem. We are establishing a more rational basis for maintaining the controls but we will not in the process lose the moral, the foreign affairs and the civil rights aspects.

It is quite clear from the new guidelines that Australia will not be exporting defence goods to countries subject to a United Nations Security Council embargo, or which are employing armed forces in a manner contrary to a resolution of the Security Council or international agreements to which Australia is a party. We will not be allowing exports of military equipment where that equipment may be used to suppress human rights and, of course, we will not be allowing private trafficking in arms. I think those views are shared by most people, if not by everybody in this House. I think it is fair to say only that they are held by most people, but I strongly support them, and they are a key part of the Government's policy.

What I glean from the sentiment of this motion, with which I do agree, is that we should not have exports at any price. The view was put by Bill Hayden when he was Foreign Minister-I think it is absolutely correct-that arms exports can be a source of revenue at a moral price which is not worth paying. Australia does not have a record to be ashamed of in that area, and nor should it, and nor should it develop such a policy.

In the area of chemical weapons-in which the Government is taking significant disarmament initiatives-Australia has a very well-developed chemical industry. If we did not have a government which had a rigorous policy and was not trying to build walls against people exporting chemical weapons but was actually going out and initiating a dialogue with Australian industry to get its support-to its credit, its very strong support-for a chemical weapons ban and working with it on the implications of a convention banning such weapons, we would start to see the permeation of a culture of the export of military material that was a source of very real and substantial moral and ethical problems. But I do not believe that those negatives apply.

I do not want to rely in my contribution to the debate merely on the double negative that certain things that are alleged are not likely to occur. I think one also has an obligation to look at the case for taking these initiatives. Essentially, it comes down to two principal arguments and some subsidiary points to which I wish to refer. Of course, the pre-eminent argument is the argument about the part of a defence industry in self-reliance-a fact that I would have thought was self-evident. Certainly, the evidence substantially supports the fact that we cannot have an Australian defence industry capable of meeting Australian demand if it is forced to survive solely on demand from within Australia. I do not understand why we are better off as a nation or why we are making a more substantial contribution to world peace if we have to import arms because our defence industry declines because it does not have an economic level of demand and therefore goes into recession and closes down and we have to import more arms than we now do in order to maintain Australia's defence capacity. This was the case previously with regard to shipbuilding in Australia. I cannot see how we made a more substantial contribution by running down our shipbuilding industry to such an extent that we were not capable of building our own ships.

It also makes a contribution to defence in another way in terms of the cost at which we can buy Australian produced equipment if we are able to have longer production runs and achieve economies of scale in the production of defence equipment in Australia. I do not accept that we are in any way better off because we have to pay more for Australia's defence to achieve the same standard of service and of equipment purchases. It is possible to argue that we should purchase A rather than B; I understand that argument. There is an argument about defence strategy that says, `You are strategically wrong; you could be buying different equipment for a different purpose'. That is a legitimate argument. But to say that we should allow the Australian defence industry to go into decline to the extent that it cannot provide the percentage of the Australian defence equipment requirement that it now does, or that it has to do so at a higher cost because it is operating at an uneconomic level, seems to me to fly in the face of the national interest. I think the self-reliance element of the capacity to sustain and develop an industry to provide Australia's defence requirements is the substantial argument in favour of the policy.

I think Australia also has to acknowledge, and those taking a broader and balanced view should recognise, that Australia has a vested interest in enhancing our regional security, in helping our friends in the region, particularly those who do not have any defence industry and who, I imagine, we and they, in terms of their economic interests, would prefer not to develop a defence industry but still to have a capacity, through the purchase of patrol boats and other things from us, to contribute to stability and security in the region. To reiterate a point made previously, I think the case for some of this activity is that some of the more defensive items provided by Australia and in some instances at the moment through the aid program and in a developing way commercially-I referred previously to the mine hunters and to the patrol boats-are making a contribution to a safer world by enhancing people's capacity to defend themselves in a way which they can afford and which can be effective.

That brings me to an important point about the provision of arms. It may well be that we all wish that nobody had any armed forces because it would be a lovely, peaceful world where everybody just shook hands with each other, but the United Nations has always recognised and, I believe, will always recognise the inherent right of nations for self-defence. Australia recognises this for itself, and we should recognise it for others. Armaments in themselves do not necessarily contribute to, nor undermine, the very high-minded and proper principles of the United Nations. It has always recognised the capacity and the need for people to have an inherent right to defend themselves. Australia's policy does not in any way change the limitation which has always applied to our sale of arms to nations which are using those arms to violate the rights of their citizens.

I find somewhat offensive the gratuitous Third World argument thrown into the motion-a sort of intellectual colonialism-that these poor people do not understand what is in their own interests and we, in the Senate, should lecture them so that they understand that they should not be buying these things from Australia; it is against their interests; it is a terrible thing. It is always necessary in a pseudo-progressive argument to shed a few crocodile tears for the Third World, but I think it is patronising bunk and intellectual colonialism.

In conclusion, I think Australia has a consistent and continuing commitment to disarmament and arms control. The policies of defence experts are in no way inconsistent with those principles; they are consistent with our objectives of self-reliance; of our support for the United Nations charter on human rights; and of our recognition of the inherent right of nations to defend themselves. It is a difficult balance, but that is what governments are about-balancing competing objectives. It is what distinguishes government parties from minorities that get elected with 3 or 4 per cent of the vote. Therefore, I urge the Senate to reject the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon the Senate is debating a motion on behalf of the peace movement from Senator Vallentine. I really wish that she would put some of the effort that she puts into the peace movement into basic grammar, because the first sentence in paragraph (a) is simply ungrammatical, quite apart from the fact that it is couched in very emotional language. Paragraph (b) puts the worst possible construction on defence. It just happens to be one of the most fundamental and important obligations of any government to defend its people. To run off with the rather hysterical construction that, because one is involved in defence one is visiting death and injury on a whole lot of innocent people, is to neglect to look at the consequences of what a negligent government visits upon its defenceless population when a usurping or invading army comes through. Of course, it denies the concept of deterrence, the concept on which the Western democracies have based their posture for the last 45 years-and a very successful posture it has been, because for 45 years we have enjoyed freedom from a major world war. So the concept works, whatever the peace movement might say about it. The final paragraph of the motion deals with the urgent need for the Government to reconsider its position.

SPEECH.PARA: I think I am reasonably alert to what the community is saying. Through you, Mr Deputy President, I can tell Senator Vallentine that I am not aware of any movement in the community protesting about the Government's actions. There were a few extremist groups, such as the Australian Council for Overseas Aid, the peace movement and all their subsets that operate in the community, at the time the legislation was talked about last year before it was introduced into the House of Representatives, but there certainly has been no reaction in the community. So it would be quite wrong to be talking about an urgent need arising from disquiet at the present policy of the Government.

Senator Newman said that Senator Vallentine's attack on the policy was based, to a very large degree, on supposition. Although the Government has made clear its intentions to liberalise the strict prohibitions that were on the supply of arms and armaments to other countries, at the moment we have only a press release-No. 99/88-of the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) which Senator Schacht read from in his address, and I believe that draft guidelines have been promulgated to industry on a confidential basis. I have not seen those guidelines and I think it is a fair assumption that neither has Senator Vallentine. So for her to mount a detailed attack on the grounds of supposition is a little unwise.

Her principal defence, though, was on the canard that we needed to sell defence equipment to other countries to resurrect our balance of payments, and that the balance of payments was in disarray and deficit purely because we were buying computers and new aircraft for the defence forces. Those propositions are absolutely false and Senator Vallentine knows it. We who are supporting this policy are not saying that at all. What we are saying is that it is desirable for Australia's own defence that we sell to other countries.

The other point on which Senator Vallentine and Senator Dunn placed some emphasis was the corruption in other countries in relation to arms sales. I say in passing that Senator Dunn needs to get another speech writer because if she can only go for seven minutes, reading a speech, she ought to steal some of Senator Vallentine's old papers and have them photocopied because she can read for 15 or 20 minutes when she has something to say.

The fact that many of the arms sales around the Third World countries have involved bribes is in no way necessarily a reflection on the integrity of the arms providers. The fact is that in almost all of those countries a standard of corruption is involved in the way that the Government does its business, whether it is buying food, wheat or arms. The evidence of bribery and corruption in getting arms sales contracts illustrates the way these countries do their business. Australia certainly will not get involved in that kind of activity but I stress the point that it is a symptom, not the cause.

Senator Vallentine also quoted at great length about the Swedes. If one nation on earth reeks of hypocrisy, duplicity and double dealing it is that country. It is a country which hosts peace movements and pacifist groups to a nauseating degree, yet it is as heavily involved in the provision of arms to other countries as it can be. It sells the arms, takes the money and runs. Sweden doublecrossed us at the time of Vietnam when it failed to support the Carl Gustav weapons system we bought from it. But Sweden was not alone in that. We had trouble with France and even with the Labour Government in the United Kingdom at the time until the then Prime Minister of Australia, John Gorton, took a very firm line with some of his opposite numbers in Britain and that position was turned around. The essential point to be learnt from that is that, as well as deterrence, Australia's defence must be based on self-reliance. We must be as independent as it is possible for us to be in our own defence capability. By generating our own defence manufacturing capability and by being able to sell that product overseas we add to our independence and thereby add to our national security.

Australia has a history of achievement in arms production. We did very little before the Second World War. Throughout the Second World War we came from nothing in a few short years and we produced everything-ships, tanks, aircraft and engines. After the Second World War the armaments industry moved into increasingly higher levels of technology and it became cost ineffective for Australia to produce with the small markets we had. The general level of military preparedness of the country, being quite low at the time, contributed to this.

Recently, under the Labor Government, we have seen a re-establishment of defence manufacturing in Australia. I applaud the Government for what it has done in that regard. However, it has not thought it through very carefully. I will just give one example of that. The big cost in setting up industries is the establishment cost. We put a lot of money into the Maribyrnong facility in Melbourne to build the 105 millimetre guns for the Army. Instead of continuing the production line to supply weapons and artillery to the Reserve, as was originally contracted, it was discontinued at the end of last year. So, after the very high cost of establishing the production line for a short run, it has been chopped. Mr Beazley and the Australian Labor Party, while they are busy setting up these industries, ought to realise that continuity is the key to them. We are much better off buying 10 weapons a year for 10 years rather than 100 in one year and having the place close down.

At present the trade in defence equipment that Australia involves itself in is absolutely minuscule. The best figures I can get relate to 1986. In aggregate about $250m is involved, which is just peanuts. The great part of that goes to our close allies. I presume-I have not seen the figures-it relates to things such as barra sonar buoys, jindiviks and ikaras, which are rather large items and now rather old equipment. However, they are still in service with some of our close friends. The regional trade that we are involved with is absolutely minuscule. I hope that the projections that the Government makes of being able to double that in a period of three to five years come true because this is a matter of great importance to Australia.

As you know, Mr Deputy President, I have always argued in the 11 years that I have been in the Parliament that Australia should expand its own resources for the production of its defence requirements. When I first came into this place I had a look at the production of ammunition by the Australian facilities in Melbourne and Sydney. At the time there was a good market in South East Asia for ammunition. That is no reference to the Vietnam War as that had just been completed. But service ammunition requires very close quality assurance procedures. Very precise loads and combustion characteristics are required for automatic weapons. Not all nations can do that. We had those facilities in place. I found that the reason why Australia could not sell small arms ammunition was simply the fact that we did not have a ship. So many requirements on loading precautions have to be met that a dedicated ship is needed. It does not have to be very large. But because we did not have a ship to take ammunition around South East Asia commercially, other than a Navy vessel, we simply could not get into the market. Of course, it is old history now that Singapore set up its own production facilities and has scooped the pool.

The biggest reason for developing our own industry is that we in Australia and in South East Asia, which is our presumptive area of operations, live in a peculiar environment. All the equipment which is produced for the Western democracies is optimised for the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO) theatre, which is a cool temperate climate. It is an intensive, competitive climate from a technological point of view and requires the leading edge of technology. On the other hand, in Australia we are dealing with very much higher temperatures and humidities and the nature of the competition is not necessarily as high. I always argued that there is great scope in many directions for Australia to be developing its own weapons systems and platforms which are appropriate for the region and selling them to the South East Asia region. It is important that we involve the South East Asian countries in our defence because the threats to Australia come not from them but through them. It is very much in our interest to maintain friendly co-operative programs and to have strong countries to the north of us.

To return to the environmental considerations, you, Mr Deputy President, would remember well that when the Americans went to Vietnam some of their air to air missiles had a high failure rate simply because they were optimised for a cooler climate in the NATO European theatre. When the missiles were exposed to the high humidities and temperatures of Vietnam they simply did not work. In our own case, if one looks at Darwin the temperature today, I suppose, is 34 to 36 degrees on the ground. A missile sitting on an aircraft in Darwin is cooking off inside at a very much higher temperature. Within a few minutes, when the aircraft climbs to 40,000 feet over the city of Darwin-one of the geographical peculiarities of Darwin is that one of the biggest pools of very cold air sits at altitudes over that town right in the tropics-the environmental change is enormous and it is significant for us. There are numerous comparisons that can be made on equipment. If one looks at the whole of the electronics field, at radar propagation in tropical areas, there are special skills and characteristics for us to develop which are relevant to the region. If Australia is to be a supplier we should develop the industries and skills that are of national importance to us. Honourable senators should always remember that most of the advantages in modern communities come from the defence industries. They never come from the peace movement, most members of which demonstrate that they cannot even write a grammatical sentence. They are a spin-off from the high technology defence industries which have done so much to improve the quality of life of countries.

I hope that we do get into this business of supplying defence equipment to our neighbours because it strengthens them and strengthens us. I hope that we can make money out of it. One of the tragedies of the present situation is that we do not have enough money in defence. I talked about the 105 millimetre weapons before. We do not have any ammunition for them because we do not manufacture it. We put a lot of money into pavetack, a multimillion dollar upgrading program for the F111s; yet the Government will not buy any GBU15 precision-guided weapons so that we can exploit this capability. The defence industry is an essential part of Australia's defence capability and, as such, I totally reject the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

Senator Newman, unfortunately, could only make a personal attack. She had no arguments to advance an Opposition point of view except to say that the Opposition wants more government assistance to Australian defence exporters. I will not retaliate in Senator Newman's vein as I think it degrades the whole argument and the debate in this place to make such personal attacks.

As Senator McLean pointed out so aptly, the Government and the Opposition are becoming increasingly similar to each other on many issues, including this one. They both want to push further militarisation in order to make dollars. It is no wonder the electorate is so disillusioned with both major parties. We see evidence of that increasingly in this place.

Senator McMullan started off with another personal attack. I could do without them, but I do not get particularly upset. It is just a waste of the Senate's time. We should be debating the issues and not personalities. I believe that we will be allowing defence exports-in contradiction to what Senator McMullan said-to those countries which have bad human rights records, as I have pointed out. As I have mentioned, the mission went to Indonesia, the Philippines, Thailand and Singapore. Those are the very countries to which we constantly make submissions on human rights cases. That reflects the absolute contradiction in the Government's position and the absolute hypocrisy.

Senator Dunn pointed out very ably that we would not be a new player in the international arms club; rather, we would be increasing the stakes. Unfortunately, we have been part of it for a very long time. Perhaps I should have been clearer by saying that the report of the Cooksey Review of Australia's Defence Cooperation Programs and Policy on Export of Defence Equipment, on which this whole issue is based, recommended a doubling of Australia's arms exports. We have been in it for quite a long time, to the mutual regret of both Senator Dunn and me.

Senator MacGibbon made a further personal attack which I will not bother to refute. There was a very patronising put down of what he called the peace movement and he included the Australian Council for Overseas Aid as an extremist group. It will be interested indeed to hear that. The council reflects the views of hundreds of thousands of Australians who want to share the world's resources in order to build a more peaceful international climate.

Senators Newman and MacGibbon made much of the use of the word `guidelines' in my motion. I was referring to the key defence export policy changes which Senator Schacht read into the debate. Both honourable senators missed hearing me say during the debate that detailed guidelines were not available.

The disarmament development link probably has not been absorbed or understood by the Opposition, but I thought it had been understood by the Government. Some of its members have understood the utter hypocrisy of pushing arms sales. For example, John Langmore, the member for Fraser, wrote to the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) and said that he was disappointed and very sad that a Labor government had decided to build a larger stall in the world's arms bazaar. He is reported as saying:
If morality has any place in foreign policy then this is a doubtful thing to be doing . . .
There could be a world-wide reduction in arms and yet we will be trying to get countries which can least afford it to buy Australian-made weapons.

I wonder how many Government members and senators will have the guts to stand up for their own principles and what ought to be the principles of their Party in this matter. It must be very embarrassing for good and principled people in the Australian Labor Party to witness the hypocrisy of our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on the world stage while at home his Defence Minister-the benign, affable-looking Mr Beazley-is getting Australia further and further into the horrible business of flogging weapons overseas as fast as possible. We do not have to go down that path. It is morally indefensible under any circumstances to try to trade our way out of our deficit by flogging military equipment. Thankfully, there is no guarantee that it will be as economically viable as the Government and the Opposition seem to think. I commend the motion to the Senate.

That the motion (Senator Vallentine's) be agreed to.

DEBATE.TITLE: GREAT BARRIER REEF MARINE PARK AUTHORITY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The annual report of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority 1987-1988 gives us the opportunity to raise briefly a couple of matters which have been of concern both to the Marine Park Authority and to people concerned with the status and preservation of the Great Barrier Reef. The Opposition congratulates members of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority for the excellent work the Authority does. The members of the Authority-the Chairman, Mr Graeme Kelleher, Sir Sydney Schubert and Dr Joe Baker-are all distinguished leaders in their field. The Australian community is fortunate to have them as members of the Authority.

As you would know, Mr Deputy President, there has been some debate during this year about the problems of the crown of thorns starfish. Some hysterical and untrue claims have been made by a large number of people in this regard and, indeed, by some television programs, at least one of which I thought was remarkably disingenuous and, frankly quite dishonest. The television program 60 Minutes substantially misrepresented the extent of crown of thorns infestation and substantially understated the work which was being done towards its control.

There are four sections of the reef: the far northern section, the Cairns section, the central section and the Mackay-Capricorn section. The proportion of the reef affected by the crown of thorns starfish is as follows: the far northern area, approximately 4.2 per cent; the Cairns area, 58.2 per cent; the central area, 34.8 per cent; and the Mackay-Capricorn area, 13.5 per cent. I believe that the Authority is doing all that it can at the moment to undertake control programs and to minimise damage by the crown of thorns infestation. The ill-chosen comments in a number of journals, television and other media reports have not portrayed a proper understanding either of the cause of the infestation-that is, the actual nature of the crown of thorns infestation-or of what is being done to combat it.

I was pleased to hear about the recently announced decision by the Federal and Queensland Governments to impose a two-year ban on floating hotel developments on the Great Barrier Reef. Further work will be done to assess the impact of the existing hotel and similar developments on the reef. It is important that that moratorium be imposed while that assessment is under way.

I would like to know whether the Authority, under pressure from the Government, the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) and the Department of Finance, in terms of cost recovery policies, will move to a user pays principle for tourist operators on the reef. This matter will have to be dealt with very carefully. As the report says:

. . . the commitment of users of the Marine Park to its protection may be undermined if fees are introduced, or applied, in a way that appears unreasonable or unfair. Resolution of these issues may well be the most important and difficult task for the Authority in the coming years.

I certainly agree with that. I am sure that the tourist operators have made representations to both sides of the Parliament about the imposition of user-pays fees on people who visit the reef. Those fees would be passed on to the travellers and tourists. I think it would be a great shame if the commitment to the preservation of the reef, which I know is shared by virtually all Australians, were undermined by an attempt to commercialise visits to the reef in a way which might cause some disharmony and which, as the report points out, might undermine the commitment of users of the marine park to its protection. This is an area that we will watch with some degree of interest, raising it in the appropriate forums, both in the Estimates committees and in debates in the Senate. In the meantime, however, I conclude by taking this opportunity to pay tribute once again to the work which the Marine Park Authority is doing and to indicate my support for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Great Barrier Reef is one of Australia's most priceless assets and is listed on the World Heritage List. Unfortunately, it is not being protected.
—Have you been there?

—Yes, I have been there. The Great Barrier Reef Marine Park was first talked about in the early 1980s. On 31 August 1983, while announcing that the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park would be extended to cover 80 per cent of the reef region, the then Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, Mr Cohen, said it was Government policy that the marine park should extend to the western boundary of the region on the Queensland mainland coast where that was necessary to protect areas of ecological significance. However, when the final two stages of the marine park were proclaimed, on 30 October 1983, some 26 inshore areas were excluded by the marine park boundary being established five kilometres off shore. The Federal Government said that that would alleviate unnecessary restrictions on local authorities and would involve less administrative work but, in fact, the 26 exclusion zones reflected the Queensland Government's interests in potentially developing these areas for port sites or as tourist resorts and its unwillingness to have the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority (GBRMPA) exert any direct control over such activities.

SPEECH.PARA: That took place quite a while back. What is happening now? At this moment $1 billion worth of development proposals are under consideration in areas of the Great Barrier Reef which have World Heritage status but which are not listed under the legislation. Why are they not listed? It is because the Federal Government is gutless. It does not want to tangle with the rip-off artists of Queensland. The projects under way are massive. One of them is a $10m re-development of the Great Keppel Island resort which is owned by Australian Airlines. The Queensland Cabinet recently approved plans at the existing resort on Lindeman Island in the Whitsundays to develop a golf course on 60 hectares of national park. Only in Queensland would that happen. On Wild Duck Island naturalists fear that a $125m resort to be built soon could lead to the destruction of one of the world's largest nesting colonies of the endangered flat back turtle. A $1m hotel and resort complex planned by Interwest Ltd on Magnetic Island off Townsville has run into a storm of local protest. But what are the local people to do? We know that in Queensland local protests often end in arrest and very little else. Earthworks have started on Dent Island for a golf course to service the adjacent Hamilton Island resort. Other World Heritage listed islands on which resorts or extensions are proposed include Keswick, Long, Hummock Hill, Daydream and St Bees.

The Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, the annual report of which we are discussing, has no jurisdiction over this land above the low water mark. Even when developments affect the marine environment, GBRMPA's powers are limited. They do not need to be, but they are. Hamilton Island continues to be a sore on the Great Barrier Reef. It continues to discharge raw sewage into the sea, even though the construction of a treatment plant has been a condition of licence issued by the Water Quality Council since 1985. Although the resort was directed to comply with the condition last May, the plant has still not been completed.

So what are we to do? We should ask our Government to do something to save this national treasure. So far it has been reluctant to lock horns with the Queensland Government for reasons that I simply do not understand. I think the Federal Government has the power-it certainly has the constitutional power, as has been shown in the Franklin Dam case-to protect this area, but it simply does not want to do it. I think it is time that the Hawke Government developed enough guts to save what is basically a priceless asset for the rest of the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hate to disagree with my colleague Senator Sanders in relation to Queensland being the only State in which developments such as golf courses can occur in national parks. You would know, Mr Acting Deputy President, that in South Australia the South Australian Government at this very time is attempting to establish an 18-hole golf course in the Flinders Ranges National Park at Wilpena Pound and is considering other developments on Kangaroo Island. I am afraid that in this respect we have a rather poor government in South Australia at present. What both previous speakers have said indicates the conflict which arises between the national park values and the problems of tourism.

SPEECH.PARA: The report of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority itself draws attention to the substantial additions which have occurred to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park recently, with the Mackay-Capricorn section extending a further 66 per cent to the area of the park. The report also draws attention to the main goal of the Marine Park Authority, which is:
. . . the protection, wise use, understanding and enjoyment of the Great Barrier Reef in perpetuity through the development and care of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park.

I draw attention to the term `in perpetuity' because it seems to me that what we are seeing, and the matters to which Senator Sanders has drawn attention, are threatening that protection in perpetuity. I also draw attention to the conflict between the idea of development and care on the one hand and protection in perpetuity on the other.

The Marine Park Authority has subsidiary roles to minimise regulation of and interference in human activities consistent with meeting the main goal and other aims of the Authority and to provide for economic development. Yet we find repeatedly that those aims-the economic development and the reduction of regulatory measures on the use of the reef-are in direct conflict with the aim of protecting the reef in perpetuity. Indeed, early in the report the precarious balance between development on the one hand and protection of the environment on the other is drawn to our attention. The report states:

Whenever there is an event in the marine park that adversely affects the environment there are demands that regulations should be tightened. At the same time other sectors of the population demand deregulation.

The report also draws attention to the fact that the staff-visitor day ratios have declined very substantially in recent years from 1 : 5,200 in 1980-81 to 1 : 44,000 in 1987-88. Increasingly there are fewer staff to supervise adequately the problems of damage to the park. The report also draws attention to the problems which might be overcome by revenue raising in the marine park. While in this instance I would certainly encourage the charging of commercial operators on the Great Barrier Reef, I would hope that we would not get to a situation in which ordinary visitors to the reef were charged to visit in a private capacity one of the great wonders of the world.

In relation to commercial developments on the reef, there is an interesting account in the report dealing with the Fantasy Island development which was a concrete, doughnut shaped pontoon designed as a day trip reef destination by Reeflink Pty Ltd, owned by Mr Doug Tarca. It was intended to replace a string of steel pontoons. The report states that on 30 March 1988, a week after being put into operation, Fantasy Island sank and subsequently parts of the structure broke up. Mr Tarca has been asked to remove the wreckage at no cost to the Commonwealth. I point out that unless a charge is made before these structures are put in place and the money is paid into a fund, the Commonwealth and the Queensland Government jointly with the Marine Park Authority could find themselves in a situation where they would have to clean up the damage resulting from this sort of development. That is something to which attention needs to be given. The report also draws attention to a number of proposals under consideration-a floating hotel at Fitzroy Reef, a marina at Nelly Bay, Magnetic Island, a pontoon at Masthead Island Reef, and a marina at Shute Harbour-and clearly indicates that the reef is under considerable commercial exploitation pressure.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL PARKS AND WILDLIFE SERVICE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The annual report of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service is an interesting one this year, bearing on its cover, both front and back, a picture of a giant panda, which I suppose simply draws attention to the fact that these days one can sell almost anything provided that it has a panda on it. It is a serious attempt, however, by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service to draw attention to the problems of the protection of endangered species. As honourable senators will know, during 1988 two giant pandas were on display in Australia. They created a great deal of what was commercially referred to as `pandamonium' around the place, and attracted huge numbers of people to see these animals. The disappointing thing in some respects is that it is a great deal easier for Australians to get agitated about the fate of somebody else's endangered species than it is for them to get agitated about the fate of endangered species within Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like kangaroos.

—On this occasion I am not referring to the Australian Democrats. The general problem of the very large number of animals in Australia, particularly the small marsupials, is not well recognised. It is a pity that there is not more active involvement of many of the organisations which are happy to promote events such as the panda visit to make more of the fact that we are losing large numbers of significant Australian species in all areas of the continent and that not enough is being done about it.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point I wish to make on the problem of endangered species is that, although many people believe in protecting endangered species, they have no difficulty when they are overseas in buying pieces of ivory, for example, and bringing them into the country. They do not realise the contribution that they are making to the elimination of another of the great species of the world, the elephant, by simply trading in and purchasing ivory, despite the fact that legislation prohibits the importation into Australia, as indeed it should, of products derived from endangered species. One sees from page 35 of the report that the largest single item of goods seized as being illegally imported into this country related to elephant products.

The report covers a huge variety of issues, all of which are comprehended in the work of the Australian Parks and Wildlife Service, a service which I believe has been unnecessarily starved of funds by this Government and which, with the limited funds available to it, does a most outstanding job. Under the heading `Australian Alps National Park Memorandum of Understanding', the report says in part:

On 4 July 1986, four Ministers of the Commonwealth, Victoria and New South Wales responsible for nature conservation signed a Memorandum of Understanding on the Co-operative Management of the Alps Parks.

The State of New South Wales has, under the leadership of Tim Moore, the Minister for Environment in that State, proposed an examination for possible World Heritage listing of the Alpine Parks region of New South Wales. I draw attention to this item because it indicates the extent to which cooperative endeavour between the Commonwealth and the States can lead to significant areas of cooperation in wildlife management and protection of the environment, the creation of national parks, the preservation of the wilderness, and nomination for World Heritage areas, without all these matters becoming matters of permanent confrontation. That is one of the interesting things in this excellent report. I commend it to honourable senators as a document that contains a wealth of information. It is a great tribute to the people who work in the Parks and Wildlife Service. I wish to indicate the Opposition's support for the Service and for its work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been interested to read the annual report of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service 1987-88 because of the Australian Democrats' commitment to the conservation of natural environment and our concern for endangered species. Like Senator Puplick, I was very interested to see the section on endangered species on page 3 of the report, where we read:

SPEECH.PARA: Considerable progress was made this year towards the implementation of an Endangered Species Program comprising an Endangered Species Advisory Committee and an Endangered Species Unit.

Last month in Adelaide I had the good fortune to meet a dedicated expert in this field, Dr John Walmsley of the Warrawong sanctuary, a private wildlife park which I believe to be one of the most important and successful projects of this kind in Australia.

Dr Walmsley has collected and bred a substantial population of Australian small native animals which are not only endangered in their natural habitat but some of which are generally believed to be extinct. If honourable senators, including Senator Puplick, and members of the public want to see what sort of wildlife abounded on this continent just 200 years ago, before European habitation, they can see a rare selection of these animals at the Warrawong sanctuary. Besides the familiar kangaroos and wallabies, some of these animals are: the pademelons, small browsers which feed on native grasses and underbrush and, therefore, in times past saved the bush from big fires; and bettongs, which are small wallabies, the former staple diet of the Aborigines rather than the larger kangaroos. Dr Walmsley has about 250 bettongs in his sanctuary, about half the population of the animals left in Australia. There are potoroos, a small primitive member of the kangaroo family. There are also bandicoots, possums and quolls. Quolls are native cats which Dr Walmsley has there to keep the population down to size in a natural way. The Tamar wallaby and the redneck wallaby are other rare species to be found at the Warrawong sanctuary.

Dr Walmsley told me of his high regard for the work of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, which has assisted him in introducing a small colony of platypuses to a specially made blackwater lake at the sanctuary. Platypuses have a very short life in zoo captivity, but at Warrawong they have survived and adjusted for just over a year, which I believe is something of a triumph. It is also interesting that Dr Walmsley has designed a retaining wire fence which keeps out foxes and feral cats. As everyone knows, we have such a small number of native animals left in Australia because of the feral animals which have been introduced since we have been here. This fence is easy to erect, is very economical compared to other types of fences and, I am sure, would be of interest to the proposed advisory committee on endangered species.

I cannot praise the sanctuary highly enough. It has won all sorts of prizes and awards. It has won a tree care award, tourism awards, heritage and culture awards, an award from the Small Business Corporation of South Australia, and many others. People can explore the sanctuary in the day time. They can also go there at night to see the small animals coming out to feed in their natural environment. They can also see rare and unusual plants and shrubs which are no longer easily seen in our urban areas. We are concerned about endangered species in other countries, but first and foremost we must look after our endangered species in this country. I believe that sanctuaries such as that run by Dr Walmsley can fill that function very well indeed. I hope that other States also will follow suit with sanctuaries of this kind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak briefly on the annual report of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service. I am a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, which has been looking at annual reports and commenting on their worth. This particular report is an exceptionally good report because it covers the wide range of services that the National Parks and Wildlife Service provides. That body's budget is not insignificant. Something like $12m is spent all over Australia on various national parks.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer, in particular, to that part of the report which contains reference to the Tasmanian World Heritage area, especially the Cradle Mountain Lake St Clair National Park Management Plan that is being formulated with cooperation between the Commonwealth and State Governments. There is reference in the report to that plan and it is very interesting to note that the State Government, the Gray Government, which is often criticised for its approach to the environment, is actively engaged with the Commonwealth Government in doing something very positive and something that is very good for our State. It is easy to see what can be achieved when the political point scoring is left out of a situation.

I understand that the management plan will be tabled in State Parliament in the very near future. The main thrust of the report is to make recommendations on the future use of the park, wilderness retention and the provision of recreation areas. One highlight is that the development will be limited to the park boundary only, which will allow something like 133,000 hectares to be set aside purely for wilderness purposes. In that park, the important wilderness areas will be protected, but recreational day walk tracks will also be provided, and the very famous overland track to Lake St Clair will be retained.

The State and Federal governments are jointly funding a new visitors centre which will be completed in November this year. That will provide a wonderful entrance to this world-acclaimed national park. Tourists visiting the park and students of our local flora and fauna will be able to study what is being preserved in the park. I refer to the rainforest, glaciation and the unique botany of the alpine and subalpine areas.

Another part of the report refers to the management plan of the World Heritage area which is being made with the cooperation of the Commonwealth and the State Governments. As I said earlier, when political point scoring is left out of it, things can be achieved. I compliment the Gray Government for its record on the environment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, God!

—It has been much criticised, but some industries lately being criticised for causing pollution at Burnie and on the River Derwent were brought in under a Labor government, not a Liberal government. At the moment, the different companies are carrying out significant works on the Derwent River. It is all very well for Senator Sanders to interject from the left. He would not even know what is going on in Tasmania now because he makes only very brief visits to Tasmania. I can tell him of my own experience as an oyster farmer on the Derwent River. We were polluted out by chemical pollution from the zinc works, but the Liberal Government in Tasmania forced environmental controls on the zinc works.
—Would you go swimming in the Derwent River?

—I inform Senator Sanders that from the surveys that have been taken it has been found that the water in the area that was heavily polluted with minerals is virtually at the stage where oysters can be grown again. The honourable senator would know that oysters are among the best filters of minerals.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

—I point out my concern that it looks like the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories is gunning for the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service. It is undertaking a review of the Service. It is obviously concerned about the independent role of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service and it looks as though it might be seeking to have more control over the Service's activities. I would be very sad if the dead hand of the bureaucrats of Canberra actually could extend into the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service and limit it in the valuable function it performs. The State equivalents of that body are simply not capable of resisting the developers in their various jurisdictions. The Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service has a better record, but what is needed is a country rather than a collection of six petulant States--
