SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wanted to make some comment on the fifteenth report of the Committee of Privileges, but I have come direct from a meeting and do not have a copy with me. I will make some preliminary remarks while waiting for a copy. The report arises from a matter which was brought forward by Senator MacGibbon, who raised as a matter of privilege the matter of certain answers which had been given by an officer of the Department of Defence to the Estimates Committee of which he was part. The report incorporates as an attachment the Hansard of that Estimates Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: It is quite clear that a number of senators were disturbed by the nature of the answers which were being given by that witness from the Defence Department. Even a casual reading of the Hansard at the Estimates Committee shows that the answers were, on their face, quite unsatisfactory. As a result, the matter was sent off by the Senate after we had gone through the usual procedures, the matter having been considered by the President in the normal way.

Whilst the report does not find that there was a breach of privilege, it is important to note the very careful way in which the Committee addressed the unsatisfactory answers which had been given. I do not believe that any of the public servants who appear before the Estimates Committees should be under any illusions about the concern there is within the Senate about the importance of having accurate, honest and straightforward responses to the questions which are put. The report ought to be almost compulsory reading for those many public servants who are called upon to appear before the Estimates Committees. I now have the report and thank the attendant for having chased it up for me.
The report notes comments which were made by Dr McIntosh in his submission to the Privileges Committee of 2 February. He said:

While the discussions of the project were of a partial nature so as not to preempt Ministers and were clearly unsatisfactory to Senators, I do not believe that false or misleading evidence was given by what I said (as opposed to the paraphrasing by others of what I said) as to the facts or status of the project.

If Senators were misled, it was certainly not deliberate on my part and I can only apologise for any deficiencies in the phrasing of my responses, which did not make the position, as outlined in this submission, sufficiently clear.
When one looks at the Committee's conclusion, it having heard the evidence, looked at the transcript and so on, it is important to note that the Committee found:
It would have been helpful to the Senators concerned if the officer had been more forthcoming . . .

But the Committee accepted the explanation and apology contained in the submission. The Committee went on to make observations which, as I say, ought to be drawn to the attention of all public servants appearing before Estimates committees. It stated:

The submissions of Dr McIntosh and Major General Francis have presented the factual background at the time of the Estimates hearings and technically the answers that were given to the Committee were correct.
In paragraph 7 the Committee went on to say:

We appreciate the problem faced by public servants in the position of Dr McIntosh at the time of the hearings, but it is fair comment that he was an experienced public servant and quite familiar with dealing with Ministers and Members of Parliament. He should have been able to overcome the problem without leaving the Senators in the state of dissatisfaction which was created by his unhelpful approach.
Paragraph 8 states:

Although public servants should not be pre-empting the decisions of Ministers or disclosing advice given to them, there is no reason why information should not be volunteered when it is quite clear that Senators are seeking more information than has been made available or if they seem confused by such information. In this case there had been news reports which had given Senators some inaccurate information about the situation with Project Parakeet. Senators may also have been given inaccurate information from other sources.
Penultimately, paragraph 9 states:
If Dr McIntosh had been as helpful to the Senate Estimates Committee as he has been to the Privileges Committee this whole exercise would have been avoided.

While the Committee concluded that `there was no intention to give any false or misleading evidence to a Senate Estimates Committee in relation to the Department of Defence project' it follows that there was no contempt. However, I want to say that it is quite clear, on a reading of that report and on a reading of the Senate Hansard, that Dr McIntosh's evidence was clearly unsatisfactory and was not given in a way which was designed to meet the objective of the Estimates Committee, which is to place before the people of Australia the information which their duly elected representatives believe is properly required.

It is a fundamental role of the Parliament to examine and to disclose matters which are the public's property, because the public, after all, is paying for all this. The programs administered by public servants are public property because they are carried out on behalf of the people of Australia and are paid for by the people of Australia. In conversations I have had with honourable senators who have been on Estimates committees over a long period-and I have relatively limited experience of Estimates committees compared with many honourable senators in this place-it is clear that this sort of prevarication and inadequate response is not unique. I hope that this reference to the Privileges Committee and the cautions which are contained in that Committee's report, will ensure that we do not face the sort of obfuscation that I believe we faced in the particular Estimates Committee consideration which went before the Privileges Committee.

I do not believe that the record, as it has finally been produced by the Committee of Privileges, shows a situation that is in any way satisfactory to the Senate. More importantly, I do not believe that it is satisfactory to the people of Australia. I have little doubt that if honourable senators find there is similar obfuscation by public servants and Ministers in future, they will object to it and take appropriate action to ensure that that situation does not continue. I do not think anyone else wishes to speak on the report now so I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

It also received submissions from older immigrants who were concerned about their level of knowledge and understanding of the system of government. They were interested in finding out how they could be involved in community participation. The Committee became very concerned, as it went through the submissions and as it heard evidence from various groups-school children, youth organisations, individuals in the community, teachers, people in tertiary education-about the lack of knowledge and understanding as well as the ignorance, apathy and sense of powerlessness of many of these people.

It is well for us to note that a survey undertaken in 1987 showed that only 54 per cent of Australians knew that Australia had a Constitution. In the 18-24 age-group, only about 30 per cent of Australians were aware of the Constitution's existence. As some commentators noted-and the report points this out-following the 1988 referendum, there was a certain incongruity in proposing amendments to the Australian Constitution when about half of the population does not even know that it exists.

A number of surveys were presented to us-some undertaken by school children themselves amongst their own peers; others by students entering tertiary institutions. These surveys painted a similar picture. One example was a study commissioned by the Australian Electoral Commission shortly after the December 1984 Federal election. When responding to the question, `Federal Parliament is made up of two Houses. To the best of your knowledge what are their names?', 64 per cent of those surveyed named the House of Representatives and 60 per cent named the Senate. About one in five were unable to name either of the Houses of the Federal Parliament.

We all know that being able to name the Houses of Parliament is not necessarily indicative of people's understanding of the functions, but one would imagine that, if one did not know the names, one would be even less likely to understand the functions. The evidence concerning levels of knowledge of State government also appeared to be scarce. A 1987 study by the Armidale College of Advanced Education of teacher education students at that institution found that only three of the 154 students surveyed could name both of the New South Wales Houses of Parliament; only four more could name one House.

The Committee found that people's knowledge and understanding of local government was about the same-abysmal. The Committee was concerned, not only with people's understanding of the structure and function of the political system, but also how they could participate in decision-making at a local, State and Federal level.

We were privileged that the first group to appear before the Committee in this Parliament was a group of students. I found it interesting that the young people presented submissions which were outstanding, exciting, interesting and challenging. However, I could say the same for the presentations of some of my peers. It was interesting to note that the students, in fact, put their finger on one of the problems that was highlighted throughout our inquiry. At page 36 the report states:
Students seem conscious that teaching of this kind has a lot to do with inadequate training.
The Committee was referring here to the teaching of politics in schools, and the teaching of politics in general. One student from Hollywood High said:

. . . it comes back to the way that teachers are trained. Some teachers are not trained well enough to give practical examples or bring out issues that are happening at the moment. They can just teach from text books and that is all.

That comment interested me. Some of the text books which are produced and used in high schools are, in fact, very bookish. I asked a number of people from colleges of advanced education (CAEs) whether they used primary sources. I was a little stunned to find that very few of these people were able to answer in the affirmative. The very informative and important articles that are produced by people such as the Clerks of the Senate, or staff of our committees, are unread by the people who actually teach. Some of those papers tell us about the characters in the Senate. One written by Peter O'Keefe tells us about Ian Wood and his commitment to the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances over a period of 23 years, having been Chairman of that Committee. It puts flesh on the bones of the information that these tertiary educators would do well to read. It behoves those who are politicians to make sure that that material is available and referred to, that we speak of it in schools, to tertiary students and to tertiary educators and that we encourage the staff of the Parliament to ensure that it appears in educators' journals and that reference is made to it so that that very important material is not lost to a group that ought to be reading it.

We were also heartened to see the work that was being done by a number of youth groups such as the Young Men's Christian Association, the Girl Guides and the Girls Brigade. These groups were presenting programs and involving young people in decision making. Organisations which some may see as fairly conservative are actually giving young people a greater opportunity to participate and to learn about democracy, decision making, and being involved in their own destiny, and are encouraging them to understand and to know about the political system through their own programs.

The report goes on to talk about the importance of citizenship. Especially in this year of citizenship, I believe that we should be taking note of the Committee's recommendations. The Committee emphasised in the report that great significance is placed on immigrants taking out citizenship but little importance is placed on attaining the status of an enrolled voter in Australia. The Committee asked that more emphasis be given to placing importance on new enrollees, so that they see enrolment as a privilege and are informed about the process through material that could be sent out to them. The Committee did not want to specify but left the matter open, possibly for the Australian Electoral Commission to develop ways of making people feel that becoming a voter was a very important aspect of playing a role in Australian society.

The report serves as a reminder that voting is the responsibility of everybody, including politicians. I hope that in this situation we can be more parliamentarians than politicians. It is our role to tell the community about the structure and function of Parliament, especially Federal Parliament. It is the parliamentarians' role at State and Federal level and the responsibility of local councils and the staff of government bodies at all levels to inform the community. It is a role that the staff of the Parliament have played very well. Educators, youth organisations and the media should be encouraged. When the Regulations and Ordinances Committee wins a battle we do not see the media shouting from the rooftop, `Another blow for freedom'. This report serves as a warning to Australians as to the fragility of our democracy and the measures we can take to ensure its continuity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beahan Sen M.E. .

TALK.START.PARA: —I have pleasure in supporting the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training and the recommendations included therein. In so doing, I want to make a few points. It is not surprising, but I think it is a pity, that the media attention throughout the progress of this report-and it has gone on now for some time-has focused on the negative aspects of the report. As Senator Patterson has already pointed out, there are some good examples in the report of research indicating a worrying level of ignorance on the part of students, teachers and the community at large about the political process in general, not simply about the Parliament. While that is of concern, I think we ought now to concentrate more on the positives, which can take two forms.

SPEECH.PARA: Some positive things are already happening. Senator Patterson has already drawn attention to the very positive contribution that was made by young people in appearing before the Committee. Two schools in particular sent delegations along, having put in written submissions-Trinity Senior High School in Wagga Wagga and Hollywood Senior High School in Perth. If I may be parochial, I would like to praise the very articulate team of advocates from Hollywood High School: Adam Bandt, Amanda Bower, Mitchell Henville, Bronwyn Morris, Lisa Roberts, Natalie Silver and Anna Takac and their very dedicated and creative teacher, Chris Hill. They were doing promising things that showed that achievements can be made. They were not typical children in the sense that they had chosen to do political studies, and I guess they were more than averagely articulate, but they were a very good example of what can be achieved if we really try. They had, in my view, a very good understanding of the processes.

We also need to concentrate on the recommendations of the report, which are very moderate and non-costly-as Senator Peter Walsh will be very pleased to know-and give some direction to the sorts of things that we learned. I am appalled at the view expressed by an article in the Sydney Morning Herald quoted on page 7 of the report. It was written by an academic. The report states:

. . . the Sydney Morning Herald published an article entitled `Political ignorance is bliss' which questioned the need for any investigation of the topic . . . the article argued that, having perceived the gap between democratic theory and political practice, Australians had rightly chosen to respond with `a combination of ignorance, apathy and cynicism'. Political ignorance, it was claimed, is a `valuable part of our national heritage'.

That is all very funny and cynical. It is dead easy for people to express that point of view and I guess they will get a laugh from it, but the Committee-I think rightly-rejected it out of hand. It rejected it not only because of its general view that an informed and aware society-an intellectual, alert and flexible society-is infinitely better than a society that is based on ignorance and intellectual rigidity, but also for a number of other, much more practical reasons. In that generalised sense of a society being better if it is informed, I think we have seen some good examples of what an uninformed, ignorant, inflexible society can do. The Salman Rushdie affair in Iran is a good example of what can happen when ignorance rises to the level of almost being an institution.

I do not want to make a political point here, but the level at which the recent referendum questions were argued was abysmal. The example was set here, but it was developed further in the community. I was, frankly, appalled by some of the questions that were seriously put to me to answer. Senator Patterson has already drawn attention to the fact that the Committee report refers to a commentator who noted in regard to the 1988 referendum that there was a certain incongruity in proposing amendments to the Australian Constitution when about half the population did not even know it existed. The same ignorance demonstrated in Iran can be shown in a society such as ours, even though it might not go as far as the Iranians have recently gone.

It is the ignorance in any community which leads to support of extremist groups. For example, in this country, the League of Rights was right behind much of the opposition to the referendum questions and we have paranoid malcontents such as the Peter Sawyer group. I believe that ignorance is the seedbed of extremism. We need to break down that cycle of ignorance which is so obviously and so patently present, according to the research that we have detailed in the report, among students and, unfortunately teachers and academics as well as the community at large.

Having looked at that broad area of whether ignorance is bliss or whether an informed society is better than an ignorant and sterile one, for those who want a more instrumental and economic approach there is also a good justification for making sure that our students and our populace at large are politically aware and articulate. In many vocational areas a knowledge of the political process is now considered essential. In the Public Service, for example, and increasingly in commerce, the media, the welfare sector and industry, a knowledge of the political process is considered to be a fundamental part of one's training. To be a decent manager nowadays is simply not good enough. One should have some idea about what goes on in the formulation of public policy.

Finally, I think there are lessons here for the Parliament. They are not spelt out clearly in the report, but I think they are implicit in it. I think there are lessons, particularly for those conservative minds within the parliamentary parties-and I mean all parties here-and within the parliamentary bureaucracy who oppose change for the sake of opposing change. It became clear when we talked not only to young people but to many of the people who appeared before us that the Parliament is seen as an archaic and out of touch institution. How can observers of parliament have any respect for the institution when they see it as so far removed from their everyday reality? How can visitors to this Parliament really understand what goes on when they see a person like me standing up and speaking to a handful of people, most of whom are half asleep-with no disrespect to anybody-or at least with glazed eyes, while the rest of the Parliament is absent, supposedly listening in, although I bet that not too many members are? How can people really understand that process? It is a silly, archaic process and it needs to be looked at. I know that currently there are attempts to do that. We need to make sure we throw out some of our old-fashioned ideas and really take up the challenge of modernising this Parliament to make it a little more relevant to the society in which we live. Not only is it a question of the behaviour in Parliament-and I think the events in the other House today give a good example of where that can be a big negative in influencing the views of the public towards this institution-but it is also a question of the anachronistic processes which people simply cannot relate to. That is one small aspect of a very broad problem over which we, as parliamentarians, have some direct control and ought to be able to do something about.

I believe that the writing of the report and the hearings were an enjoyable process, particularly, as Senator Patterson has already pointed out, with the active involvement of so many young people, which made it a lot more fun than the average public hearing. It is a very good example also of a productive use of a Senate committee, not only because we managed to come up with a consensus report and no minority report, but also because we took on an achievable task and were able to draw from submissions and public hearings the research necessary to develop a body of knowledge on an issue, and to come up with some realistic and sensible recommendations within the framework of our current constraints. This Committee did not enter into any political witch-hunt, as many Senate committees do, or try to reinvent the wheel. We undertook a small achievable task and did it well. I would like to thank the secretary, Derek Allan, and his staff and the other members of the Committee for their assistance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support my fellow members on the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training and to commend to the Senate the report entitled Education for Active Citizenship in Australian Schools and Youth Organisations and its recommendations. I am proud to have been associated with the preparation of this report. It has been a very stimulating experience. I draw this report to the attention of honourable senators. It is literally one of hundreds of documents that pass across our desks in a session, but I urge honourable senators to pluck this one out and to give it very serious and deliberate consideration.

SPEECH.PARA: I am proud to have placed this matter of active citizenship before the Committee. With the support of Senator Patterson, we urged the Committee to address the question of active citizenship. Probably the most satisfying aspects of having been associated with this report were the speed with which the Committee identified with what we were on about; the enthusiasm with which it was approached; the enthusiasm with which it was received by the community at large; the quality of submissions; and the very positive response to what was considered by the community as being an urgent need.

I was prompted to place the question of active citizenship before the Committee as a result of an experience I had working under the Australian Assistance Plan. Honourable senators may recall that that fine plan was introduced by the Whitlam Government, but unfortunately terminated only three years after it began. Essentially, the Australian Assistance Plan was a plan about people power which acknowledged the fact that communities have a great capacity to resolve their own difficulties, to marshal their own resources, to focus their attention on their own needs, to resolve their problems, and to satisfy their own needs.

I was enormously stimulated by that experience under the Australian Assistance Plan, but one of the things that became obvious to me in working in communities in this sort of process was that some communities are utterly powerless to resolve their own differences while other communities are quite powerful. There is a disproportionate distribution of these abilities within the community. In fact, some communities are quite frustrated; they do not know how to get their hands on resources and they do not know how to approach their problems. This disproportionate distribution of power, knowledge, skills, insight and commitment detracts from the quality of our democracy and, indeed, is an inherent limitation to the quality of democracy as it exists in Australia today. I think this was reinforced by the evidence that was brought before the Committee.

Of course, active citizenship is more than just knowing about government. It is something one feels in one's heart; it is something one feels in one's gut; it is a confidence that one is able to affect what happens in one's daily life because of the structures within which one works. If one does not have that positive attitude towards those structures and if one does not feel that commitment, one will not be an active citizen. As a result, communities will be powerless, impotent, disillusioned and apathetic.

TALK.START.PARA: —And vulnerable.

—Vulnerable, poor and everything else goes with these things in an affluent society such as ours. So active citizenship is something which one feels in one's heart and one knows to be one's own potency. Sadly, the evidence that came to us through this Committee was that young Australians, and indeed mature Australians, today do not feel those things. That lack of feeling, that impotence and that apathy greatly detract from the quality of our democracy. The strongest message to come through in this report and in the submissions that were made to the Committee is that this strikes at the very heart and the quality of our democracy and that, if we neglect it, we do so at our own peril. The evidence that came to us was that it is now neglected, and that neglect reflects our lack of responsibility towards the great Australian democratic processes.

SPEECH.PARA: We probably know more than most that the democratic and parliamentary process is imperfect. We also know that it can be improved, and we are looking at it from the point of view of those who have perception, knowledge and power. What must it look like from the point of view of those who do not have knowledge, perception and power? This report says to the Government that the quality of our democracy is less than it should be. It says quite clearly that we must address this as a matter of urgency, and it makes what we believe to be significant, achievable and realistic recommendations to the Government.

All of us as members of the Committee and certainly all of those who made submissions and provided evidence to it say to the Australian Government of today, `Please, address the recommendations of this report seriously. Please put in place very soon a national program of active citizenship by which we will dramatically enhance the quality of Australian democracy; by which we will attack the apathy that is out there; by which we will dismantle and counter the ignorance that is out there; by which Australians will begin to feel committed and potent, and stop feeling powerless; and by which we will render the great Australian democracy, of which we are indeed the elected representatives, much more effective in the interests of our community'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is vital that Australians of all ages are better able to understand their rights and privileges as citizens and also the obligations and commitments that active citizenship confers. Education for active citizenship through the Education for Active Citizenship report reveals that there are substantial gaps between theory and practice. There is almost universal agreement for active citizenship to be an educational goal. But unfortunately the strength of that commitment really leaves a lot to be desired. At the head of page 6 of the report we stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the situation revealed in this report amounts to a crisis which Australians cannot afford to ignore. These are indeed very strong words, but they are quite true.
We found at our public hearings in each of the States and through written submissions that many young Australians do not understand the Australian political system and how they can participate in it.

Political systems are like artworks. To appreciate them in full, they must be understood. It is in this area of understanding that we are falling down. I believe that any responsible educational system should equip all young people to be good citizens. But are we doing this? In fact, we are not doing it well. It is of concern to me, as it was to all members of the Committee, that the subject that used to be called `civics' is no longer taught in many schools. This has led to better educated young people knowing less about their rights and responsibilities than every before. The media can play a major role in educating people in citizenship. It is something that in the past has been largely neglected. We praise the Commonwealth Parliamentary Education Office and the work done by other parliaments, especially in New South Wales. But these are only peripheral attacks on a major problem.

One of the most sobering experiences for me during our public hearings was listening to articulate and intelligent students who came before us to plead for a more comprehensive education on active citizenship. These students showed by their understanding of our task that they would have greatly benefited from a course in active citizenship. At the first meeting of the Parliament in this building last year, the Governor-General, Sir Ninian Stephen, pointed out that only Britain, Canada, the United States of America and two European nations have a parliamentary democracy with an unbroken history longer than our own 88 years.

We have developed and refined an effective parliamentary system in each of the States, the Northern Territory, Norfolk Island and, shortly, the Australian Capital Territory. In 1947 the late Sir Winston Churchill spoke in the House of Commons about his views on democracy with this well-known saying:
Indeed, it has been said that democracy is the worst form of government, except all of those forms that have been tried from time to time.

It is not only the students who must be taught. Their teachers are also often found lacking in their ability to teach adequately about active citizenship. Alarming figures were presented to the Committee by the Mitchell College of Advanced Education. In a 1983 survey carried out by the college, only 5 per cent of first year teacher education students could name the Deputy Prime Minister of Australia and only 22 per cent could name the president of their own Students Representative Council.

Thus, the problem has to be tackled in more than one way. Teacher training institutions have to give active citizenship a much higher priority, as some colleges have already recognised. But active citizenship is not only concerned with understanding the Commonwealth parliamentary system. It should also include an appreciation of the State parliaments and how they work, of local government bodies and of such basic concepts as the independence of the judiciary, the role of the Crown and the idea of executive government.

Although the Committee's members were staggered at the lack of knowledge about civics, there are certainly encouraging signs. An example is the secondment of a teacher to the Parliament of New South Wales, specifically to assist that State Parliament's education program. Further moves in the right direction are illustrated by the excellent Parliamentary Pack and Parliamentary Pack 2 produced by the Parliamentary Education Office of this place. This provides opportunities for young people, especially those in remote parts of Australia, to see videos, play educational games and read well-presented material about their rights and obligations as citizens and a system of government which exists for them and all Australians. I commend all those various people who made contributions from all walks of life-from the schools, voluntary organisations such as the Girl Guides Association of Australia and others-because I thought their contributions and concerns were first rate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training report on education for active citizenship and draw attention to the remarks of both Senator Patterson and Senator McLean. In relation to the recent referendum in which we asked the people of Australia to vote on certain issues, as Senator Patterson has already indicated, a large proportion of the Australian population did not even know that Australia had a constitution, much less know what the content of it was. That really strikes at the very root of our democratic process because surely we must ask ourselves what it means when people vote in a certain way on issues of which quite clearly they have very little understanding. Of course, one can reflect on the recent Western Australian election where Grey Power was able to get one in 16 votes and quite clearly was an organisation with only a name. This again indicates the lack of understanding of many people when they go into a polling booth to exercise that very precious democratic right and elect governments which will determine many aspects of their lives for three or four years into the future.

SPEECH.PARA: Several people have used the word `apathy'. I certainly would not wish to blame the victim. I would not want to argue that what we are seeing here is in any sense apathy. I think that we have a combination of factors, some of which attention is drawn to in this report, namely, that our education in an understanding of the democratic process and how to participate in it and what it means is deficient. At the same time we have in many areas journalists, middle level editors and editors of newspapers who are more interested in titillating their readers than in properly informing them. Senator Beahan drew attention to an article in the Sydney Morning Herald which bears some repetition. An academic writing an article in that paper, which was obviously acceptable to the Sydney Morning Herald, said that there is a gap between democratic theory and political practice and that Australians had rightly chosen to respond with `a combination of ignorance, apathy and cynicism'. The repetition of that sort of remark merely serves to reinforce this attitude which we call apathy but which in fact is something which is quite positively produced in the Australian public by that combination of lack of education and the slick remark which causes people to disrespect the political process.
The report draws attention to the very grave dangers in which Australia finds itself as a result of these deficiencies. At page 8 of the report we read:

Some submissions saw dangers in current educational policies which appear to stress narrow labour market requirements and to underestimate the importance of a capacity for critical analysis of social and political issues . . . `we will pay a price, for we will end up with a technologically trained, but politically illiterate, young citizenry' . . . this trend is laying the ground for `the phenomenon of the skilled barbarian-a section of professional or educated society whose attitude towards civic questions or ideas is uninformed or crude to say the least'.

It is worth pausing there and stressing that we are in grave danger at this time when we have a government which appears to see education as a cost to society and not as a benefit and a government which sees the need to train people narrowly because education is seen as something which contributes principally to the economic benefit and the economic welfare of the country. In these times it is important to stress the other values of education-the values which produce widely literate, informed and critical citizens who can participate in the political process, make informed decisions and translate those decisions in their personal lives into intelligent voting patterns and can then, through that process, influence the government of the country.

The report also draws attention to the high levels of political ignorance already in the community. It draws attention to that by saying that it is a danger sign. It points to a situation in which accountability is weak-that is, the accountability of the elected parliaments at both Federal and State levels and at the local government level-and in which power may be concentrated in the hands of a few. In other words, it is relatively easy for those who are informed, those who are able to manipulate the political process, to concentrate power to the detriment of the many. The report goes on to state:
They are a warning that the quality of democracy may be under threat.
The deficiencies in the educational process are further expanded upon where the report says, quite unequivocally and without any qualifications:

Many children are reaching the end of their primary schooling without any real opportunity to grasp what is meant by participation in democratic processes or to understand what parts such processes play in the society around them.
The report continues:

Even on a conservative view of the matter, students stand more than an even chance of completing their secondary education without taking any course which genuinely prepares them to be an informed and active participant in the democratic process of Australian society.

I think it is worth stressing that there are enormous opportunities at school, particularly at the secondary grades, for students to participate both actively in the community and in their own democratic processes within the school in circumstances which give them a real understanding of democracy at work. For instance, most secondary schools have student representative councils (SRCs). Those councils have officers that stand in a unique position, such as the president or chairman of the school council, the vice-chairman and the secretary. There is an ideal opportunity for electing those members by a process similar to the processes of election which occur in the lower Houses of all the State parliaments.

Those SRCs also have committees. There is an ideal opportunity for those committees to be elected by processes which, in every respect, are the same as the processes by which we elect the Senate and the upper Houses in several States of Australia. I would commend the adoption of those practices. Given that understanding at the hands-on level, I believe that many students would be able to participate more actively in the community and understand the way in which they can properly exercise their vote to achieve the desirable ends. The report says that the aim should be to make maximum use of whatever opportunities are available within such subjects to focus on the question of participation in society-not just in the national context but right down to the level of the local community. I suggest that that starts right in the school where students are involved in the processes of election and determining, through that election process, how their school will be run.
The report concludes by drawing attention to the wider dimension of the political process. A quote at page 60 sums up the desirable end goal of this process:

. . . young people should be encouraged to progress beyond a purely insular view of the world and to become aware of the interdependence of all nations-in short, to see themselves as `global citizens'.
That leads directly to the principal recommendation of the report that the Commonwealth initiate a national program in education for active citizenship. I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present a report of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on matters relating to the Defence Service Homes Amendment Bill 1988.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a short statement in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 13 December 1988, the Senate referred to the Committee two matters relating to the Defence Service Homes Amendment Bill 1988, which is now an Act. These matters concerned the constitutionality of including certain clauses in the Bill and the constitutionality of the Bill itself. In preparing this report, the Committee sought opinions from various organisations and individuals with expertise and/or an interest in the matter before the Committee. For the information of honourable senators, those opinions are reproduced in the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill incorporated an agreement between the Commonwealth and Westpac concerning the sale of the Defence Service Homes Corporation to Westpac Banking Corporation. The agreement was a commercial and contractual arrangement between the Commonwealth and Westpac. It is a matter of commercial reality that Westpac would not wish to be bound by terms to which it had not agreed. Clause 6 of the agreement, upon which concern has been focused, merely preserved this right. On the basis of the material presented and the Committee's own examination of the issues, the Committee has concluded that there was nothing in the Bill which purported to limit or affect the Senate's power to amend legislation. In the Committee's view, the Bill did not give rise to any constitutional problems. The Bill expressly recognised the ability of the Parliament to amend the Bill as it thought fit. It also encompassed the concept that, if there is an agreement between the Commonwealth and a private institution such as Westpac, that institution, according to the usual rules of contract, should be entitled not to go ahead with an instrument which has been changed by one party, which in this case would have been the Commonwealth. As it turned out, the Bill is now an Act and the agreement has been consummated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act, I present reports relating to the following projects: construction of national medical cyclotron facility, Royal Prince Alfred Hospital, Sydney; construction of new communications and recruits schools, HMAS Cerberus, Crib Point, Victoria; and development of a military police complex at Green Hills, Liverpool military area, New South Wales. SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The Committee welcomes the Government's decision to establish a national medical cyclotron at the Royal Prince Alfred Hospital, Sydney. The provision of the facility will enable a production of a range of short-lived radioisotopes which presently are unavailable in Australia or have to be imported. The use of the cyclotron, in conjunction with a positron emission tomography camera, to be operated by the Royal Prince Alfred Hospital, will enable the introduction of technology which is vital to the early diagnosis and treatment of a wide range of medical conditions, including cancer, coronary heart disease, stroke, and severe trauma.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee's report on the construction of new communications and recruits schools at HMAS Cerberus, Crib Point, Victoria, at an estimated cost of $15.95m, is the second report the Committee has presented in relation to the redevelopment of HMAS Cerberus since November 1986. In November 1986 the Committee recommended the construction of the first phase of the redevelopment of facilities at HMAS Cerberus, including a wharf, seamanship school, marina and boat ramp, at an estimated cost of $14m.

The Committee has also recently held a public hearing into a further phase of the redevelopment of HMAS Cerberus-the upgrading of living-in accommodation. The Committee will report on this project shortly, the estimated cost of which is $15.7m. HMAS Cerberus is an historical base and the Committee is particularly pleased with the architectural design of the redevelopment and wishes to congratulate both the Department of Defence and Australian Construction Services for their efforts in this regard. However, in the report I have just tabled the Committee has suggested that there is merit in involving heritage organisations, particularly the Australian Heritage Commission, in heritage issues at an early stage in the planning process.

The Committee's report relating to the development of a military police complex at Green Hills continues the Committee's involvement in the upgrading of facilities in the Liverpool military area. Since mid-1986, the Committee has recommended the expenditure of approximately $95m on the upgrading of facilities in the Liverpool military area, including this project. This expenditure covers accommodation, warehouse facilities and the redevelopment of the School of Military Engineering. I commend the reports to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the suspension of the sitting for lunch, I was speaking to the motion moved by the Opposition's spokesman on women, Senator Hill, in respect of International Women's Day. The motion states:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate, on International Women's Day-
(a) applauds the efforts of farsighted and courageous women who have worked to improve the status of other women;

(b) pledges to fully recognise the contribution of women in the family and in the community and to continue to work to improve the status of women towards the goal of true economic, educational and social equality;

(c) recognises the achievements of the women's movement and those who have supported improvement in the status of women but acknowledges that true equality between the sexes has yet to be achieved; and

(d) notes that true equality of opportunity includes the freedom of choice of women to support children outside of paid employment and that such a choice requires greater recognition of and support for the unpaid work of mothers.

Prior to the luncheon break I had mentioned the courage of our pioneering women and the achievements of Kay Cottee, Mother Theresa and Sister Elizabeth Kenny. I would also like to pay a tribute to Jane Addams, the first woman to receive the Nobel Peace Prize, Madame Curie, who won the Nobel Prizes for physics and for chemistry, and Amelia Earhart, the famous woman flyer. Although there are many other women of note, perhaps I could add the names of just two other women-Mairead Corrigan and Betty Williams-who have taken an extremely courageous stand.

On 10 August 1976, in Belfast, Northern Ireland, an Irish Republican Army getaway car, its driver shot through the head by the British soldier whom he had attacked, jumped the kerb, crushed to death three young children and critically injured their mother. Hours later the mother's sister, Mairead Corrigan, then a 32-year-old secretary, appeared on television and denounced the Irish Republican Army. She was the first Catholic woman in Ulster who had dared to challenge the gunmen. Betty Williams, mother of two and wife of a seaman, lived just a few blocks away from the place where the tragedy occurred. When she met Mairead Corrigan, these two Catholic women began organising the people's peace movement. Despite their lack of experience, within two weeks some 30,000 Protestant and Catholic women in Northern Ireland were marching behind them, demanding an end to the violence.

That is the sort of courage which I believe women through generations have exhibited and which we acknowledge this day. There are so many names I could mention but, without a doubt, the unique contribution that women make to the world in the bearing and rearing of children is their most important contribution. The motion specifically refers to true equality of opportunity. It says that this:
. . . includes the freedom of choice of women to support children outside of paid employment and that such a choice requires greater recognition of and support for the unpaid work of mothers.

Yet so many mothers today are not given this choice. Indeed, we have seen how this choice has disappeared over the last six years that this Government has been in power. How this choice has disappeared was put very well by Eva Cox in her paper The Women's Tax Policy when she said:
The loss of income by families with children over the last five years comes from the following factors:
1. The loss in value of Family Allowances as these have not been indexed or increased since the advent of this government.

2. The loss of family allowances for families with joint income over the limit. This would be exacerbated by the fact that many of these families would include two full-time earners and have high child care costs.

3. Increases in child-care fees for many families due to changes in the funding system in 1985. The halving of the operational subsidy led to steep increases and the pegging of the top fee has also led to high fees for those with joint incomes over $35,000.
4. The fact that the cuts in income tax have been primarily directed at higher-income-earners with no compensatory payments, such as FAS, for most dual (but relatively low) income earners.
5. The rapid increase in housing costs and interest rates which fall primarily on households with younger children in their early mortgage stages.
6. The general fall in real wages which will affect spending power in larger households more than in smaller households as children are additional consumers.

That complete criticism by Eva Cox of the way that this Government led women to have high expectations but then deserted them completely is supported by our statistics, which show that women have turned from the Australian Labor Party and now intend to vote Liberal.

I would like to mention a few of those criticisms. I refer first to the loss of value of family allowances, which have not been increased once by this Government. Under the previous Fraser Government the family allowance was increased on three separate occasions: When we first came to power we made the previous rebate a family allowance which was paid right into the hands of the mother. On the second occasion we increased the allowance for the third and fourth children and on the third occasion we increased it across the board. As Eva Cox said, there has been a loss of family allowance to people with incomes exceeding the means-tested limit, decreasing the number of recipients of that benefit by 10 per cent. There has also been a loss of value in the dependent spouse rebate. When we first came to power we increased that allowance, for women with children, from $400 to the present $1,030. All these increases were put into effect by the Fraser Government. Not one increase has been made by this Government. Of course, the increases in the Fraser years were a direct recognition on our part of the unpaid work that women do in the home.

It is pointed out very clearly in the document Families and Tax in 1989, put out by the Institute of Family Studies, that there have been taxation increases through bracket creep. That document states that the average disposable income for families with two children increased by $34.23 under the Fraser Government. Under the Hawke Government it has decreased by $41.71: it is down by $7.48. There is a great need for the Government to answer this report, which is very clear and very indicting. It states that since 1984-85, under this Government, real disposable incomes have fallen sharply for all income unit dependants on one income. These falls have ranged from $30.61 for single persons to $47.85 for couples with four children. It is an absolute indictment of the way this Government has treated women. Yet we have had such rhetoric from this Government. We have had statements from the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, Senator Reynolds, for the past 12 months that the Government would spend money on domestic violence. Not one penny has been spent. She made the announcement in May last year, but the money that she has been talking about will not start to be spent until April this year.

We were told by Senator Crowley with great pride that this year women comprise more than 50 per cent of the work force. She had not attempted to establish whether this was what women wanted or what it would do to families. She did not try to establish that at all; she said with great pride that this was what the Government had done. You bet it is what the Government has done! It has forced more than 50 per cent of married women into the work force. We know that in many instances women are doing menial jobs which they do not want to carry out. If we are to have true equality, without any doubt we must give women a choice. I have a definition that I have used many times in this place for what I believe is true equality. I would like to repeat that definition tonight:

True equality, put simply, gives every woman the right to choose the type of life she wishes to live. She may choose the traditional role of wife and mother, she may choose to follow a wonderful career, she may choose a combination of the traditional role and a career or she may choose the traditional role and just another job, either full time or part time, to earn the extra money that she believes would be of great help to her family. She may choose to do some part time work just because she likes to accomplish something but wants to fit in with her family arrangements. Of course, the emphasis is on choice.

It is not on pushing or pressganging women into the work force. That is what high housing costs and interest rates-up to 16 per cent and 20 to 22 per cent for bridging finance-are doing to the women of Australia.

I do not think the Government understands what the situation is all about. When Senator Crowley got up in her place this morning she said that women were happy to be in the work force, but she could not know that without going through some of those menial jobs that the women are doing and without an understanding of what they are putting up with. Many women do not want to put their babies in childminding centres. They would prefer to have some financial recognition for the work they do in the home. I hope that the Senate at least will be unanimous on the definition I have given tonight of what true equality means to women. I feel that the Labor Party would agree. I am sure that Senator Harradine and perhaps even the Democrats, although they are not present, would also agree with my definition. I hope that at least it will have unanimous acceptance in the Senate on this International Women's Day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to commence my short contribution to this debate by saying that the feminist slogan that I appreciate more than any other I have seen is the one that says-and I think that there is some truth in it-that for a woman to compete on equal terms with a man she has to be better; fortunately, that is not very difficult.
—Hear, hear!
—My colleague says, `Hear, hear!'. There is no question that women have made the advances they have only in the last decade or so.
—What about the suffragettes?
—Typical male! Not a clue!
—There are women, and there are women! The most significant advances, real advances, tangible advances-and I am happy to debate this-have been made in the last decade or so.
—What is your assessment?

—I am sure one of the women opposite will agree that when suffragettes were necessary women had real advances. That is a nonsensical proposition, and those opposite know it. In the days when the Constitution which established Australia as a nation, was established, women had little role to play in the life of this country. Indeed, when the framework of the Constitution was established in 1898 the only women in Australia who had the right to vote at that time were residents of Western Australia and South Australia. An eminent commentator on the Australian Constitution, Professor La Nauze, made an interesting personal observation on the delegates who attended the first Constitutional Convention held in Australia. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Their average age was nearly 58. There was one clean-shaven member; one wore a moustache only; one a moustache and side-whiskers; the rest beards, more or less impressive. The clean-shaven features of Edmund Barton, Leader of the second Convention and the first Prime Minister of the Commonwealth, familiar in school text books, are untypical. The Constitution emerged from the labours of an overwhelmning majority of hairy men.

There is no question that Australian women have come a long way since then. Australian women were at the forefront of the suffragette movement around the world and won the right to vote in Federal election in 1902. They are now involved in updating the Australian Constitution, but it is generally considered that it has been only in recent years that really dramatic steps forward have been taken for women. In the past 15 years the concept of equal pay for work of equal value was enshrined into central wage-fixing systems. Unmarried mothers and deserted wives were provided with income support for the first time, and the Whitlam Government introduced subsidised child-care. Many significant advances have been made in education and employment. The advances, however, have not come quickly enough and obviously much is still to be done to enable women to make their own choices and to gain economic independence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Real choices.

—Real choices; that is correct. This Government is committed to the view that Australia cannot meet the challenges of the future if it does not allow the full and equal participation of women in society. This Government took a significant step last year with the release of its National Agenda for Women. The agenda, which sets out steps to advance the status of Australian women into the year 2000, was launched by Prime Minister Bob Hawke and the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, Senator Margaret Reynolds. The 70-page agenda is this Government's response to the views expressed by more than 25,000 women during exhaustive nationwide consultations with Senator Reynolds's predecessor, Susan Ryan. These consultations included large public meetings in the Northern Territory, and I am sure that many Territorians were eager to read the results of that agenda.

SPEECH.PARA: The release of the agenda followed the Federal Government's release of a report on Aboriginal women entitled Women's Business and the recently completed survey of rural women, Life Has Never Been Easy. The agenda set out specific plans for the next five years in areas nominated during those consultations and objectives to the year 2000. The areas covered are far too numerous to mention in the time available to me tonight, but include strategies to increase the capacity of women to participate in decision-making and to allow greater access to education, employment and training.

This Government is also looking to consolidate achievements in removing discrimination on the basis of sex and continuing recent initiatives in the area of domestic violence prevention, the portrayal of women in the media, housing and health. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) pledged at the launch of the agenda last year in Sydney that the Federal Government would remove the overall exception for sex and marital status discrimination in superannuation funds and schemes from the Sex Discrimination Act. I understand that that legislation is to be introduced into the House of Representatives shortly. Financial security, particularly in retirement, is a serious concern for women and few are covered by, or have access to, adequate superannuation, compared to men. However, statistics show that women generally retire earlier than men and are more likely to live longer.

Many women in very arduous circumstances have made an extraordinary contribution to the life of the Northern Territory. One of the most famous-and she must have been an extraordinary women indeed-was Emily Creaghe, who accompanied her husband on the Ernest Favenc expedition from the Gulf of Carpentaria through the Northern Territory in 1883. She was Australia's first woman explorer. One of the most extraordinary things about the trip was that she was pregnant at the time.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was not extraordinary. They were usually pregnant at that time.

—I say in response to that interjection that it was extraordinary for a woman to travel pregnant on horseback for six months through the Gulf of Carpentaria. Her diary, a fascinating document which I commend to Senator Newman, is in the Mitchell Library in Sydney and is worth reading. She was the first white woman many Aboriginals in the Northern Territory had seen. One of the most extraordinary sections of the diary-and I have read the original-was her shock and abhorrence when she called into a Northern Territory cattle station, walked into a shed and found nailed to the wall 40 pairs of human ears. They were ears that had been cut from the heads of Aboriginals who had been shot to death by the station in reprisal for the spearing of cattle. That is in the diary.

SPEECH.PARA: Some extraordinary women in the Northern Territory lived in the most appalling circumstances. What was typical in those days was not only their having to bear children a great deal of the time but seeing those children die very early in their lives. The history of the Northern Territory is full of women who bore seven, eight or nine children and saw none of them live past the age of five. Many of these women lived alone in the most extraordinary circumstances while their husbands were out fishing or mustering cattle-alone for six months at a time. Fortunately, the contribution of those women in the Northern Territory is about to be finally enshrined in print. They are about to come out of the darkness in which they have sheltered for the last 80 years. A book entitled No Man's Land, Women of the Northern Territory is about to be published. I am pleased to be able to say that the author of the book, Barbara James, was my former press secretary when I was Leader of the Labor Party in the Northern Territory. The book, even though read only in its proof stage, has been heralded as a significant contribution to the acknowledgment of the extraordinary role played by women in the development of Australia. I am pleased to be able to contribute to this debate and fully support Senator Hill's motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to add my contribution to the motion put forward earlier today by Senator Hill on International Women's Day. In rising to speak on it, I place on record that I look forward to a day when in this place and on the parliamentary broadcast airwaves I will hear a motion to the effect that the Senate take note that it is pledged to recognise fully the contribution of men in the family and in the community and will continue to work to improve the status of men towards the goal of true economic, educational and social equality and notes that true equality of opportunity includes the freedom of choice of men to support children outside of paid employment and that such a choice requires greater recognition of and support for the unpaid work of fathers. It needs to be recognised that only when men and women are truly equal can the status not only of women but also of men be enhanced. It will only be when full time child-caring is given the status of full time paid work for the good of the community and the economy of the country and is not regarded as holding back a career for either men or women that true equality will exist. The househusband, like the housewife, deserves full status recognition. Suitable, affordable child-care also needs to be available to all who require it, both mothers and fathers. In this way, we can achieve for everybody the economic, educational and social equality that is sought in the resolution.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look briefly at something of the history of women in the professions. An Age editorial in the 1870s stated:

. . . The ladies are again to the front, clamoring for the right of plucking the fruit of the Tree of Knowledge, and it seems certain this right cannot be denied them very long. They pass the matriculation examination by scores and find themselves disqualified at the first fence in the steeplechase whose prize is a degree . . .
Janet Hawley, in her review of Dr Farley Kelly's book Degrees of Liberation: a Short History of Women in the University of Melbourne, writes:

This Age editorial of the 1870s admirably summed up the predicament faced by young women in Victoria who were barred from entering the University of Melbourne. It was not until 1880-27 years after the University's foundation-that women were admitted to its corporate rights and privileges. The legal right of entry was only a first step in women staff and students' long battle for full acceptance and equality with their male colleagues.
The review continues:
The opposition was particularly strong in relation to medicine which, it was believed, would `unsex' lady practitioners.
In her book, Dr Kelly writes:

There was some trade jealousy and some genuine revulsion at the thought of the protected female encountering brutal bodily facts. The horror expressed at the notion of a female physician wielding a surgical knife about a defenceless male body requires little elaboration for post-Freudian readers.
Janet Hawley's article continues:

In concluding degrees of liberation, Dr Kelly offers the following reflection: ``The first women students of the 1880s and 1890 had expected much and much had been expected of them in return. Their intellectual demands were certainly satisfied; full professional recognition and independence were not so easily pursued or attained. As students they enjoyed, by and large, more nearly egalitarian treatment than they would later encounter in the competitive world of work or within the conventional marriage structure. These conditions have not yet altered greatly.''

In an article in the Age of 4 May last year, headed `Medicine remains a male stronghold', Valerie Colyer Farfalla reports that women doctors remain in second-class jobs because they are forced, unlike their male peers, to choose between career and family obligations. She writes:
Women in medicine are struggling to achieve even half of the salary and status of their male counterparts . . .

They have circumscribed careers, often spent working for male doctors or government organisations, rather than running their own private clinics. They are less likely to publish books or do research, or work as teachers of medicine.
Their absence in senior administrative or policy-making positions, says Dr Dennerstein, means they have little say on medical courses or practices.

Let us consider now how the specialists line up. Twelve per cent of paediatricians in Australia are women; 17 per cent of anesthetists are women; 2 per cent of surgeons are women; 8 per cent of physicians; 18 per cent of trainee physicians and 9 per cent of gynecologists and obstetricians are women. Caroline Falls, under the by-line `women in Business', writes:
The number of women graduating in medicine has increased dramatically in the past 30 years. Today women represent between 40 and 50 per cent of graduates from most Australian medical courses . . .

As honourable senators will understand, those percentages do not reflect that graduation level of women in medicine. That is because, in the current order of things, to specialise, a medical graduate needs to do post-graduate training for a minimum of six years and up to 10 years without interruption. Those sorts of courses certainly hold women back in the medical area. We certainly still have a long way to go.

I would like to place on record here some of my own experiences in this area. I had my first child in hospital under a very male dominated and paternalistic system. The obstetrician expressed surprise that I demanded to have a say not only in the control of what medication I had and any procedures to be used, but also to know exactly what was going on at all times. He made snide remarks such as, `Do you intend to study midwifery when all of this is over?'. I was more fortunate when giving birth to my subsequent children at home in my own environment and in my own way with the aid of a sympathetic, sensible and sensitive midwife. It is unfortunate that in Australia today if women chose to have their babies at home they cannot get full Medicare rebates. The privilege is reserved for the few who can afford it.

Women are making their way in many professions, not only medicine. Many articles have been written on women in the professions. There are too many for me to quote from, but I list some of the headings: `Women in the law-The takeover begins'; `Women Scientists on the Move'; `Time to give girls a go in non-traditional trades'; `First woman to head engineering school'; and so on. It can be seen that women are making their way in the professions.

In conclusion, I express the hope that we have moved forward from what Geoffrey Blainey, now Professor Geoffrey Blainey, wrote in A Centenary History of the University of Melbourne, published in 1956:
. . . the admission of women to all the lectures of the universities cramped the style of the professors who could no longer illustrate their lectures with `bawdy stories'.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 20 October 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) If medical practitioners do not fulfil their duty to inform parents and children about the effects of prescribed drugs, e.g. Ritalin, where does the responsibility lie to ensure full information is being given about the risks of taking drugs.
(2) What safeguards can be enforced so that this information is provided.
(3) Is the American Psychiatric Association's Diagnostic and Statistical Manual III the method used for diagnosing ``hyperactivity'' in Australia.
(4) Is the Minister aware that this `diagnostic criterion' is the subject of multi-million dollar law suits in the United States.
(5) Is coverage for this ``diagnostic criterion'' available under Medicare; if so, why.

(6) Is a side effect of the drug Ritalin listed as drug dependence by its manufacturer, Ciba-Geigy: if so, what specific information or medical studies is the Department of Community Services and Health using to conclude that the proper use of Ritalin does not necessarily lead to addiction.
(7) What monitoring has occurred in relation to the effects of Ritalin and Dexamphetamine and when was the last comprehensive report on any adverse effects requested and/or made.
(8) Is there material pertaining to adverse effects of Ritalin in the Department of Community Services and Health library; if so, what actions have been taken on these reports of adverse reactions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Housing and Aged Care has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Medical practitioners have an ethical responsibility to obtain informed consent from patients for the administration of therapy. In the case of children, informed consent would need to come from the parent or guardian of the child.

The primary responsibility therefore rests with the prescriber. If a medical practitioner has not adequately informed patients about the effects of prescribed drugs, some information may be provided by the dispensing pharmacist who will hold a copy of the product information for the drug concerned.

Manufacturers may sometimes print special instructions, warnings or other notifications on the packaging or provide them in the form of a package insert. The manufacturer of Ritalin, Ciba Geigy Australia Ltd., does not provide a patient package insert.

Ritalin is scheduled under the poisons scheduling arrangements as a Schedule 8 medicine. This means that written State or Territory Government authority (except South Australia) is required before Ritalin may be prescribed to any patient.

(2) Medical practitioners and pharmacists are bound by professional standards of ethical behaviour. The Commonwealth does not have the power to direct the behaviour of individual professionals. However, it is concerned that the highest ethical standards in professional practice be maintained. In the event that damage occurs to the patient as a result of inadequate advice then legal advice may be sought concerning appropriate remedies through the courts.

(3) Individual medical practitioners may refer to this description if they so wish. The description for ``attention deficit disorder'' (which you describe as ``hyperactivity'') is an inclusive and general one. The description given in DSM III would need to be balanced against the clinical picture used to formulate the professional's diagnosis. Since concepts such as ``inattention'', ``impulsivity'', ``hyperactivity'' are subjective assessments and part of a continuum including normality, the applicability of DSM III, or any other organisation's criteria would be decided by the medical practitioner on a case by case basis.

(4) Media reports of this have been noted by the Department of Community Services and Health. The precise particulars of the legal action against the American Psychiatric Association are not known to me.
(5) Under the Medicare arrangements, benefits are payable towards the cost of professional services rendered by legally qualified medical practitioners.

The diagnosis of ``attention deficit disorder'', when performed by a medical practitioner, would therefore, attract Medicare benefits. It is not possible to differentiate between services on the basis of the diagnostic technique which an individual practitioner may deem appropriate in particular circumstances.

(6) Ciba-Geigy do list dependence as a side effect of Ritalin. In addition, there is information on dependence under the heading Precautions. I will provide Senator Childs with a copy of the product information for Ritalin as published in the Prescription Proprietaries Guide of 1987.

The Department has never evaluated Ritalin as the drug was marketed in Australia prior to any requirement for the submission and evaluation of data. However, a recent article in Australian Prescriber volume 9 number 4 concerning the treatment of hyperactive children states that after decades of use overseas there is still no reputable evidence that this treatment leads to addiction. A copy of this article will be provided separately.

(7) The side effects in relation to the use of Ritalin, Dexamphetamine, and other marketed drugs are monitored continuously through a voluntary adverse reaction reporting scheme administered by the Department and assisted professionally by the Adverse Drug Reactions Advisory Committee, a sub-committee of the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee. A copy of the adverse reactions to Ritalin and Dexamphetamine reported between November 1972 and August 1988 is being provided to Senator Childs. There are 3 reports to Ritalin and 2 to Dexamphetamine. None is of dependence.

(8) The Department gives weight to the voluntary reporting scheme referred to in the answer to question 7. Literature searches can be undertaken on a ``needs'' basis. The library service is not used in the first instance.

The library of the Department of Community Services and Health contains a very large number of books and journals. To search the library's contents for all material pertaining to adverse effects of Ritalin would be an enormous undertaking and has not been done. It is likely however that material pertaining to adverse effects to Ritalin does exist in the library and it would be possible to identify some of the material by searching several computerised drug information databanks. Such searches are not routinely performed after a drug is marketed unless there are reasonable grounds. Manufacturers of imported drugs are expected to inform the Department of previously unrecognised significant or serious adverse reactions to their products.

(4) If the Minister will not re-list the drug, will he give an undertaking to make special provision for pensioners who require Persantin in the treatment of their illness.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Housing and Aged Care has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I accepted the advice of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC) that the drug dipyridamole should be deleted from the PBS. Persantin is a brand of dipyridamole.

(2) Yes. Having noted reports indicating doubt as to the usefulness of the drug, the PBAC requested the manufacturer of Persantin to provide whatever data were available to support the drug's efficacy.
On reviewing the data submitted, the PBAC was of the view that there was indeed a lack of efficacy data.
The matter has been reviewed by the PBAC on several occasions.

(3) I am unable to indicate why patients with transient ischaemic attacks appear to obtain benefits from the drug. Persantin has never been approved for use in Australia for this purpose as the application from the manufacturer to include transient ischaemic attacks as an indication was rejected by the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee.
(4) No such undertaking can be given as under the National Health Act there is no capacity for special provisions to be made.
